PROCTEXT.PARA: The Senate met at 9 a.m.
The Clerk-Pursuant to the leave of the Senate granted yesterday, Senator Peter Baume will take the chair.
The ACTING PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Peter Baume) took the chair, and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney Airport: Third Runway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth that the Federal Labor Government is procrastinating over the decision on the third runway at Sydney Airport. An immediate decision to construct the third runway is essential to ensure that regional air links are maintained to Sydney Airport. Continued access by rural airlines to Sydney Airport is essential for business purposes in the Sydney Central Business District (CBD), to connect with interstate and international flights, for essential legal, health and welfare services, and to encourage decentralisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East: Australian Military Personnel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The hasty deployment of Australian military personnel to the Middle-East at the request of the President of the United States has involved Australia in an undeclared war with potentially disastrous consequences for Australia and the people of the Middle-East.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Immediately withdraw all Australian military personnel from the Middle East and pursue a foreign policy designed to secure justice and human rights for all of the people of the Middle-East.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Hedland-Marble Bar Road
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Port Hedland/Marble Bar road is in terrible condition;
As far back as the early 1950s the people of Marble Bar were promised an all weather road;
The poor state of the gravel road is deterring tourists from seeing the many attractions in the Marble Bar area and causing untold damage to the town's economy.
Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure that funds are made available for the essential upgrading of this important road.
As in duty bound your petitions will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Farm Exemption
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the Government is planning to introduce an assets test on Family Allowance at a level of $500,000. It will maintain the current assets tests on Family Allowance Supplement (FAS), Austudy and Isolated Children's Allowance which are discriminating against farming families particularly during the present rural crisis.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Family Allowance, Isolated Children's Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
- gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
- gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
- fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
- could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
- request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bushmead Rifle Range
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your Petitioners request the Senate to urge the Federal Government to retain the Bushmead Rifle Range in Western Australia;
That it remain in the hands of the Federal Government with a commitment to its ongoing use by the various rifle clubs of Western Australia.
Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING (PROHIBITION OF BROADCASTING OF TOBACCO ADVERTISING) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting Act 1942 to prohibit the incidental broadcasting of tobacco advertising.
Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I am introducing this Private Member's Bill to remedy a major deficiency in the Broadcasting Act. The Bill would close the loophole in that Act which allows the incidental advertising of tobacco products on broadcast media.

It is a matter of great regret to me that it has proven necessary to introduce this Bill. Earlier this month, I moved amendments to Government legislation to close the loophole but both the Governments and the Opposition-with the honourable exception of Senators Baume, Herron and Archer-saw fit to oppose those amendments.

Various unconvincing arguments were advanced by those who opposed the amendments, ranging from the suggestion that now is not the right time to close the loophole, even though it should be closed through to the longstanding furphy about freedom of choice.

All honourable Senators are aware of the support for this measure from medical and consumer organisations who will not desist in their efforts to have it passed by the Parliament. I, too, will continue my efforts, as evidenced by this Bill.
At the time I moved my amendments, I outlined the undeniable reasons for supporting this measure and I want to reiterate those reasons in relation to this Bill.

Honourable senators will be aware-if they are not I will make them aware-that the so-called direct advertising of tobacco products was phased out of the Act between September 1973 and September 1976, but that advertising, which was defined as `accidental or incidental' to broadcasting remained permissible. I understand that this innocuous sounding caveat was an eleventh hour amendment successfully lobbied for by the tobacco industry. That was before the Australian Democrats either existed or had representation in this Parliament.

I also believe that few parliamentarians at the time could really have known just how effectively that loophole in the Act would be exploited. Following the passage of that legislation in the 1970s, the tobacco companies set about buying out Australian sport and, by 1980, the Anti Cancer Council of Victoria tells us, the tobacco industry owned every sporting event worth having-high profile televised events such as tennis, cricket, Rugby League, Australian Rules, horse racing, golf, soccer, ballet and opera: the list is almost endless.

In 1989, the tobacco industry spent an estimated $20m on sporting sponsorship, of which $12m went to sporting bodies and $8m to promotion, through this loophole in the Act. This is no act of sporting philanthropy on behalf of tobacco companies. It has been a deliberate and highly successful effort to gain access to the broadcast media, access facilitated by the loophole which was retained at the time of the amendment in 1973.

A number of studies have shown just how much television coverage cigarettes have received since the so-called ban in 1976. The Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria estimated that the televising of test cricket over the summer of 1980-81 gave the sponsors Benson and Hedges at least 72 hours of coverage. This included 40,000 exposures of the name Benson and Hedges on a single channel. Things have not improved. A recent report has shown that during one day's play of a Benson and Hedges-sponsored cricket match televised from Sydney in 1988, the television spectator would have seen the Benson and Hedges name or logo clearly for a full 88 minutes of that one day's coverage.

Equally concerning are the Grand Prix events which feature vehicles predominantly sponsored by tobacco companies. An analysis of television coverage received by Marlboro's Formula One racing car in the Adelaide 1989 Grand Prix show that the Marlboro name gained prominent exposure for up to 36 per cent of broadcasting time. There are other statistics of this nature which have been circulated to all senators and members. I also commend to the attention of all honourable senators a report-a very well documented study-by Donald Martin circulated by the Australian Medical Association. There is no question that the tobacco industry has deliberately sought to circumvent the intention of the Act as it stands. This has been revealed in a number of court cases. An example is the contract between Rothmans' Winfield and the New South Wales Rugby League which was revealed during the Federal High Court case in 1985. A number of clauses in the contract ensured maximum exposure and assistance from the League in gaining high quality exposure, and that exposure was specifically for Winfield cigarettes. Interestingly, there was also an escape clause. The company had the right to terminate the contract if the kinds of advertising and promotion it sought through its sponsorship were restricted or banned by government or any other authority. Not surprisingly, the judges in that case in 1985 agreed that ``the sponsorship arrangement was intended as an advertising opportunity rather than an act of sporting philanthropy''.

The same court case examined the contract struck between Benson and Hedges and the Australian Ballet. In this contract an incredible 75 per cent of sponsorship money was earmarked for advertising and promotional purposes, leaving the remaining 25 per cent of the funds to be used at the recipient's discretion. In another High Court case decided only in February this year, United Telecasters-Channel 10-was convicted for broadcasting a cigarette advertisement in the form of a Winfield spectacular, a dance extravaganza featuring the Winfield name and logo that took place just before the beginning of the 1984 New South Wales Rugby League Grand Final. Yet more evidence was stacked up in that case against Rothmans.

Further, in the much publicised Mr Fix-it trial, also earlier this year, in which a former Rothmans executive was tried for fraud, in his summing up of the evidence the judge stated, and I think it is worth quoting: The company's main concern in all this . . . would seem to have been to circumvent the ban placed upon the advertising of tobacco products on television not only by having events assume the company's brand name but also by ensuring that the advertising signs were transmitted on television. No one seems to have questioned the legality of all this, a question which perhaps would now have to be reconsidered in the light of the High Court's decision, the Department of Public Prosecutions v United Telecasters Sydney Limited (which was decided only on 15 February last).

I could continue to lay before the Senate other examples of a multitude of breaches of the Broadcasting Act, which we are considering today. In short, the legislation-if it is intended, as it says, to ban the advertising of tobacco products-is not working. It has been found before the High Court to have been breached on a number of occasions. It is clearly time for the Parliament to act in this area.

My Bill seeks simply to remove the so-called incidental advertising provision. Material which is genuinely accidental to broadcast would continue to be permitted. It comes as no surprise to the Democrats that our proposal has met with strong tobacco industry opposition. The tobacco industry's arguments in defence of its actions and position and of continued advertising through sponsorship are fatuous in the extreme. I am reluctant to bring its arguments before the Senate as I do not want to give the industry any particular credibility. But as we will be hearing them in the future, as we have in the past, until I imagine it believes the Democrats' resolve has crumbled, which probably will not be until hell freezes over, I suppose I should take the opportunity briefly to refute at least some of the arguments.

The tobacco companies ask us to believe that their advertising has no effect on children and that it is merely to encourage brand loyalty, or to persuade existing smokers to swap brands. They claim that restriction of their access to electronic media via sports sponsorship is an incursion on their right to free speech. The industry also threatens the demise of sport as we now know it in this country should we amend the Broadcasting Act in this way.

I will take each of those particular claims in turn. With total smoking prevalence declining in Australia by about one per cent a year bringing about an estimated annual reduction of smokers of about 120,000, for the tobacco industry to remain viable, clearly it must recruit new smokers. We have very good evidence which shows that children are influenced by tobacco sponsorships. The Australian Cancer Society conducted a national survey in 1984 to measure the smoking habits of Australian schoolchildren. In an interview last week on a radio station in another State, when I sought to quote this survey I was accused of quoting surveys from vested interests. In this debate I would much prefer to quote surveys from the Cancer Society whose vested interests, I would suggest, are positive, than to quote surveys from anyone connected with the tobacco industry whose vested interests are material at the very least, and damaging at the very worst.

This survey was conducted in 1984 to measure the smoking habits of Australian schoolchildren. As well as finding alarmingly high smoking rates among schoolchildren the study also identified different brand preferences in different States. It is interesting to look at them. In New South Wales and Queensland, far more children smoked Winfield where Winfield received high exposure through sponsoring the major winter sport, rugby league. Escort was favoured among South Australian children where it sponsored the Australian Rules Escort Cup. Escort was not one of the leading brands anywhere else in Australia.

In Victoria, Peter Jackson was the most popular brand, followed by Winfield. Both of these brands are heavily advertised, or were at the time, through the Victorian Football League in a number of forums and in particular on television.

The freedom of speech argument is a favourite of the tobacco industry. In this context, freedom of speech means the freedom to advertise a highly dangerous and addictive product that killed in excess of 18,000 Australians in 1987. Frankly, I believe that a more important freedom is that of children to be free of advertising pressure to adopt smoking. Recent media reports of a British study state that over 90 per cent of teenagers who smoke three to four cigarettes a day are trapped into a career of regular smoking which typically lasts for some 30 to 40 years. The report from the Australian Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare on drug problems in Australia, chaired by Senator Peter Baume in 1977; the Better Health Commission, established by Dr Neal Blewett in 1985; and, only last year, the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, have all endorsed the view that there is no place for tobacco advertising in the Australian community. At the end of last year, through the all party support for my private member's Bill, which placed a ban on the print advertising area, we saw that even the Parliament as a whole had finally come to the view that it was time for us to act again federally for the first time since the mid-1970s.

If tobacco advertising has been a blight on the print media, then it is equally a blight on the electronic media in spite of the Act as it stands which nominally places a ban on that advertising. It is naive to regard the forms of advertising as different entities. Tobacco sponsorship is tobacco advertising.

Let us have a look at the tobacco industry's threats about the certain decline and fall of Australian sport as we know it in the absence of tobacco sponsorship. I make it very clear that my Bill does not prevent tobacco sponsorship of anything. In Canada, the Canadian Government has simply banned tobacco sponsorship of sporting events. If the tobacco companies wish to respond by withdrawing their funding of certain sporting bodies, I suppose that will show us that the arguments we have put about sponsorship being advertising are very clear, but I do not believe that should hinder the passage of these amendments in any way.

I hope that honourable senators will be aware of the very successful health promotion foundations that have been established in Victoria and South Australia, funded by purpose-built levy mechanisms on wholesale sales of tobacco products and providing considerable support and replacement sponsorship to sport and other health-related activities.
A mere one per cent of revenue from the Federal excise on tobacco would provide $12.5m, sufficient to replace current tobacco company expenditure on sport sponsorship.

I believe that the Federal excise on tobacco products is currently under review. I also believe that submissions are being made to Cabinet at the time that we engage in this debate and I commend those submissions to the Government.

As I have said, under the terms of this Bill, sporting and other organisations would be free to continue to accept sponsorship from tobacco companies if they wished, subject to legislation enacted at State level. Tobacco companies would be permitted-as they are in the United Kingdom and West Germany-to use their colours, they simply would not be allowed to display trademarks, brand names or logos. As I said, that happens in Europe. In those countries tobacco companies have demonstrated that they are quite able to comply with that level of regulation, and it is the utmost in hypocrisy for them to say in Australia that the livelihood of Australian sport would be threatened. If we allow ourselves to fall for that argument, I suggest that we are succumbing to precisely the blackmail that the tobacco industry always intended, and the tobacco industry will not only have bought sport, but government or the Parliament as well, with the exception of the Australian Democrats who are putting forward these proposals.

Honourable senators may be aware that one recent parliamentary report does not recommend the ban of tobacco sponsorships for sport-that is, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, in its second report on an inquiry into sports funding and administration. This report does not favour a ban on tobacco sponsorship which, as I have already said, is not the purpose of what we are proposing to do with the legislation before us.

The report went on to conclude that a complete ban on the accidental and incidental televising of cigarette products is not realistic on the grounds that it would be an impossible piece of legislation to enforce. I agree with that. That is precisely why in the amendments I am putting forward I am proposing to continue to allow accidental broadcasting of tobacco advertisements. `Accidental' means just that-accidental. If an event is being filmed and somebody wanders past with a Marlboro tee-shirt on, that is not the fault of the organisation involved. It is not my intention to devise troublesome legislation that would be open to vexatious litigation; indeed, I think I have already demonstrated that litigation is exactly what is happening with the legislation as it currently stands.

I remind honourable senators of the level and strength of support in the general public for action in this area; indeed, support specifically for the amendments which the Australian Democrats will be moving. As I said, there was all party support for a move in the print media a few months ago. It would be inconsistent in the extreme of both the coalition and the Government to fall away at this stage from a public health move of major significance and to close what is a dramatically damaging loophole in some legislation which is clearly the Federal Government's responsibility. There can be no claims that this is not within the responsibility of the Federal Parliament. Quite clearly it is. This Bill goes forward with the strongest endorsement from medical and health groups, as well as from a range of wider community groups. State governments are increasingly taking what action is open to them within their jurisdiction with, I regret to say, the notable exception of New South Wales.

It is up to us, as Federal legislators, to meet our responsibility to support the landmark work that has already been passed in Victoria and South Australia, that is in passage in Western Australia and is being proposed in other States, and to push those States that are being laggardly in this process.

Tobacco related illness, death and disease are costing our community dearly. The Democrats are putting forward a very sensible rational proposal. There is no economic and, certainly, no moral argument for not taking this step. I tell the Senate that as I move amongst young people, and I do that as its being of the highest priority when I am not in this place-I visit their schools and talk to them in every other environment in which I can-I find that it is a matter of very great concern to young people that there is such a close link between sport and drugs and even an apparent or accepted dependence of sport on drugs.

We make a lot of song and dance-indeed there are some people in this chamber and in the other place with whom it seems to be an absolute obsession-about drugs in sport. Tobacco is a drug. I might be corrected, but I think that of the legal drugs, it is the only one of which we could say that there is no safe dose. I do not know about all the illegal drugs, but we could probably say the same thing, based on our present knowledge. Tobacco is certainly a grossly damaging substance. The very fact that it is legal is irrelevant in this debate. As for those people who say, `Why don't you just ban tobacco smoking?', we know that would not work; we know that all that would create is a black market and quite probably even more peer pressure on young people. We have a responsibility to take the pressure off whoever it is and not allow the promotion of a product which we know costs our community so dearly-over $2 3/4 billion a year at least.

The health bodies, such as the Australian Medical Association Ltd, the Heart Foundation, the Asthma Association, the anti-cancer councils and a whole range of other groups, are putting their voices so strongly behind this move because they are the ones who have to cope with the damage that is created in our community. Amongst us in the Parliament are people from the medical fraternity who know very well the gross damage which tobacco causes. I make a plea to them, in particular, for leadership within their various parties on this particular issue.

I could not commend anything more strongly to both sides of the chamber. We owe it to our young people and to their future. If we cannot bring ourselves to take this action for them, at least we should take it on the basis that we need not be spending $2 3/4 billion, largely out of the health budget, which we could put better into the other activities by way of government expenditure. This Bill corrects what we believe is a gross deficiency in the Broadcasting Act. I commend that action to both sides of the chamber.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report:

(a) the mechanisms available to parties dissatisfied with determinations made by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission pursuant to section 81 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, section 25Z of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and by the Privacy Commissioner pursuant to section 52 of the Privacy Act 1988;
(b) the costs arising as a result of those mechanisms; and
(c) whether, having regard to the provisions of the Constitution relating to the conferral of the judicial power of the Commonwealth, alternative, less costly, procedures can be developed.
(2) That these issues be considered in the context of the Committee's current reference on the cost of legal services and litigation, as a discrete part of that inquiry.
I seek leave to incorporate a short statement in relation to the reference in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON
LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS
Statement in relation to new terms of reference
Under the Privacy Act 1988, the Privacy Commissioner can investigate a complaint about an interference with privacy and then make a determination.

The determination might dismiss the complaint, or find the complaint substantiated and make a declaration, for example that the act constituting the interference should not continue or that any damage or loss suffered should be redressed or compensated, or that any further action in the matter would be inappropriate.

The Privacy Commissioner can determine rights between private parties, but he is unable to enforce his determinations because he does not exercise judicial power. This is a constitutional limitation on the exercise of the Commonwealth's judicial power. It is not simply a question of conferring such power on the Privacy Commissioner.

During the Committee's hearings in October on the Privacy Amendment Bill, there was discussion of appeals from determinations of the Privacy Commissioner. The problem that was discussed by the Committee was the difficulty of a party, in this case a credit provider, subject to a determination of the Privacy Commissioner, but unhappy with that determination. If the party were to continue with conduct contrary to the Privacy Commissioner's determination, it would be up to the Privacy Commissioner or the person who made the original complaint to bring an action in the Federal Court to enforce the Privacy Commissioner's determination. At the most, the credit provider could seek judicial review of the Privacy Commissioner's decision, but far from being an appeal, this review would be narrowly based, for example, on an alleged lack of natural justice or irrelevant consideration.

The minister rejected the proposal that AAT review be provided in relation to determinations of the Privacy Commissioner. He said it would impose `an unnecessary additional burden upon complainants'. He pointed out also that the AAT itself is subject to the same constitutional limitations as the Privacy Commissioner in so far as it lacks judicial power and therefore the power to make binding decisions. Enforcement action would have to be taken in a court.
Review by the AAT was considered to be inappropriate also because of the role of the AAT. It reviews decisions of Commonwealth agencies; it has not to date had a dispute resolution function.

Despite his rejection of the suggestion that such an appeal mechanism should be incorporated in the legislation, the minister acknowledged the concerns that had been raised by Committee members and also the

somewhat intimidatory prospect of having to pay a considerable sum of money to get into the Federal Court for a de novo hearing by way of being the only means open to review of [the] Privacy Commissioner's determination . . .

He undertook to consult with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in drawing up suitable terms of reference which would enable the Committee to investigate the question of appeals in more detail. It was considered this was a matter appropriately dealt with in the context of the Committee's larger inquiry into the cost of legal services and litigation.

Because similar issues arise in relation to other decisions that may be made under the Commonwealth's human rights legislation, the terms of reference have been drawn in such a way as to include those decisions, namely, decisions under section 25Z of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and section 81 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (DUTIES AND POWERS OF PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Spindler) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the National Crime Authority Act 1984 in relation to the duties and powers of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.
Motion (by Senator Spindler) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
S.55(1) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 provides: ` `(The duties of the Parliamentary Joint) Committee (on the National Crime Authority) are:
(a) to monitor and to review the performance by the Authority of its functions.''

Subsequent subsections provide for reports by the Committee to both Houses of Parliament on the performance of the Authority and impose on the Committee the duty to examine the Authority's annual reports and to report on them to Parliament, to examine trends and charges in criminal activities, to inquire into any relevant question referred to it by either House of Parliament and to report on it.''

Subsection 2 expressly states that the Committee may not (a) ``investigate a matter relating to a relevant criminal activity'' or (b) ``reconsider the findings of the Authority in relation to a particular investigation.''

The important aspects of S.55 are firstly the clear duty placed upon the Committee to monitor and to review the Authority's performance and the prohibition in paragraph (2) (a) on investigating a matter relating to a relevant criminal activity.
Clearly this section has been drawn so widely as to hamper any reasonable attempt by the Committee to fulfil its duties.

It is one of the objectives of my private Senator's Bill to remove the unreasonable component of this restriction by omitting the words ``a matter relating to'' from S.55 (2) (a), so that the Committee is now prohibited only to investigate a relevant criminal activity or to reconsider the findings of the Authority in relation to a particular investigation, thus giving the Committee reasonable scope to fulfil its duty to Parliament.

The other major provision of the National Crime Authority Act which has hampered the work of the Committee is Section 51 which prohibits a member of the Authority or a staff member to disclose any information acquired in the course of his or her work with the National Crime Authority. The suggestion has been made that this prohibition also covers the provision of information to the Parliamentary Committee in the course of exercising its duty to supervise the activities of the Authority, thus making the Committee virtually a `lame duck'.

These problems have been the subject of considerable discussion within the Committee and between the Committee and the Authority. In fact, the problem of Section 51 was first raised in the first Annual Report published by the National Crime Authority in 1986 and has made a regular reappearance since then.

It could be argued that in part the implementation of these provisions depends on the quality of the working relationship between the Parliamentary Committee and the Authority and that if there is a high level of trust one can expect that adequate information would be provided. However, clearly this is not a sound basis on which a relationship between two legal entities in this sensitive area can be based, and indeed there is evidence that at times such a level of trust was not present.

It is clear that a situation has now been reached where this impasse needs to be resolved, and while it has been argued that Parliamentary privilege would override the secrecy provision and that the Committee would be entitled to receive any information it sought from the National Crime Authority, the resolution of such a conflict would take considerable time, time which could be spent much more productively pursuing the substantive work of both the Authority and the Committee.

To ensure that the secrecy provisions of Section 51 do not apply to information sought by the Committee, Section 3 of my Bill declares that they do not apply to the Committee. In turn, this immediately raises the necessity to ensure that members of the Committee do not disclose either in their report to Parliament or otherwise information which could be prejudicial to the safety or legal rights of persons identified in that information, which prejudices legal proceedings whether or not those proceedings have commenced, or which would disclose the operational methods of the Authority in a manner prejudicial to the operations of the Authority. To cover these exceptions, the Bill provides that the Committee may not disclose such matters in a report to Parliament provided they have been taken as evidence in camera and provided the Authority has supplied a certificate to the Committee certifying that the information in question is covered by one or more of these exclusions. The Bill thus creates a situation of checks and balances which will enable the Committee to fulfil its obligation to supervise the Authority without jeopardising the work of the National Crime Authority.

To cover the possibility that either the majority of the Committee or the Authority oversteps the intended boundaries of these exceptions and either declares evidence to be in camera, when this would not be justified, or, in the case of the Authority, provides a certificate in accordance with a mistaken perception of the need for secrecy, the Bill provides what is in effect a right of appeal to a Justice of the Federal Court who would decide the matter on objective criteria and determine whether the information sought is in fact covered by one or more of the exceptions in the Bill.

The provisions contained in this Bill are the result of considerable consultation between members of the Committee and in particular, with Senator Crichton-Browne, who has previously moved an amendment to ensure that the Committee may obtain the information it requires. Earlier drafts of the amendments contained in the Bill have been submitted to the Attorney General, to Mr Justice Phillips, the Chairman of the Authority and to members of the Committee. Encouraging comments were received from Senator Michael Tate representing the Attorney-General, and from the Chairman of the Committee, Mr E J Lindsay MP. However, in the absence of a definitive response, I thought it would advance the debate and the resolution of the current impasse if I introduced the Private Senator's Bill now, thereby making it available for further discussion and public comment.

It is abundantly clear that the current evaluation of the purpose and performance of the National Crime Authority cannot be completed effectively unless the means are found to remove the shackles which currently prevent the Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority from carrying out its statutory duty ``to monitor and review the performance by the Authority of its functions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.
