DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for inquiry and report:

The management and operations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and whether that Department is fulfilling its role to protect and advance Australia's foreign policy interests, and that in particular the Committee examine the following:
(a) management systems and program evaluation procedures;
(b) alleged malpractice and financial irregularities;
(c) security procedures and custody of classified material;
(d) overseas conditions of service and their implications for efficiency and effectiveness;
(e) morale and discipline within the Department; and
(f) implications for Australia's international image of management and morale problems.
It is not intended that the motion be dealt with today, but I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement which briefly sets out the reasons for the reference.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Reasons for the Reference

In his introduction to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT)'s first Corporate Plan on 7 May 1990 the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, stressed the ``high priority'' the Hawke Government accorded foreign affairs and trade issues which he described as being ``fundamental to the nation's security and economic well being.''

The Minister further stated that, ``The Government looks to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to advise it and to implement its decisions within the portfolio in a professional and efficient manner.''

During much of 1990 the ability of the Department to fulfil this role has been called into question by a series of public allegations of financial irregularities and mismanagement, by at least 16 leaks of highly sensitive classified materials, and by damaging industrial disputes and work bans both in Canberra and at Australia's overseas missions.
The Senate cannot but be concerned at the implications of these serious allegations and leaks, and by the further indications of malaise and poor morale among officers of the Department.
MANAGEMENT AND OPERATIONS
1990 has been marked by serious allegations of ongoing and widespread maladministration and financial irregularities within the Department.

Allegations have been made of incompetence, rorts and ``cronyism'' across a range of administration areas, for example in the administration of tuition fees, boarding schools allowances, general education entitlements and travel allowance.

Allegations have also been made that senior officers of the Department have been involved, that their actions are carried out with impunity, and that ``cover ups'' are carried out to avoid detection. Further allegations have been made that systemic problems exist which prevent detection.
These allegations have been made to the media and to Members of Parliament by individual officers as well as a group within the Department calling itself the ``Officers Revolutionary Council.''
The Department has set up internal fraud reporting and detection systems, the effectiveness of which some officers have commented upon unfavourably.
An Auditor-General Report (No. 15 1990) tabled in the Senate on the 17th December 1990 found inter alia-
- That allegations of maladministration and impropriety within the Department were still being investigated by the AFP and the Department.
- That there was a large number of long outstanding debts.
- That procedures for handling disciplinary case were inadequate.
- The procedures for acquitting advances were inadequate.
- That cost effective fraud control arrangements were not yet fully in place.
LEAKS
Since July there has been a sequence of leaks of highly sensitive documents and cables originating in or which have been passed through the Department.

In all cases copies of the actual documents were in the possession of members of the media. Some of the documents bore SECRET and TOP SECRET security classifications. Two had the most sensitive ``AUSTEO'' (For Australian Eyes Only) classification.
All received wide coverage in the media.
6/7/90 The Australian

Confidential dispatch from a senior DFAT officer on leave without pay, Lyndall McLean. Ms Mclean who was working in Cambodia for aid organisations, wrote to the Minister urging the Hawke Government to recognise the Hun Sen regime.
23/7/90 Channel 7

Confidential and sensitive cable from the Australian High Commission in Sri Lanka reporting that Australian Defence Industries was tendering to supply 76 millimetre ammunition to the Sri Lankan Government.
26/7/90 The Australian

``SECRET'' cable from the Australian Embassy in Jakarta reporting the conversation between Indonesian Defence Minister General Benny Murdani and the Leader of the Federal Opposition, Dr Hewson, during Dr Hewson's visit to Indonesia.
26/7/90 The Australian
``SECRET'' cable from Canberra to the Australian Embassy in Jakarta recommending that Senator Evans give General Murdani a full briefing on Australia's policy on PNG.
26/7/90 The Australian

Other SECRET and CONFIDENTIAL cables were quoted revealing the Australian Government's concern that PNG had sought military training from Indonesia, that the PNG Government intended to send troops back to Bougainville if peace talks failed, and that some PNG defence advisers were in favour of establishing ``secure zones'' on Buka Island.
30/7/90 Sydney Morning Herald

Confidential DFAT cables were quoted by the Herald. They revealed that Australia had told the Political Counsellor of the US Embassy on 23 July that Australia planned to delay the release of its own assessment of the US plan to destroy chemical weapons on Johnston Atoll until the South Pacific Forum meeting as a tactical move, in order to minimise debate on the matter ahead of the Pacific island countries' hostility to the US plan.
2/9/90 Sunday Herald

``TOP SECRET'' DFAT report compiled from intelligence sources and classified materials to the Government revealed the Australian Government's assessment of continuing human rights abuses in China. This public revelation came on the eve of the Trade Negotiations Minister Dr Blewett's arrival in Beijing.
3/9/90 The Australian
The contents of an assessment by the Office of National Assessments carrying the highest intelligence classification: ``AUSTEO, SECRET AND CABINET IN CONFIDENCE'' was published.

It revealed ONA's assessments that nuclear weapons were likely to spread in the region through North Korea, Pakistan and India. It further revealed ONA's assessment that Iraq was 15 years away from developing a nuclear bomb, Taiwan was twice stopped by the United States from developing nuclear weapons capability, South Korea once had a nuclear weapons programme and Israel has nuclear bombs 10 times as powerful as the one dropped on Hiroshima.
4/9/90 The Australian

``CONFIDENTIAL'' internal DFAT assessments of the situation in Cambodia revealed, including the existence of a draft Memorandum of Understanding between Cambodia and Australia on the return of the boat refugees presently in Australia.
4/9/90 The Australian
A confidential high level assessment of DFAT of the Gulf Crisis was revealed in which DFAT warned that Australians could be the future victims of Iraqi-sponsored terrorist attacks.
5/9/90 Sydney Morning Herald
SMH reported that DFAT had concurred with two ONA assessments just before the Gulf Crisis that Saddam Hussein was merely engaging in sabre-rattling and was unlikely to invade Kuwait.

A letter from Prime Minister Hawke to Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney was obtained by 2GB in which Mr Hawke cited ``key domestic issues'' as his reason for not attending the World Summit for Children.
7/9/90 The Australian

A confidential letter from Senator Evans to Irish Foreign Minister Mr Gerry Collins was quoted at length. In the letter, Senator Evans revealed that he did not think there was sufficient international support to have Cambodia's seat at the UN declared vacant. Senator Evans also wrote in detail about his assessments of the strategies of ASEAN, China, the East European and other countries.
8-9/9/90 Weekend Australian
A Confidential assessment from the Australian Embassy in Hanoi to DFAT at the end of July, which painted a pessimistic picture of the situation in Cambodia following recent Khmer Rouge victories.
8-9/9/90 Weekend Australian
DFAT document giving the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)'s views on the problems posed by the large number of Cambodian refugees.
15-18/12/90 Weekend Australian and Australian

What appears to be practically the whole of the DFAT file in recent times on Cambodia including views of the US and British Governments and Record of Conversation with such as Prince Sihanouk and DFAT Deputy Secretary, Michael Costello.
MORALE AND DISCIPLINE

There have been suggestions that the leaks were aimed at drawing attention to serious management/staff problems within the Department. Some Departmental officers have also alleged that the leaks were being carried out because information/advice to the Minister and senior officers on problems in the Department were not being heard or acted upon.
These include allegations that under the Hawke Government, different standards are applied to senior staff and junior staff and staff in the Minister's favour.
If substantiated, there are serious implications for the ability of the Department to work effectively to promote and maintain Australia's international relations interests.

The serious industrial relations problems in the Department since June this year have not contributed to boosting staff morale. Members of the Public Sector Union occupying critical positions in Australia's overseas diplomatic and consular missions overseas took unprecedented industrial action in June over the Government's arbitrary decision to deduct a further 16% from officers' pay as contributions to rent and utilities costs.

Industrial action taken included bans on overtime work, delays in the processing of visas and passports, refusal to collect remitted revenue, and refusal to reply to correspondence from Ministers and Members of Parliament.
The PSU members were joined in their industrial action by other officers responsible for overseas missions communications, including all classified and unclassified materials.
The Senate would be concerned to note that communications between the Department and many overseas missions were entirely cut off in June this year, except where management performed those tasks.
Work bans have been again imposed in recent times with detrimental effects upon the capacity of overseas posts to function effectively.
EFFECT ON INTERNATIONAL IMAGE

Overseas missions presently face substantial additional difficulties as a result of cuts in funding for Locally Engaged Staff resulting in bans on overtime work, termination of services of many local employees and delays in the processing of passport, visa and other documentation.

Cables from Australian missions throughout the world in July/August pointed to the negative impact the problems were having on Australia's international image. A typical comment is such as that from the High Commission in Malaysia cabled on 1 August 1990.

``The proposition that the most significant mission of Kuala Lumpur, representing an aid donor country, host to a considerable number of civilian and services scholarships, cannot afford to pay its staff will be seen as ludicrous, embarrassing and simply unacceptable.''

The recent industrial disputes, problems with overseas living allowances, leaks of confidential documents and allegations of maladministration and impropriety have done damage to Australia's international image.

The vast majority of DFAT officers are competent and dedicated professionals. Service overseas in Australian interests involves family and social dislocation not well appreciated by the Australian community. Grievances of these officers require a more sensitive assessment than the Minister has been prepared to give.

The Minister and the Government having failed to properly address the issue, it is in the national interest and that of Departmental officers that the Parliament intervene and provide a forum for proper investigation and report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a replacement revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Bill 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting President, may I add my congratulations to you on the honour accorded to you today of taking the chair at the beginning of the sitting. It is very well deserved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Bill 1990 has as its purpose the conversion of the Superannuation Funds Investment Trust, commonly known as SFIT, from a statutory authority into an incorporated public company. It will also allow the Commonwealth Funds Management (CFM) to compete with private sector schemes for additional funds. It transfers SFIT's management and investment trustee functions in respect of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund to a joint employer-employee board of trustees.

These measures are intended to achieve greater efficiency and a better performance from the new Commonwealth Funds Management by putting it on a more commercial footing. The Opposition endorses this sentiment and direction, and it is for this reason that we are supporting this Bill before the Senate today.

We do, however, have a number of concerns at the Government's approach to these goals. It always seems to believe that the corporatisation path is the way to commercial reality and that nothing else needs to be done. In fact, that path is strewn with problems, unless the other matters and aspects that ought to go with corporatisation are fully thought through as well.
The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), when explaining the reasons for introducing this Bill, said:
To be able to compete successfully with the private sector for GBE funds, and attract new clients, SFIT needs to be allowed to operate as a truly commercial enterprise . . .

That is an admirable sentiment but the structure of the CFM is not consistent with this objective for various reasons. For example and most importantly, the CFM will have a statutory monopoly over the funds of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme (CSS) and the public sector superannuation scheme (PSS) until 1 July 1995. The Commonwealth superannuation scheme has of itself over $5.8 billion under management and is by far the largest, as I understand it, Australian superannuation scheme.

There are very real difficulties, I believe, in allowing the CFM to compete on a commercial basis with private sector firms if it maintains advantages from its association with the Commonwealth. In this respect I think it must be queried as to why the CFM will retain control of the substantial resources of the PSS and the CSS for five years. The control over these funds gives it an unfair advantage over private sector funds which do not have guaranteed control of substantial assets.

It would appear that the five-year term was decided, fairly arbitrarily, to ensure that there was not a mass exodus of funds from SFIT and to give the Government breathing space to consider its longer term position. This is a matter that was debated during the autumn session when the Superannuation Act 1990 was passed and I do not therefore propose to pursue it further other than to point out that the new CFM will have an unfair advantageous position over the next five years.

Another matter that I think is worth noting is the fact that the Government is also to provide the Commonwealth Funds Management with access to a $20m guarantee for working capital purposes which carries no penalty and is available again until the 30 June 1995. One would hope that that guarantee will not be required to be acted on but it does, nevertheless, give the fund a competitive advantage that is not available to other superannuation funds.

The question of board representation is also a matter to be noted with some concern. The Minister for Finance claimed in introducing the Bill in the other House that it will be important that the board members have suitable investment experience and business acumen. We would certainly agree with that sentiment. Yet the Bill gives the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) the right to appoint the employee representatives on the board and there appears from the Bill to be no provision whereby the other unions who control funds may be able themselves to appoint representatives. Perhaps Senator McMullan may wish to comment on that in any remarks he makes, but that certainly appears to be the case. Again, it puts the ACTU in a very powerful position, particularly in relation to other unions. Not even the Australian Public Sector and Broadcasting Union, whose members actually contribute to the fund, have a say and certainly not the industry's experts, but the Government's joint venture corporatist partners in the form of the ACTU.
On the question of board appointments, the Minister stated:

The proposed memorandum and articles of association will provide for the Minister responsible to have the power to appoint and dismiss the CFM board of directors. Also, the Minister responsible for CFM will be able to issue guidelines to the board.

That power of the Minister could well be interpreted as an implicit Government threat to the board to act in the Government's own policy interests or be sacked. That bears no reality, of course, to independence in the commercial world. More importantly, I believe it raises serious matters of propriety and fiduciary implications. There would have to be a question to ask as to whether that places the members of the board in a conflict of interest situation. Again, I think that is something that the coalition will certainly be monitoring very closely and something on which Senator McMullan may wish to comment.

It is intended that this new corporation be entirely owned by the Commonwealth Government and that its shares not be able to be transferred to anyone other than the Government or the Minister. That proposal, as I understand it, came in at the end of the debate on this matter, which was guillotined, in the House of Representatives. At that time, the Opposition spokesman in the House of Representatives had not been given any notice of it and he reserved the coalition's position on it.

We believe that the only way that the CFM can genuinely compete and operate in the private sector is if its management and ownership are also reflective of the private sector. We do not believe that the CFM should be owned in perpetuity by the Government. We are opposed to the Government's proposition which seeks to prohibit share transfer other than within the Government. Whilst we will not divide on it, I formally state the Opposition's opposition to that proposal.

In relation to a more general matter, the concerns that I have expressed are all the more serious given the huge sums of money involved. Superannuation savings that Australia will have amassed by the year 2000 are estimated to be something of the order of $600 billion. Much of that will be union controlled funds. These funds will, therefore, have the necessary resources to have an enormous impact on investment activity in Australia and the direction of that activity. The role of the CFM in this will be very important.

I think it is of great importance that the operations of superannuation funds, and in this case the CFM in particular, be directed in such a way as to maximise the efficient allocation of these huge resources so that we can advance our overall standards of living in this country. It is very important indeed that those funds not be directed into activities or particular areas for purely political reasons or reasons other than the most efficient use of that huge pool of savings.

The shift in the 1980s into superannuation is a welcome move. With the control of these enormous resources moving into the hands of unelected and unrepresentative officials, particularly of trade unions, unless there are very important and very carefully defined rules of operation of the funds, and unless steps are taken to ensure that there is no conflict of interest between getting the best return for shareholders or contributors to the funds and the use of funds for other purposes, we can look forward to very significant problems. I hope that will not arise but it is something that is exercising the minds certainly of the coalition and I think of many other people throughout the community.

Having made those comments, I conclude with putting on the record that we believe that the only solution to achieve the goal of the Minister or the Government and our stated goal of proper commercialisation of the CFM is to privatise it. The coalition has taken the decision to do just this when it returns to government. We have taken that decision in the last few weeks. The CFM has been added to the list of the previously announced government business enterprises that we will seek and take action to privatise when we come to government.

Corporatisation, which this Bill enables for the fund, should be seen, we believe, as just the first step on the road. To the Government, it would appear that corporatisation is the end of the road. That is a very clear distinction, I think, between the Government's approach to this whole matter of government business undertakings and the coalition's view. That is a debate for another occasion. It has already been discussed a great deal and will be discussed a great deal further in the future.

The idea that we can get maximum efficiency from business enterprises by continuing to have them owned 100 per cent in the public sector is a view which has been shown quite clearly in many other examples around the world to be not the way to go to get the greatest maximisation of the resources, use of the resources, of the nation, and the Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd fits into that category as well.

Having said those things, I repeat that the coalition does not oppose this Bill. We hope that the corporatisation of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and its conversion into Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd will act in the interests of the contributors because that, of course, is the basic objective of any superannuation fund.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate today is discussing the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Bill 1990. The Bill proposes to convert the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT)-which is the statutory body which is the trustee of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund-into a public company and, secondly, to transfer the trustee function of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund to a joint employer-employee board of trustees, to be known as Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No. 2. The trustee of the new Commonwealth superannuation scheme is, of course, known as the Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No. 1.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will formally split the functions of trustee and manager, which are currently both performed by SFIT. SFIT will retain the management function only and will be converted into a public company. The new company will be 100 per cent Commonwealth owned initially. The Government did move an anti-privatisation amendment in the House of Representatives. However, it is defective because it does not cover the issue of new shares. I shall be moving an amendment to fix this loophole later in the committee stage. Given that the Government agrees that there is no problem, we hope that it will see its way clear to support this amendment.

I sought an interview with the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) during the last week but it proved impossible because of his busy schedule. The amendment I shall be moving is very clear-cut and simple. It simply says that no shares may be held in the company by a person other than the Commonwealth, a body corporate established for a public purpose by a law of the Commonwealth or a Minister.

In discussions with ministerial and departmental staff, an alternative was offered because it was stated that the objective of our amendment is indeed shared by the Government. The alternative that was offered was an undertaking by the Minister to amend or to undertake to insert in the memorandum and articles of association of a company a condition which says that shares may not be issued unless this is authorised by the two Houses of parliament.

I believe this is a very cumbersome, circumlocutory and legally somewhat doubtful proposition. It could well come adrift on the way. I do not frankly like the concept of making the action of a public company dependent on an event outside, be that the decision of two Houses of Parliament. I believe that the amendment that I will be moving is clear-cut and simple and I would hope that the Minister has had the opportunity to consider it in detail and that he will see his way clear to support it. As I said, if the objectives are indeed aligned then it is a very clear-cut way to achieve that.

The Opposition also announced, on 13 November 1990, that it had decided to privatise Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd (CFM) when it gets into government. This was today confirmed by Senator Short in his address. We believe that this is a wrong move. At the very least, the Opposition should consider consulting the hundreds of thousands of superannuation fund members whose money is to be invested by CFM. Given the recent history of dubious business practices and bad investment decisions made by the private sector, why should the fund members not be asked whether they want their funds managed by a private or a public sector entity? The Australian Democrats do not subscribe to the furphy that is being put around that public management of necessity must be bad and that private management of necessity must be good. I would submit to honourable senators that it is indeed a question of management rather than ownership-but, in this case, management goes with ownership.

Apart from this, there is also the question of fiscal prudence by the Commonwealth Government. The public sector superannuation schemes are defined benefit schemes. The Commonwealth Government pays the difference between CFM's returns on Commonwealth contributions and the obligated benefits. Thus, it is in the Commonwealth's interests to maintain control to maximise returns-especially long term returns-to minimise the Commonwealth's costs.

Another reason to maintain public control is to promote responsible investment by superannuation funds. Senator Button is proud, and rightly so, of the recent initiative he and the Government managed to persuade some large institutions to create. The Develop Australia Fund is a step in the right direction in terms of guiding just a small proportion of our superannuation moneys into profitable but necessarily long term investment. The decision to corporatise SFIT is in direct contrast to the initially announced Government position in Reform of Commonwealth Superannuation, released by Senator Walsh on 15 October 1989. This document stated at attachment E5 that SFIT will continue to be constituted as a statutory authority. There has been no official explanation of the corporatisation decision. The trustee in funds management function could have been separated without adopting a corporate structure. The right to compete with private sector funds managers could have been granted to SFIT without a corporate structure. Perhaps the Minister could explain this to the Senate. Indeed, during the last five years SFIT has achieved above market average rates of return-and this with a portfolio approaching $6 billion. If it is not broken, why fix it?

CFM will continue to be the sole investment manager of the two Commonwealth superannuation schemes, but only until 30 June, 1995. The shield of the crown immunity will not be available to CFM Ltd. However, the Commonwealth will guarantee the first $20m of money initially borrowed by the company, which is defined as borrowings prior to 30 June, 1995. The usual continuity of employment provisions are contained within the Bill and the Australian Democrats welcome that.

At least with this Bill the Government has not repeated the disgrace of the last corporatisation-that of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories-although there is still obviously a contingent privatisation here. We believe that the Commonwealth Government is to be commended on its statement that it wishes to retain Commonwealth control and ownership of this fund, and I look forward to the Government's support for my amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank both parties for their support of the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Bill. Firstly, I will deal with some of the issues raised by the Opposition. Then I will refer to Senator Spindler's amendment because we will not have time to deal with it in a normal committee stage discussion. I will be very brief in dealing with the privatisation issue, although I regard it as very important not only in my capacity here representing the Minister for Finance, but also because I, with my colleague Senator Reid, have the honour of representing more public servants, more members of this scheme, than anybody else.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard it as a very important part of my representative responsibility to those people also to say that I and the Government are totally opposed to the idea of the privatisation of Commonwealth Funds Management Limited (CFM). I believe that the interests of the people who have contributed, and the interests of the Commonwealth as the employer of those people which has made contributions on their behalf and has obligations to them, including obligations under a defined benefit scheme, would not be preserved in the manner that I would find acceptable by a consideration of privatisation. It is a debate we will have subsequently as a matter of substance when the Liberals proceed to further debate on it or at a time of the Government's choosing. Today is only a time to say that I am totally opposed to that point. I believe that it is ideology getting in the way of logic.

Senator Short also raised the question of the short term monopoly for CFM until 30 June 1995. The first thing to remember is that some part of that is absolutely essential because until 30 June 1991 we have the intertwining of the two major Commonwealth schemes as they evolve. It is very difficult at the moment-if not, I suspect, impossible-to say what is the exact size of each of the two schemes. So until 30 June 1991 we cannot disentangle the two. Then I think an appropriate transition period is relevant and necessary, but I do support the view that there should be a time limit to that period. Four years seems a reasonable one and it certainly will put a lot of pressure on CFM to perform. That limited appointment will keep its eye on the game because it will know that at the end of four years the trustees will have to look at whether CFM should continue to be the funds manager. It obviously would be terribly important to it in a corporate sense, but also a key element in its capacity to persuade other people that it should be the funds manger would be undermined significantly. Were it to lose its principal client it would clearly be undermined in its competition, so it would be a spur to it to perform very successfully.

Another issue of importance that has been raised relates to the Commonwealth guarantee of initial borrowings, but the Senate needs to be aware that any commercial enterprise, CFM or otherwise, will require working capital to enable it to meet day to day expenses, whereas fixed working capital is currently derived solely from the superannuation fund against which it charges all of its expenses. The only assets it has are the assets it has as trustee. It does not have assets as manager. If those two functions are distinguished, then CFM has no assets as such or-to put it another way-the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) has no assets in its own right which it can transfer to CFM. So it would be without working capital and perhaps without the capacity to secure a loan for such purposes. There is a limited guarantee both in terms of the amount of money and the time over which it will operate. It will apply only to amounts borrowed prior to 30 June 1995. I do not think anybody would be concerned in terms of protecting taxpayer interests about the capacity of CFM to meet that loan, so it is simply a mechanism to facilitate it achieving loans that it might not otherwise be able to get.

The other issue that Senator Short raised was the question of union participation. It seems to me that there is some con- fusion here. CFM's board of directors is quite separate from the board of trustees which is responsible for administering the Commonwealth schemes. CFM's board will be provided for in the memorandum and articles of association, and it is important that those board members have investment experience and business acumen. The existing members of SFIT will be eligible for appointment to the board. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, it is true, will be making nominations to the boards of trustees administering the Commonwealth schemes. In the past these have been employees of the Commonwealth and its authorities.

Those are the essential points of Senator Short's to which I wish to respond in the time available, although there are other matters, he said, that might have in other times warranted further debate. We could both claim that there are other things we could all have said in debates, but I think that goes to the essence of it.

I will take this opportunity to respond briefly to Senator Spindler so that we can then dispatch the Bill. The Government will not be accepting the amendment to be moved by the Democrats. As Senator Spindler said, we already have a clause prohibiting transfer of Commonwealth shareholding to persons outside the company. It is true, and accepted, that by itself it does not prevent the company from creating new share capital which could be issued to persons outside the Commonwealth and, therefore, undermining the purpose of the clause. We share the objective, but I reiterate to the Senate the Minister's assurance that the matter of a new share capital will be addressed by the inclusion of a specific restriction on new share issues in both the memorandum and the articles of the company.

I have sought and received assurance that this restriction can and will be framed in such a way as to necessitate the amendment of the legislation to authorise new share issues to non-Commonwealth interests. The Companies Act and the Corporations Act do enable such entrenchment provisions and we will be taking advantage of those entrenchment provisions. Therefore, the privatisation of CFM would not be possible without amendment to the legislation by the Parliament. The protection that Senator Spindler seeks and which my Party seeks will be provided adequately through this mechanism and, therefore, the amendment, although its purpose is understood, is unnecessary and we will not be supporting it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 47, page 18, lines 9 to 15, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
``Shares of Company to be retained by Commonwealth
47. No shares may be held in the company by a person other than:
(a) the Commonwealth; or
(b) a body corporate established for a public purpose by a law of the Commonwealth; or
(c) a Minister.''.

This amendment seeks to prevent the holding of shares in the company by persons other that the Commonwealth, the body corporate established for a public purpose by law of the Commonwealth or a Minister. The Australian Democrats believe that the assurance given by the Minister as to proposed incorporation of certain conditions in the memorandum of articles in association is not adequate, and the Australian Democrats press this amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment moved by Senator Spindler to the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Bill 1990 be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for consideration of the Bill having expired, I put the question that the Bill be reported without amendment.

INTERJECT.PARA: Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to and the Bill be now passed.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION (SALE OF ASSETS AND ABOLITION) BILL 1990COMMONWEALTH AND STATE HOUSING AGREEMENT (SERVICE PERSONNEL) BILL 1990DEFENCE FORCE (HOME LOANS ASSISTANCE) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 and 15 November, on motions by Senator Tate and Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating now a package of three Bills, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1990, the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement (Service Personnel) Bill 1990 and the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Bill 1990. I will address my remarks only to the first of those three, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation Bill. My colleague Senator Newman will be addressing her remarks to the remaining two Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1990 provides for the sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (HLIC) business; the transfer of goodwill and physical assets, plant and equipment, to the purchaser, CIC Insurance Group; and the abolition of the Corporation itself after the sale.

The CIC Insurance Group is Australia's fifth largest general insurer. It is owned jointly by the Norwich Insurance Company of the United Kingdom and the Winterthur Swiss Insurance Company, with a minority equity holding by the Chiyoda Insurance Company of Japan. Those three companies carry an AAA claims paying ability from the Standard and Poor's rating group. The Bill also includes details of the continued government guarantee of all existing insurance policy holder obligations and relevant employment arrangements for the staff of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

The HLIC was established by the Liberal-National Party Government in 1965 to make home ownership possible for more Australians, particularly low income earners. That is something that this Government, through its cripplingly high interest rate policies, has done a great deal to destroy in recent years. The HLIC annual report, tabled in this Parliament last week, stated:
With interest rates at record high levels for the whole of the financial year-
that was the year to 30 June 1990-

. . . and the threat of unemployment growing, the demand for home ownership loans fell to the lowest level for many years. The new home buyer found the deposit gap difficult to breach and the affordability problem almost insurmountable.
I do not think one could find a more damning indictment of the impact of the Government's policies on housing than that quote from the Government's own housing corporation.

The HLIC has been very successful in achieving its goals. Last year it posted a record profit and was the largest mortgage insurer in Australia. I take this opportunity to congratulate the staff and management of HLIC over the past 25 years. They are to be congratulated for their achievements. I trust they will continue their good work in the private sector, as is about to occur.

The Opposition has long supported the privatisation of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. For this reason, we support the Bill. It has been a long road to the privatisation of the HLIC. The Fraser Government started the process back in 1979 and it has taken a long time to come to fruition.

The major component of the income from the sale of the HLIC will arise from the realisation of the investments the Corporation holds in its books. These investments will be transferred to the Government as part of the residual assets and liabilities when the HLIC is wound up. According to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) when introducing this Bill, more than $100m is expected to be credited to Consolidated Revenue in the current financial year from the sale of HLIC and the disposal of the residual assets. However, he said in his second reading speech:
The overall return to the Commonwealth from the sale and the associated abolition of the HLIC is estimated to be around $80m in net present value terms . . .

As I understand it, the difference between the current $100m and the $80m net present value arises from the Government's commitments to meet over time the policies entered into by the HLIC before the date of sale, and also to pay for the ongoing administration costs of those policies. Provisions for both of these obligations are expressly contained in the Bill.

This Government first announced the proposed sale of the HLIC in its August 1989 Budget. It has subsequently been reported that all six of the originally interested parties dropped out because they would not pay the $50m to $60m the Government was said to be seeking at that time.

Given that the investments of the Corporation are valued at cost at $114m and the Minister said that the Commonwealth will receive more than $100m after the transaction is complete, it raises the question of how much, if anything, CIC is actually paying for the goodwill of the Corporation. Perhaps the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in summing up the debate on this subject, can enlighten us on this because some confusion has certainly been evident in the press and, indeed, in Government ranks, particularly in publicised correspondence from Mr Langmore, the honourable member for Fraser, to the Minister. There is some confusion which I think needs clearing up.

The fact that apparently no-one thought the HLIC was worth $50m to $60m as an intact body last year must certainly raise some doubt as to the current net value being around $80m. As the potential liability on policy obligations has risen in the past 12 months due to the major downturn in the economy and subsequent increases in mortgage defaults, the value of the HLIC would have been expected to have fallen, not risen, in the last six to 12 months.
My colleague in the lower House the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) made the following comment on this Bill during the debate in that place:
It is understood that the level of claims against the HLIC is rising, particularly in Victoria.
This was subsequently substantiated in the HLIC annual report which said, inter alia:
Defaults in Victoria increased by 29 per cent during the year-
that is, during 1989-90:
. . . and it is this State that is certain to cause the Corporation the greatest concern in the future.

The annual report contained other interesting comments as well which, as I said earlier, amount to a very strong indictment indeed of the Government's economic policies. At page 8 the annual report says:

A disturbing trend emerged during the year which indicated that around 52% of all claims paid during the year came from loans written in 1987-88 and 1988-89, with 28% coming from loans written in 1988-89. These figures indicate that many marginal borrowers who either purchased homes when interest rates were low or purchased homes at the top of the boom are finding great difficulty in meeting repayments.
Given the restrictions on time, I will conclude with the following quote:
. . . the affordability problem and the general lack of confidence in the future is preventing many families making the decision to purchase their first home.

This is a matter on which the Opposition has been pressing the Government for many months-that is, the devastating effect on the home market, particularly for new home buyers, young families and single income families. The prospect of buying their own home and being able to meet the interest payments and commitments has put housing out of the reach of huge numbers of young, and not so young, couples in Australia. It is a great indictment of the Government that its economic policies have had this devastating effect on home buyers, particularly on young families, in this country.

Despite repeated requests, the Minister has refused to make available actuarial advice he received earlier this year on the question of future potential obligations of the HLIC. I hope that the Minister, in his response to this debate, will be able to comment on that and, in particular, provide some of that information. I believe it is something on which the Parliament ought to be advised.

More information on the details of the sale, and exactly how much of the funds the Government is actually going to receive from CIC, the purchaser of HLIC, I believe, also should be made public. I hope that the Minister will be able to be more forthcoming than his Government has been to date. I repeat that the coalition supports this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now cognately debating three Bills. The first is the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1990, which the Australian Democrats oppose. This is a privatisation Bill and, from our fundamental position, we are opposed to it. Senator Spindler will speak to this Bill very briefly. The Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement (Service Personnel) Bill 1990 and the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Bill 1990 must certainly be welcomed by those in the defence forces and they are welcomed by the Australian Democrats, who will be supporting them.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators are probably aware that my family had a defence life for about 20 years. I assure the Senate that one of the most burning questions associated with being in the Services in this country is housing. The Government is to be congratulated on taking a step in 1988 which has proven to be extremely successful, that is, the establishment of the Defence Housing Authority. As a member of the defence subcommittee one travels around visiting defence establishments and speaking to personnel in the Services, and there is no doubt at all that the establishment of that Authority was a major, very positive step. The two Bills which I am addressing now-those relating to service housing-are a continuation of that very positive development.

There is no doubt that for a number of years it was extremely difficult for service personnel to purchase homes, not only because of their mobility but also because of a number of factors which virtually made it impossible for them to be home owners in this country. Senator Short has quite correctly stated that most young Australian couples these days are finding this difficulty. This has been compounded for anybody in the Services over many years, and it is good to see legislation which is quite clearly and very effectively directed towards resolving those problems.

The Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Bill is one which I believe quite generously and realistically provides a support mechanism to those in the Services which will now enable them to make a decision to purchase a home and to no longer be disadvantaged. Not only is this important for those who are actually the members of the Services themselves but also especially for their families. It is a life of turbulence and frequent posting, and one of the things that one has sacrificed is the family home in the sense of identifying with it as one's own, and everything that goes with that in the sense of family.

I congratulate the Government on bringing down these Bills, and on formulating and structuring them in the way that it has done. This Bill provides generously for anybody who makes a positive decision to be a home buyer and a service person at the same time.

The Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement (Service Personnel) Bill 1990 simply acknowledges the fact that there is a lot of adjustment flowing from the establishment of the Defence Housing Authority in 1988, and the impact upon that of the ownership and relative responsibilities of State and Federal governments. This Bill simply adjusts, by agreement between the States and the Commonwealth, to accommodate for the impact of the establishment of the Defence Housing Authority in 1988.

The Democrats support these two Bills. We commend them to the Senate and we welcome the fact that they provide service people with the opportunity to become home owners at favourable rates because the assistance Bill provides subsidy and opportunity for service people to elect between two positive options. I am quite sure that people in the Services now no longer need to see themselves disadvantaged in terms of opportunity for home ownership, and the Government is to be congratulated for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are currently debating the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Bill 1990 and the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement (Service Personnel) Bill 1990, and I wish to speak to both of those Bills this morning. It is a measure of the Government's interest in the welfare of defence personnel, as a result of the gag by the Government and the Australian Democrats, that I as the Opposition spokesmen have been given only 10 minutes to speak on the important issue of defence housing. Both these Bills put in place very necessary defence housing reforms. One Bill brings in a new subsidised loan scheme for serving defence members which will assist them in purchasing their own homes. The other Bill brings in new arrangements for the ownership, upgrading, repair and maintenance of defence houses formerly owned by the States under the Commonwealth and State housing agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: It is because of the lack of time that I will speak only briefly to the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement (Service Personnel) Bill as the Opposition welcomes its passage. Agreement has been reached with all States except South Australia to renegotiate this agreement. Under this agreement 7,000 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement houses will be returned to the States over the next five years for use as public housing. The remaining 7,000 houses will be transferred to the Defence Housing Authority, which will have the right to sell or upgrade the houses, and the responsibility for repair and maintenance which in the past was not readily forthcoming from the State authorities.

The Defence Housing Authority record on speedy repair and maintenance is already recognised as being a very good one, and I hope that the Defence Housing Authority continues to put the needs and wants of defence personnel above all else. It is important that, in its purchasing of Defence Force homes, the homes are located where there are good public transport and community facilities.

I now turn to the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Bill. This Bill gives effect to the introduction of a new scheme providing home loan subsidies for members of the Defence Force who enlisted after 14 May 1985. On 17 August this year the Government announced that the National Australia Bank Ltd had won the tender to run a new defence service home loan scheme. The 72-year-old defence service home scheme, which currently provides a $25,000 loan at 6.85 per cent over 25 years, was sold to the Westpac Banking Corporation in 1989 and will continue to run alongside the new scheme. Essentially the new scheme gives eligible members access to a portable subsidised housing loan of up to $40,000 with an interest subsidy to the member of 40 per cent of the monthly average of the interest payable over a 25 year term.

Pre-1985 enlistees will also be eligible for the new loan scheme if they have not already taken a defence service home loan. To do this they must formally relinquish that previous entitlement. This Bill will make amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act to facilitate this. This Bill provides for payment of a housing loan subsidy to the National Australia Bank which is to be paid into the loan account of the subsidised borrower.

This Bill includes, as a schedule, an agreement entered into between the Commonwealth and the National Australia Bank, giving the bank the exclusive right to participate as lender under the scheme. How will it operate? The National Australia Bank will pay the Commonwealth a franchise premium of $42m on 15 May 1991. The bank will then pay to the Commonwealth a commission payment each year, the amount of which will be based on the number of subsidy commencements which have occurred in the previous year.

The Department of Defence will be responsible for meeting the ongoing monthly subsidy payments payable to the National Bank and for the administrative costs associated with the promotion of the scheme. The Department will also be responsible for assessing applications for entitlement certificates and other approvals and payment of subsidy. The Department of Defence will be subject to fringe benefits tax in relation to the subsidy. The interest rate for the subsidised loan will be the lower of the average of the housing loan interest rates of the five largest home loan lenders or the National Australia Bank home loan interest rate, and the member will pay the remaining 60 per cent.

One welcome initiative is that two members who are married can add their loans together and take an $80,000 loan. This is not possible in the old scheme, meaning that a service couple are not able to both take their entitled loan for the same home. This is a ridiculous and unfair situation and it is about time the Government rectified this anomaly in the old scheme.

We also particularly welcome the fact that the provision for loan portability will allow a top-up back to $40,000 each time the loan is transferred. In the old scheme, the amount that can be transferred decreases with each transfer. Even a $40,000 loan does not adequately reflect current market values. It has to be recognised that people will need to be taking a second mortgage if they want to buy a house.

The report on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force, known as the Cross report, recommended that any new defence home loan should be indexed to keep in line with market values. The Government has decided not to index the $40,000. Inevitably, this will lead to a devaluation of the loan as has occurred so badly with the old scheme, and the Government should be condemned for failing to take up the Cross report recommendation. I only hope that it is not 18 years before indexation is introduced, as was the case with the defence orphans pension until recently.

It is claimed that the new scheme will act as a retention measure, providing an incentive for members to stay longer in the service because the subsidy is payable for a period which is directly related to a member's years of service. The attempt at encouraging retention of personnel by restricting payment of the interest subsidy to a period equal to a member's years of service beyond six years means that a serviceman leaving after 10 years is eligible for only four years at a subsidised rate. This is a considerable reduction of the 25 years subsidy for the earlier scheme, and one might say yet another erosion of the conditions of service of defence personnel. What presents at first sight as a considerable improvement on the old scheme has substantial warts, and this is one of them.

The scheme does not provide ade- quately for reservists, either those who come in for a year or two on full time duty or those who serve for a short period on operational service, such as the Gulf forces. For example, regulars and reservists who have had less than six months effective full time service prior to going to the Gulf will not be eligible, nor will a sailor if he is injured and has to leave the Navy with less than one year's service after return from the Gulf. In addition, this loan will not be available to the vast majority of reservists, who rarely serve on full time duty in the integrated force for the necessary six years qualifying period.

It is not only reservists on full time duty or reservists at war who are forgotten in this scheme. It seems that some regulars will be disadvantaged too. Members who have purchased a house or started to build a home after receiving assurances from the Services that they will have a second posting in the same location, and then get posted away before the house is completed and a subsidy commenced should be eligible for subsidy. They will not be.

Our most serious concern, however, relates to something much more basic and disturbing. This Bill effectively removes the defence home loan as compensation for war service. No longer does war service entitle one to such a loan. The only benefit that those who serve in war will receive is a waiving of the six-year accrual time. The Minister has told me, `The legislation was not designed with operational service in mind. In the past, it had been a matter for the Government of the day to decide on the specific conditions that should apply to a particular instance of operational service, and in my view we ought to retain this flexibility by avoiding rigid legislative provisions'. What rot.

Right back in 1918 this Parliament passed the War Service Homes Act, which has operated down the years to recognise Australian servicemen's war service by way of home loan assistance. That Act became the Defence Services Homes Act in 1973 and will now apply only to those who enlisted prior to May 1985. Yet the purpose of the loan has always been to provide returned soldiers with the best and cheapest housing possible. In general, eligibility was confined to persons who had embarked for active service outside Australia, their widows and certain widowed mothers, but in 1920 it was extended to include persons who had enlisted for active service outside Australia even though they did not leave Australia.

The Minister has told me that a sailor injured in the Gulf deployment and discharged from the Navy with less than one year's service would not be eligible for the subsidised loan. A sailor who joins the Navy, does six months training and is injured on the first day on a ship in the Gulf will get no war service loan. The Government has abolished this historical commitment knowingly and with its eyes open. I find that totally unacceptable, and indeed dishonourable. Even now as we speak in this chamber the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) are all at the docks in Sydney greeting the men whose war service loans they have just snitched. Some welcome!

This Bill is not opposed by the Opposition, but we condemn the Government in the strongest possible terms for removing the entitlement to a war service loan for our service men and women. The Minister claims that this scheme is needed as a retention measure, and we support such measures, but it is no excuse for turning home loan assistance on its head and thereby abolishing an entitlement which our service men and women have had since 1918. The Government must take urgent action to restore war service loans for our young people who serve their country in war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall confine my remarks to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Bill. In contrast to the other Bills in this cognate package, which the Australian Democrats support, I find that the best way to characterise this particular Bill is that it is a disgrace. It is destroying a small but extremely successful and useful public enterprise. There is absolutely no justification in our view for the decision to abolish the Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Corporation was established 25 years ago by the Menzies Government. Since that time it has repaid the initial capital to the Commonwealth and currently has assets of around $120m. The Corporation insures lenders, that is banks, against losses on loans secured by mortgage, both residential and non-residential. Since 1985, the Corporation has been allowed to insure approved dealers in the secondary mortgage market, and since 1987 has been allowed to enter into certain reinsurance contracts. The Corporation is guaranteed by the Commonwealth but is self-financing. It pays all Federal and State taxes and has paid over $44m in dividends and special payments during its lifetime. With a market share of some 55 per cent, the Corporation is the dominant mortgage insurer in Australia and consequently has considerable market power.

For this reason alone, the Corporation should be kept in public ownership to maintain a genuinely competitive market. In the past, the Corporation has thrice resisted attempted price increases in the industry which would have occurred if the Corporation had not been a public body looking after the interests of home buyers. That is the really appalling thing-that mortgage insurance is most necessary for so-called marginal borrowers. Obviously, these are people who must struggle to get their homes-the so-called battlers. Indeed, the Corporation was established to assist those people who are not regarded as good risks by financial institutions. Perhaps they are prone to lose employment or have a physical problem which may affect their income earning potential, or more likely they are simply low income earners without much prospect of increasing their incomes. There is absolutely no doubt that the price that these battlers will face for their mortgage insurance will rise. Yet the Minister effortlessly predicts, `With its strong international backing, the CIC Insurance Group is expected to provide effective competition to the other existing private mortgage insurers, thereby helping to ensure that premiums are kept low'. But who has an interest in keeping premiums low? Future home owners will pay for this decision, and the Government knows it.

However, it is not only home owners but also taxpayers who will lose. In the usual fashion, we have been given virtually no information regarding the details of the sale. No figure other than `an expected net present value of $80m' has been announced by the Government. The full financial detail which the Government is providing to Parliament to make this major decision is, `Well, we expect to get about $80m'. There is no mention of the sale price, of estimated future claims, or of the discounting factor used to arrive at the present value figures.

The Corporation has just announced its results for the last financial year. The gross operating profit was a record result of over $15m. Why is the Government abolishing this institution? Who are the purchasers of the Corporation? They are foreign insurance companies. So the business of a dominant market player which affects low income families in Australia has not only been privatised but also sold to foreign interests. We used to hear a lot about the Government's commitment to industrial democracy, to worker participation and ownership and moving towards a genuine partnership between staff and management. What has occurred in this area in the case of the Corporation? The Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Crean) stated in his second reading speech:
Equitable treatment of the present employees and their continued welfare has been a major consideration for the Government in developing the staffing arrangements associated with the sale.

What a joke. We have received correspondence in my office from Corporation employees who for months have been worried about the future. At least, if the Corporation itself were privatised, the Government could have guaranteed continuity of employment, but the Corporation is being abolished. The Minister assures the Corporation staff:
The great majority of the present HLIC staff and management will be able to continue their careers in mortgage insurance on terms as good as or better than at present.

In plain English that means some of the staff will be sacked, with no voluntary redundancy packages, which is the usual practice in these circumstances. They will simply receive redundancy pay and bleak prospects given the current job market. Furthermore, those who do not want to work for the new owner will just be sacked and no redundancy will be paid. The Corporation is a successful business and its employees deserve a better go than that proposed by the Government and gleefully accepted by the Opposition.

The tragic thing about the direction which Cabinet has taken, against the wishes of the great majority of its members, is that it legitimises the position of the Opposition on the question of privatisation. There is now absolutely no difference between the old parties on every major issue. The Australian Democrats totally reject the Bill and will vote against it on the second reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler began his contribution by telling us that in 1985 the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (HLIC) was able to extend its activities into insuring dealers in the secondary mortgage market. The point is that when the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation began during the Menzies era there was no secondary mortgage market. Indeed, the whole idea of mortgage insurance was only in its fledgling stages. It was necessary for the government of the day to make a decision to set up a government corporation to enter the field and to pioneer efforts in it. There is no question that the HLIC was successful in doing so. It meant that during that quarter of a century many low income earners were able to get themselves housing loans from banks that they may not have been able to get otherwise. That was a legitimate purpose-a government corporation set up by a conservative government-and one that we would all support.

SPEECH.PARA: But in looking at the size of government and in looking at what is appropriate for governments to run and not to run, one would have to say that in the 1990s the mortgage insurance industry is now well-established. There are many players in the game. There is now a market for those dealing in secondary mortgages and the reality is that the Government does not need to pioneer anything in this area.

In making the decision we have made, we ensure a return to the taxpayer. Senator Spindler said that in plain English this means that some will get sacked. In plain English it means exactly what the Minister said-the great majority of staff will be retained on as good as or better conditions. That is what it means. That is the kind of guarantee that most employees in Australia would love to have. If one could give a guarantee to every firm in Australia at the moment that the great majority of its employees-no matter which industry they are in-would be retained on as good or better conditions, I think the applause around Australia would be deafening. I do not believe that the staff are being disadvantaged. It has been a prime concern of the Government.

As one sits around the Budget Cabinet discussions and looks at where governments can prune and where governments can save, here we have managed to keep a government enterprise going. Senator Spindler said that it is being destroyed; far from it. It goes into the hands of the private sector where, if anything, its opportunities to grow will be greater. Any idea that it is being destroyed is just not true. There is not a skerrick of evidence to suggest that that is the case.

The Australian Democrats act in this manner out of prejudice and not out of intellect, which is unusual because usually they do try. The Democrats need to break the cycle and not say that they are opposed to any suggestion ever of the Government moving out of any enterprise. Any thought, by the way, that the Government is going to run mortgage insurance better in this day and age than the private sector is, to my mind, a nonsense.

I have been given some answers to comments by Senator Short. He referred to the likely return to be derived from the sale of certain of the HLIC's business assets and the vesting of its residual assets and liabilities in the Commonwealth. It remains our position that the Government expects to obtain more than $100m in the current financial year from this process. I think that was the original estimate; so there is no change at this stage from what we would expect. As Senator Short indicated, the bulk of those funds will be obtained from the realisation of the Corporation's investments after its abolition.

As indicated by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) in his press release of 30 October, the overall return is expected to be around $80m in net present value terms after allowing for claims on existing policies of mortgage insurance which will have to be met by the Commonwealth in future years. The estimate of the number of claims to be made in future years is considered to be realistic and the Government sees no reason to change its estimate of the overall return in the sale process.

The other thing that Senator Short mentioned was the actuarial advice. While I do not have a note on that before me, my recollection is that the Minister said at the time that that was confidential, commercial in-confidence type information and was not to be released. I understand there is no change to that position. So, the Government will not be releasing it.

I now turn to the other two pieces of legislation which affect the defence forces. As Senator McLean correctly pointed out, over the years one of the great problems has been that service life has tended to discourage home ownership. With this new scheme we seek to reverse that trend and encourage home ownership by service personnel. This new legislation establishes a form of home loan subsidy for members of the Australian Defence Force and approves an agreement with the National Australia Bank Ltd for that subsidy-where the Commonwealth will pay the National Australia Bank a subsidy of 40 per cent of the average interest bill over the life of the loan, and the National Australia Bank will make available loans up to $40,000. The National Australia Bank will pay the Commonwealth $42m on 15 May next year and an annual commission based on the number of clients.

I understand that Senator Newman has written to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) about the problem that she sees with reservists. The first point the Government would make is that this was a scheme which was primarily established to make sure that full time service personnel were helped. They were always the priority from the concept of the scheme coming into being. The subsidy is based on the number of years of service after an initial six years of full time service; unless, of course, there has been a posting to the Gulf when the six years will be waived.

`Reservists who are posted to the Gulf are less likely to gain loans because they will not have much full time service necessary to build up that subsidy entitlement', is the kind of claim that Senator Newman makes. If one has a scheme which is a retention measure for full time defence personnel, one wonders what else one would expect. It is about increasing permanent numbers in the Defence Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is something else.

—It is not. There has been criticism of the loss of war service home loans. The Defence Service Homes Act provides only for specific benefits for specific operational areas. That has always been the case. There is no commitment now, nor has there been any in the past, to provide loans for service in any future war zone. That has simply not been the case ever before-not when the honourable senator's predecessors or my predecessors ran the show.
—All our servicemen on active service have had an entitlement to war service loans since 1918. You have abolished it.

—We cannot abolish something that did not exist. In any event, there are far better benefits, such as tax free salaries and allowances for operational service, for persons who are posted to war-like areas. For example, those deployed in the Gulf have a daily amount paid to them. Maximum subsidised loans-$25,000 in the old scheme and $40,000 in this scheme-are not indexed. The new scheme provides for an evaluation of the scheme in a three to five-year cycle, including the incentive effect of the loan.

SPEECH.PARA: The benefits under the old scheme have risen dramatically. Since the limit was set in 1982, market interest rates have risen, whilst the rate paid by borrowers has remained the same. In short, this new scheme is a vast improvement on the old one and I am sure it will achieve its aim of keeping full time defence personnel in the forces.
