SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition basically supports the thrust of these amendments to the Australian Heritage Commission Amendment Bill 1990, which provide for advance notice for owners of land subject to a notice of intention to include the place in the National Estate, make minor amendments to the procedures for inclusion or removal from the register of the National Estate and to alter the basis for grants for National Estate projects. These were basically announced on 18 November 1988. It has taken the Government until now to get them to this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: However, as the thrust of the legislation is to improve the status and effectiveness of the Australian Heritage Commission, the Opposition, while agreeing with that thrust, nonetheless feels that the Government has not done a good enough job. It is vital to increase the status and standing in the public's eye of the Australian Heritage Commission and what it does. Of course, its task is of major importance and has had, and continues to have, the support of the coalition.

The Heritage Commission has played a significant role in the preservation of the National Estate since 1975, despite the fact that some of its actions have generated controversy and criticism. There have been complaints, particularly from sections of the rural sector, that the Heritage Commission has been used-or one might say misused-by pressure groups. But much of this criticism and complaint emerges basically from misunderstandings of the role of the Commission, which is basically advisory, or the misuse of the Commission's advice basically by those people who at times can put an added gloss on statements from the Commission.

It is very important indeed for the Commission's status and standing in the community to be as high as possible. That is why we are moving some amendments which we believe improve perceptions of the equity with which the Commission deals with people. While in the community there are concerns-and some quite soundly based-that the Commission does not deal totally fairly with everyone, there will be these resentments, which should not exist in this area.

That is why at this second reading stage I would like to discuss the broad thrust of the amendments we want to move. The Bill excludes Australian Airlines Ltd from the effectiveness of the Act. That seems extraordinary. Australian Airlines, among all the competitive government business enterprises that compete in the marketplace, is selected to be exempted from the requirements of the Act. As explained to us in a committee, this was done on the basis that there has been a level playing field for Australian Airlines in competition with the other airlines, which are privately owned and do not have to meet the requirements of the Act. This rests very uneasily with the assurance by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and by the Heritage Commission that no commercial disadvantage is involved in being bound by the Act; that in fact it is simply on `an advice to the Government' basis. The Government cannot have it both ways. If there is no commercial disadvantage-if it is not a disadvantage to be listed-why on earth is Australian Airlines exempted? There is simply a logical gap in the Government's thinking on this score.

We have some concerns about the way that the Government does not observe the requirements of the Act. Had we been able to devise an appropriate amendment to require a government to be bound by its own Acts, we would have done so. We saw the extraordinary situation in the case of the Paddy's Market redevelopment. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) disgracefully ignored the requirements of this Act, thumbed his nose at it and did so in secret. It emerged that he had entirely disregarded the requirements of the Act only when he gave foreign exchange approval to a foreign based development; only when, in a court case, the facts of his ignoring the requirements of the Act became clear. A judge made a damning comment on the Treasurer's total and arrogant disregard for the requirements of this Act. Unfortunately, it is very hard to draft an amendment requiring the Government to be bound by the Act when it is in the Act itself. I guess Mr Justice Wilcox's decision will change the atmosphere. Maybe now the Government will feel that it should be bound by its own Act.

The other amendments we shall move, once again, are directed to increasing the public perceptions of the fairness of decisions made by the Heritage Commission by requiring it to take into account the economic impact of registration on the National Estate. There are those people who, quite properly, express concern that one of the major factors influencing people's views of the merit of listing, that is, the economic impact of so doing, is presently excluded by the law itself. I am talking about pragmatic effects. That has generated a perception in the community that the Australian Heritage Commission adopts a one-eyed view of these things. Our amendment to require it to take into account the economic impact simply is to increase public perceptions of its fairness. That will enhance the status of the Heritage Commission.

We also want a clear limit on the time in which the Heritage Commission has to deal with submissions. At the moment, applications can basically be hanging over a property owner for an unlimited time. The Minister has the capacity to extend the time limit under which the Commission must act for as long as he likes. We do not believe that that is proper. It can generate a lack of enthusiasm to resolve matters. In committee we heard the objection that sometimes the delays are caused by the protesters-the objectors-themselves. If the objectors themselves are mucking around they do not deserve to receive protection of this objection process. What interests me is that most of the objectors who do delay are in fact government instrumentalities. Maybe by putting a limit on it the Government will smarten up and deal with these matters quickly.

We also want to provide an avenue to deal with one of the major aspects of the legislation which I think is very important: that is, to provide people whose properties are proposed for entry on the register with the right to access information and to guarantee that right of access. It is all very well for the Government and the Commission to say, `It is our intention to provide it without cost', and so on, but there is no absolute requirement on the Commission to provide the sort of information that people normally have to get under a freedom of information (FOI) application at some cost. There is no provision for the Commission to provide that fulsome information which an FOI application would provide at no cost. We intend in the committee stage to move the following amendment:
(6) Clause 8, page 6, paragraph (h), at the end of the paragraph add ``and substituting the following subsection:

``(5) Any owner or owners (or the nominee of any owner or owners nominated in writing), of a place which is proposed for entry or entered in the Register, shall have the same right to inspect, as would exist under an application lodged under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 except at no charge, all papers or documents held by the Commission relevant to the nomination, assessment, evaluation and decision that the place should be entered in the Register.''.

This will protect the privacy of those people who make recommended nominations. Under the Freedom of Information Act, there is provision for adequate privacy. I regret to say that under our time sharing arrangements I have no further time but I commend the Opposition's amendments because they are aimed at enhancing the public status of the Australian Heritage Commission, which has the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Australian Heritage Commission Amendment Bill. It is the product of an extensive process of review and consultation. We believe that it will formalise a number of significant changes to the Australian Heritage Commission's powers and operations. The Democrats' stance on this Bill arises from our strong support for the Commission and for its rigorous work. We believe that an important measure of the integrity, and indeed the health, of our nation is the reverence which we accord to our cultural and our natural heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: We therefore believe that the Commission's tasks of listing places on the Register of the National Estate is of enormous importance, particularly at a time when reverence for our heritage is so often swept aside in a push for profits. It is well known that the Commission has been the subject of controversy in recent times. The forestry industry complains that the environment movement and the Commission itself have deliberately blurred the distinction between the National Estate and national parks in an attempt to win greater protection for National Estate forests, which they claim do not deserve it.

The real problem is that the National Estate has no real protection. It dismays us that proposals to exploit and to degrade vast tracts of native forest can be justified by the forest industry as well as by State and Federal governments as being in the national interest. It is to address this problem that I will be moving an amendment to the second reading motion to call on the Government to ensure that corporations and State, Territory, and local authorities are bound to consider prudent and feasible alternatives to any development proposal which would degrade the National Estate in the way in which Commonwealth authorities already are.

We also believe that the National Estate should be better protected, consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. In the case of the National Estate forests that protection would come from a shift to plantations as the primary resource base of the timber industry. Unfortunately, the political tide has turned against the Commission and the National Estate. Sometime next year this chamber may be called on to debate so-called resource security legislation which, after a forest zone has been declared available for logging, would exclude the Heritage Commission from offering advice which could help preserve natural values. Such legislation would be a major victory for those who are committed to neutralising the Commission.

The Democrats are aware that the Opposition will be moving a number of amendments in the committee stage, based on amendments already debated by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts two weeks ago. The Democrats will not be supporting those amendments. Two of those amendments are particularly significant in that they would compel the Commission to consider the economic impact of decisions to list places on the Register of the National Estate. This has long been Opposition policy but we believe that it is neither necessary nor practical and would be a distraction from the Commission's primary task of identifying our national heritage.

There is no shortage of economic analysis in support of development proposals in this country. The resources available for identifying natural and cultural values are by contrast woefully small. The Democrats support the Bill and we wish it a speedy proclamation. We remain concerned, however, that its passage will do little to stem the corporate tide which is rapidly eroding our heritage. I move:
At end of motion, add: ``but the Senate:
(a) recognising the importance to our cultural, environmental and economic well-being of the National Estate, and the threat posed to it by unsustainable development practices; and
(b) noting with concern the campaign by some Government ministers to dilute the Australian Heritage Commission's already limited powers to protect the National Estate;
calls on the Government to:
(i) demonstrate a minimal commitment to the National Estate by proclaiming this legislation at the earliest possible opportunity;
(ii) include the activities of corporations, and State, Territory and local authorities within the ambit of the Australian Heritage Commission Act; and
(iii) provide greater protection to the National Estate, consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development''.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Australian Heritage Commission Amendment Bill 1990. I endorse the comments of my colleague Senator Michael Baume. In dealing with the matter before us, it is my intention to move an amendment to the definition of an owner as it applies to Crown land. Part (b) of the definition of `owner' in section 3(c) of the Act relating to Crown leaseholders discriminates against exploration in the mining industries in that it will create a situation where they not be notified of heritage listings. This was raised in the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts but I was not satisfied with the answers that were given then. It is my view that in terms of the operations of the Act it is desirable that all landowners or land users, in terms of the definition of leaseholders, be notified. I do not believe that it is the difficult problem that was outlined to us because a register is kept of all leaseholders. I emphasise that we are talking about the prime leaseholder, not secondary leaseholders or arrangements that are made by a leaseholder with other people. As such, I wish to move an amendment to take out that discrimination against one of our major resource industries. It will allow the Act to operate in a better way. It will create more harmony. I believe that discrimination or any inequities in the operation of an Act in the longer term are undesirable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, the amendments outlined by Senator Michael Baume on behalf of the Opposition have been discussed at some length at a committee which you chair. I outlined the Government's position on them. I do not propose to redebate all of them but I will refer to two in particular. The first relates to the amendment which suggests that the Australian Heritage Commission should take into consideration economic matters when making decisions for National Estate listing. That is something which the Government cannot and will not accept. That represents an insidious attack on the very basis of why the Commission exists.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Commission is to look at the significance-usually the environmental significance-of the special places of this country. When it comes to making an economic assessment, when it comes to judging the worth of a mine or a timber operation, there are any number of ways in which that will come to the fore. There are government departments whose specific responsibility it is to make sure that Australia knows all about it. Private industry comes forward all the time and does it. But one wonders what the relevance of the value of a forest operation or of a mine in a National Estate area would be if a commission sat down to determine its natural significance. That goes to the heart of the Commission's functions. It is something that the Government cannot possibly agree to.

I now refer to Senator Crane's amendment concerning owners. I think the best way to kill off the Heritage Commission is to put burdens on it that it cannot possibly meet. What Senator Crane is suggesting in his amendment requires the absolute cooperation of State governments and local authorities in determining who the holders of various kinds of leases might be. It has been my experience that the Commission often does not get that kind of cooperation. This is not a matter of conservative versus Labor politics. There have been some State Labor governments which have been very slow to cooperate with the Commission in a range of areas.

There is just no point in putting a burden-a requirement-on the Commission that it cannot meet. I know that the Commission will live up to a range of provisions in this Bill which make it obligatory for it to notify certain people and to have specified periods of notice. That is only putting into practice what was already happening, but it does allay some of the fears that have been around.

I have just seen Senator Bourne's amendment. I understand that she is trying to help Ministers who, perhaps, have a different view from other Ministers. This is not the way to help them. Her statement that the tide has turned is simply wrong. That will be demonstrated over the course of the next few months. As they say in the classics, keep the faith.

The amendment calls on the Government to include the activities of corporations, State, Territory and local authorities within the ambit of the Australian Heritage Commission Act. That cannot be done. We just have to accept the fact that the Commonwealth does not have that kind of constitutional clout. While the amendment may be well-intentioned, I do not think the Government is in a position to agree to a constitutional impossibility, no matter how well-intended it might be.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ahead of its time.

—Senator McLean says it is ahead of its time. I am afraid its time will not come. I do not intend to hang by the neck waiting for changes to our Constitution. We will have to work within its limitations. We have been fairly successful at doing that in recent years and will be no less successful in the next few. I commend this piece of legislation; it is long overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, I was looking at the very last of the Liberal amendments. I now wish to conclude my remarks with regard to the amendment relating to people over the age of 65 being appointed. I emphasise that the Australian Democrats support 100 per cent the principle behind this amendment, but we will be maintaining the position we have held on three pieces of legislation; that is, until the Comcare legislation is amended to cover people over the age of 65, we do not believe that we should be putting them in a position where they will possibly need to seek an extensive appeal provision in order to receive compensation. We have been attempting since the Government supported this in a previous Bill-I believe it was last week-to get written assurance from the Minister guaranteeing that the Government will amend the Comcare legislation to cover people over 65. We have not been able to get this assurance. The Democrats put on notice that if we do not have this assurance by February, we will be moving, through a private member's Bill, to make the necessary alterations.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, I wish to note that there is one piece of the picture missing. If the Opposition and the Government are to be consistent in their concerns relating to drug use in sport then they need to look at the most commonly used drug and that is tobacco. They had an opportunity last week to support us in removing the last loophole-a loophole which sporting organisations are being pressured through. We will not stop the drug companies putting pressure on the sporting organisations to get sponsorship unless we close that final loophole. I note that Senator Powell has a Bill that she will be dealing with in February and we look forward to the Senate's support for that.

On that basis I shall not speak on the second reading but I shall speak briefly to my amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 20, page 13, subclause (3), lines 8 to 12, omit the subclause.

I am astounded at the hypocrisy of the Australian Democrats on this matter. It is absolute nonsense to claim that because Comcare has not been changed yet by the Government an intolerable situation should be allowed to continue whereby more and more governmental agencies bring in this age limit-this ageist, discriminatory limit. The Australian Democrats know perfectly well that there are plenty of government boards that do not have this discriminatory age limit and which survive quite well without Comcare.

The Democrats know that the Australian National Gallery has Mr Gough Whitlam, aged, I think, into his seventies, as its Chairman. There are plenty of them. I do not mind the Government resisting the forces of progress- after all, that is its consistent position-but I find it intolerable that the Australian Democrats would continue to display this nonsensical hypocrisy, no doubt because they have done some sort of deal with the Government, and refuse to join with the Opposition in getting rid of and preventing the extension of this ageist discrimination against these bodies.

We had the same thing in the debate on the National Maritime Museum Bill. The Government, by accident, when Senator Tate was being reasonable in a sea of unreasonableness on his side, accepted it last week in respect of the pharmaceutical legislation. I urge the Democrats to recognise that they are continuing and improperly maintaining ageist discriminatory legislation. The coalition believes this amendment is right and should be supported. Senator Crichton-Browne will move the amendments standing in his name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 67, page 26, after subclause (4), insert the following subclause:
``(4a) For the avoidance of doubt, and without prejudice to the effect of any other law, it is declared that this section does not affect:
(a) the presentation or submission of a document, or the giving of evidence, to a House or a committee; or
(b) the operation of a lawful order of a House or a committee.''.
Clause 67, page 27, subclause (5), before definition of ``court'', insert the following definition:
`` `committee' means a committee of a House or of both Houses, or a subcommittee of such a committee;''.
Clause 67, page 27, subclause (5), after definition of ``court'' insert the following definition:
`` `House' means either House of the Parliament;''.

Clause 67 is a standard secrecy provision which honourable senators will find sprinkled through about 300 Acts of the Commonwealth. I would like to draw attention to a rather bizarre legal opinion given by the Solicitor-General in respect of the same set of words in the National Crime Authority legislation that purports to suggest that any witness appearing before a committee of the Parliament who discloses information within the terms of the clause will find himself subject to a penalty of two years in gaol. That is a bizarre interpretation because section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act starts off with words to the effect, `So as to clear up any doubt.'

Section 16 provides absolute immunity from any prosecution for any disclosure to anyone who appears, whether voluntarily or by subpoena, before a parliamentary committee and gives evidence; and quite rightly so. A simple fundamental principle contained in the Charter of the Bill of Rights of 1651 provides that people who appear before the Parliament will be immune from any prosecution as a result of what they say. This pretty simple and fundamental provision is enshrined in Parliamentary Privileges Act; that is why the Act is there. The Solicitor-General has given a bizarre opinion that this is not the case. My amendment is a declaratory amendment which does nothing other than declare and re-state the position as it is. Hence the reason for this amendment.

For the purpose of the Australian Democrats-although I am certain they understand this-my amendment does not provide for the public disclosure of anyone who tests positive. It is simply to give immunity. For instance, if the chairman of the new authority were to come before a committee and asked in camera to provide the names of athletes who might have tested positive, this amendment would stop him going to gaol for two years. That is all; it is not for public disclosure. That is the purpose of the amendment. It is a declaratory amendment which, frankly, under normal circumstances, one would not expect to have to move. However, because the Solicitor-General has given an opinion which the Attorney-General said he will accept as policy, we are required to move these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee that the amendment moved by Senator Michael Baume and the two amendments moved by Senator Crichton-Browne be dealt with together? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will quickly outline the Government's position on these amendments. In respect of the amendment relating to the aged, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is considering a report prepared by his Department on the issues raised by the review and on possible measures to overcome instances of age discrimination. It is understood that the Attorney will issue a discussion paper within the next couple of months, which will be followed by a series of consultations and possibly by legislation sometime during 1991. Might I say that I am delighted to have an expression of confidence by Senator Baume in Mr Whitlam's capacity. It is something like 15 years overdue but is no less welcome for that. We are indebted to that Christmas spirit which no doubt inspired it.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the privacy matter raised by Senator Crichton-Browne, the Government's resistance to this has, I think, been well articulated in other places. In the event that there is media speculation about a particular athlete, there is a safeguard in the legislation to enable the issue to be raised in Parliament. Provision has been included for the Minister to request the agency to notify him or her whether a competitor's name has been entered on the register. Under those circumstances, we believe there is no basis for pursuit of this amendment at this stage.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Michael Baume's) (Senator Crichton-Browne's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.
Amendment (by Senator Michael Baume) proposed:
After Clause 73, page 28, add the following clause:
Cessation of operation
``74. This Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to be in force at the expiration of 3 years after the date of commencement of this Act.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Michael Baume because I believe there should be a central testing agency away from the sports. Senator Baume told us yesterday that amateurs have been cheating in sport. It is not only the amateurs who have been cheating. I was a member of the inquiry and I believe that professionals have been cheating too. We should have a central testing agency and keep it. But I condemn the Government because, under the financial impact statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The administrative and operational expenses relating to staff, travel, meetings and day-to-day running costs of the Agency, following the proclamation of the Act, will be determined annually in the Budget.

We had nothing from the Government to tell us how it was going to do any cost recovery. We have cost recoveries on everything else-meat inspections by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and all that sort of thing. But in this case, it did not give us one ounce of it. I am not prepared to give the Government an open cheque book.

If the Government had said that it was moving towards some cost recovery-whether it be 10 per cent moving to 50 per cent because the amateurs have problems with paying for the testing-but the professional sports such as the Australian Football League, professional boxing, rugby league, and a whole lot across the board can pay. If the Government had put something in here that it was moving towards cost recovery, as it expects other industries around Australia to do, Senator Michael Baume would have had no need to move this amendment. It is on this basis that I support the amendment. Hopefully by the time the Budget comes around next year, the Government will tell us how it will effect some cost recovery.
Amendment negatived.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the Report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia-India relations: Trade and Security. I seek leave to incorporate that response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to that response.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The Government has approached the Report with great interest, and find much in the findings and recommendations with which we can readily agree. We welcome the thoughtful, imaginative and forward-looking approach taken by the Senate Committee and share its view that our relationship with India has much to offer. The friendship between our Prime Minister and the former Indian Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, successive Ministerial visits from both countries and contacts between officials have confirmed this and provided an impetus for the relationship which is entirely consistent with the thinking reflected in the Report.

The relationship has been important to both countries since India established independence, and is by no means static. There have been periods of activity, but also periods of relative neglect. We do not always see eye to eye with India, and there are times when, as mature democracies, we have agreed to differ. But our political dialogue with India is relevant, we share objectives and concerns on important global issues and, as the Committee found, there is room for development. As the Prime Minister's visit in 1989 and the subsequent Ministerial and other visits have shown, the Government shares the view that the time is right to invest the relationship with energy and vision. It is this Government's firm conviction that, this time, the revitalised relationship is here to stay.

The Report itself is timely. Significant changes in the international environment have helped make it so. The Report draws attention to the process of economic liberalisation which has been under way and which has attracted the attention of a number of countries. The institution of policies for economic openness has been one of the hallmarks of our own Government.

Our support for economic openness has been an important element in our efforts in multilateral trade forums, and we look for likemindedness in our friends. We welcome increasing access and openness in India, and I believe that our commercial interests in India will continue to be productive for both sides if they are matched by a continuing Indian liberalisation effort. We hope that the new Government under Mr Chandra Shekar will continue the trends set by his two predecessors in this regard.

The Report has also served to highlight matters of concern to those Government Departments dealing with aspects of our relations with India. The Government acknowledges that there has been a need for a coordinated strategy in dealing with India. We are all familiar with the tension in the bilateral relationship which followed the Government's decision to sell its obsolescent Mirage aircraft to Pakistan. It is certainly our strong desire to avoid such setbacks in the future, and I am confident that the lessons learned from this episode, relating especially to the need for careful coordination, have not been lost on those concerned.

I believe the Committee's report may have under-valued the progress made in the relationship with India in recent years and the role of the Government in assisting or facilitating this effort. In summary, the Australia-India relationship of the 1990s has seen:
* a 200 per cent increase in total two way trade between 1983/84 and 1989/90 in dollar terms;
* an Australia-India Joint Business Council;
* a Joint Trade Committee;
* a Joint Working Group on Coal;
* a $A35 million, three-year development co-operation program and a treaty to facilitate it;
* a Joint Ministerial Commission,
* an umbrella agreement fostering cooperation in science and technology, under which a number of projects is being pursued in fields such as space science and monsoon meteorology;
* a range of bilateral defence exchanges;
* a Mixed Commission which is actively promoting cultural and political exchanges; and
* a significantly expanded political agenda, which includes regular bilateral disarmament talks.

The process of developing the relationship has generated an unprecedented level of importance which is reflected in the Department's corporate plan. The Department now coordinates the Officials' Working Group on India, an interdepartmental committee which, apart from monitoring and coordinating the operational arm of our relationship, also has productive links with key groups in the private sector. At a time when the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, like the rest of the public sector, is operating under tight resource constraints, an officer at Deputy Secretary level in my Department is spending much of his time on the development of our commercial relationship with India, and staffing at the High Commission in New Delhi has been increased. Further, the Department's public affairs program in India has been tailored to support our export drive. The establishment of the Australia Abroad Council will ensure improved coordination and a sharper focus of that public diplomacy effort in India, in the context of increased emphasis on the Asian region generally. I would also note that our level of funding for cultural activities in India in the coming year, while less than ideal, nonetheless represents an increase.

Having made these points, which I think clearly signal our intentions with regard to the relationship, I must point out that a good working relationship requires two willing partners. It has been gratifying for the Prime Minister and for me to have been assured, at the highest levels, that India shares our desire to develop the relationship, and we confidently expect that the new Indian Government will continue to reciprocate our efforts.

Underpinning the new level of attention, and providing its strategic direction, are a range of long term projects with well defined objectives. The major focus of the enhanced relationship agreed upon by Prime Ministers Hawke and Gandhi in Canberra in 1986 has been commercial. In the six years to 1990, bilateral trade has increased by well over 200 per cent and is fast approaching the $A1 billion mark. During the Joint Ministerial Commission in 1989, the Indian and Australian negotiators reached an agreement to work towards doubling the two-way value of trade by 1992. We are on the way toward meeting that objective.

What we must appreciate is that the concept of bilaterally balanced trade is not necessarily an indication of a healthy trading relationship. We must ensure a fair share of the benefits from the growth in bilateral trade while working towards reducing the present imbalance. To this end we have set a target, in consultation with the Indian Government, whereby one per cent of our total imports of engineering products should come from India. This agreement was made subject to the quality and price competitiveness of the Indian products. Since that decision the Market Advisory Service of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has spent a total of $A300,000 on promoting Indian engineering products in Australia.

We now also have in place an extensive array of bodies or forums designed to promote the economic relationship between us. We have the Australia-India Joint Business Council, the Joint Trade Committee, the Joint Working Group on Coal and the Joint Ministerial Commission. We have results to show for this: the Piparwar open cut mine and the Karwar naval base consultancy are important successes for Australian companies and showcases for Australian expertise and technology.

These kind of achievements require a dexterous use of diplomatic, marketing and financial resources. I believe we are using them well. Through DIFF we have been able to offer an attractive mixture of aid funds and commercial export finance. It is not mentioned in the Report, but the grant aid component of the Piparwar project-$A60.3 million-was funded under DIFF. Our ability to offer concessional finance can often make a difference in helping Australian firms with initiative and tenacity to establish themselves and their products in the Indian market.

It is possible that the limited penetration of the Indian market described in the Report reflects an establishment of Australian business priorities occasioned by the genuine difficulties and costs encountered in overcoming existing Indian trade barriers. India, for all its large size and growth in GDP, actually imports fewer goods than does Australia, and this shows the difficulties faced by Australian companies in establishing a bridgehead for Australian goods in India. Nonetheless, the fact that some Australian companies have succeeded in doing business in India shows what is possible.

Looking to the future, we will be hoping for further progress in trade liberalisation in India and, consistent with the Report's recommendation, we should encourage the Government to make swifter progress in relaxing trade and investment controls detrimental to our interests. Indeed, much effort is, in fact, already devoted to that objective-officers are persistent in raising questions with appropriate Ministries, as well as through multilateral channels such as the Uruguay Round.

We will also be encouraging our private sector to make the most of opportunities as they arise. In 1989, Austrade strengthened its presence in New Delhi, and I look forward to continuing an even closer cooperation between its representatives and those of my Department there. There is likely to be a qualitative increase in the commercial intelligence available to the public and private sectors as a result.
DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION

An important element in our enhanced relationship with India is our agreement on a new $A35 million development cooperation program over three years, beginning in 1990/91. This is grant aid, additional to the assistance provided under the DIFF scheme. The program has the potential to play a significant role in encouraging mutually beneficial links between Australia and India. The program will be focussed on sectors upon which India places development priority and in which Australia has comparative advantage. These include mining and energy (with an appropriate environmental focus), telecommunications, food technology and railways.

I am pleased to report that the High Level Officials' Consultations were held in Canberra in October and that an Agreement on Development Cooperation covering the new program was signed. Agreement has been reached with the Indian Government on a number of project design and feasibility studies planned to take place this financial year.
DEFENCE

The Government broadly endorses the analysis of India's military capabilities and objectives set out in the Report. We understand the historical factors that have helped to fashion India's perception of its strategic environment. India, in the four decades since Independence, has fought a number of wars. It still has disputed borders and faces some serious separatist and insurgency problems. We are also aware that our own position, as participants in a long standing alliance, is somewhat different from that of India.

We would not wish to give the impression that we are unable to understand India's circumstances. We recognise that India must be able to protect its long coastline, its scattered island territories and its off-shore interests. India's strategic circumstances mean that it needs to maintain a certain level of military capability. We also readily acknowledge that while India's military build-up has enhanced its power projection capability in the South Asia region, this does not constitute a threat to the security of Australia or South East Asia. We would, however, emphasise the need for openness and dialogue to allay any regional concerns that may arise from time to time.

I note that there was little reference in the Report to the strengthening of the bilateral defence relationship. We engage in a range of visits and defence staff exchanges, and have re-established the Defence Attache position in New Delhi. These measures will contribute to a better comprehension of and means of dialogue about India's defence preoccupations, and thus to a better understanding of India's strategic concerns and objectives.

Nuclear proliferation pressures in South Asia will continue to warrant the attention of the Government. We have made our concerns known to both India and Pakistan on this issue. The dialogue has been strengthened through bilateral disarmament talks held at Prime Ministerial instigation. I also pursued the issue during my visits to both countries earlier this year. Our position remains clear. The Government believes it would be in the interests of all nations if both India and Pakistan were to demonstrate conclusively that they were not pursuing a nuclear option. This could be done by their acceding to the NPT or, at the very least, placing all their nuclear facilities under full scope safeguards applied by the International Atomic Energy Agency. It is worth pointing out that Australia maintains links with India through the Regional Cooperation Agreements under the umbrella of the IAEA.
INFORMATION AND EDUCATION
The Committee's recommendations for the establishment of an Australia-India Council, and an Indian Studies Centre deserve particular attention.

I support the establishment of an Australia-India Council. It would undoubtedly prove to be a catalyst in the development of our relations. Similar arrangements in the cases of China, Japan and Indonesia have proven profitable. I accordingly intend to seek funds for the Council, as a new policy proposal in the coming budget. It should be noted, however, that in the difficult budgetary environment the Government continues to face, the proposal will have to compete with other pressing priorities, and the Council's establishment in 1991-92 cannot at this stage be guaranteed.

With regard to the proposed India Studies Centre, I agree in principle but must make the point again that a decision can only be made in the budgetary context. The Minister for Education, Employment and Training has recently commissioned, through the Asian Studies Council, the production of a national strategy document for the study of India, to be completed in the coming months. One of the tasks of those devising the national strategy document will be to consider the recommendations of the Report. The results will help inform the Government's decision on the proposed Centre. I would appreciate further comment from the Committee as to what it envisages the form, role, location and structure of an Indian Studies Centre might be. I also note with interest the Committee's intention that an Indian Studies Centre attract private sector support in the long term. I would be interested in indications from the business community as to the feasibility of such an arrangement.

The Report highlights the crucial function of education in developing the relationship by providing an expert base, as well as a better informed community. Much has taken place toward that end. The Asian Studies postgraduate Scheme and the National Asian Languages Scholarship Scheme aim to increase Australian expertise on Asia. A series of awards for study in India have been made for 1990 and 1991. The establishment in 1990 of the Indian Ocean Peace Studies Centre, to be jointly managed by the University of Western Australia and Curtin University of Technology also helps us in moving towards the goal of a better informed Australia. Under the Targeted Institutional Links Programme, Murdoch and Curtin University have received grants to strengthen their ties with Indian institutions in areas of priority for Australia.

In the context of improving two-way information flows, informal links and understanding generally it should be noted that the recently established Australia Abroad Council, an advisory body of 30 prominent Australians representing all relevant government agencies and the private sector, now has the task, the commitment and discretionary funds of $A1 million to project Australia's image overseas more effectively. The Council has a particular interest in education, science and technology and sport and will be focusing on the Asia-Pacific region. I hope and expect that the Council will pay particular attention to India, including facilitating an expanded programme of visits from India.

With regard to Immigration, an issue touched upon in the Report, I can comment that during 1989/1990 there was a 74 per cent increase in migration applications, and migrant visas issued rose by 32 per cent. Liberalised procedures for assessing Indian professional and technical qualifications will also boost the number of applicants eligible for migration to Australia. The recent enhancement of staffing of the Immigration section in Delhi will allow for an increased capacity to respond to Indian interest in Australia.
CONCLUSION

The recommendations made by the Senate Committee offer valuable pointers for the future direction of the relationship. Many of the areas identified by the Committee as being ripe for progress are of course beyond the Government's authority, but those recommendations for which the Government has responsibility are addressed in the attached document. The release of the Report itself has provided further impetus for our relationship with India and I am pleased to have been able to report some progress. I look forward to being part of its continuing evolution.
COMMITTEE RECOMMENDATIONS AND SCHEDULE OF RESPONSES
EDUCATION

6.33 With due regard for the above considerations, the Committee recommends the establishment of an Indian Studies Centre to provide advanced academic study of a range of Indian related disciplines. The development of this Centre should be based on a thorough analysis of the needs of the Australian Government and the business community. In establishing the Centre, the Committee recommends maximum use of existing academic resources. In particular, Indian Studies Centre should overcome the existing problem of loss of institutional memory on India as individual universities change their priorities away from Indian studies or as Australia's older academics specialising in India retire. Such a Centre would become the country's register of expertise on India in other Australian institutions or enterprises.

6.34 The Committee believes that future development of Asian studies in Australia should recognise the need to pursue a two-track approach-the first involving support for advanced studies in humanities (history, literature, languages, arts and social sciences); the second involving support for commercially related, applied studies. Government, educational institutions and the commercial sector should work actively to develop the two elements in tandem, with a creative and innovative approach to promoting interaction between the academic and applied streams. Studies in support of trade and collection of basic data on Australia/India trade should be an important part of the Centre's activity.

6.35 The Committee believes that the long-term funding of an Indian Studies Centre should be undertaken on a partnership basis between government and commercial enterprises, particularly large public corporations. The relatively new Australia-India Business Council may be able to play some role. In fact, the development of an education policy, duly accompanied by appropriate funding, could be regarded as an integral part of the Council's trade promotion program.

6.36 The Federal Government as an important user-at least in theory-of expertise on all of Australia's major Asian neighbours should take a strong lead in developing a more solid basis for future Australian knowledge and study of India. The Committee believes that the Australian Government should, through relevant organisations such as the Asian Studies Council, commit itself to strong funding support for an Indian Studies Centre for an initial fixed term such as five years. The main user departments, such as Foreign Affairs and Trade, Defence, and the Office of National Assessments, must have training and information requirements that an Indian Studies Centre would satisfy and which are not now being fully met.

6.37 The level of funding required would be several hundred thousand dollars per year over and above current costs of existing Indian studies courses in the universities. The Committee believes such a funding level could be easily met within existing levels of appropriations by the relevant departments through minor adjustments in priorities.

6.38 The Committee envisages a need for the development of innovative funding and endowment arrangements for a new Indian Studies Centre. The provision of direct commercial support for specific specialisations in advanced study in the humanities in Australia is extremely underdeveloped, and, as a consequence, many areas of foreign commercial and government policy analysis suffer.

6.41 The mechanism by which a new Indian Studies Centre is created would be the concern of the relevant organisations but the Committee believes that a free-standing Centre, affiliated with a major university, would be the most desirable model. A new corporate body formed around representatives of major interested parties would appear to be the management arrangement most likely to guarantee long-term private sector funding (and use) of the Centre.

6.45 No time should be lost in establishing the new Centre if it is to begin operating as a driving force in the development of Australian expertise on India, particularly in commercially related aspects. For this reason, the Committee does not regard it as premature for interested parties to begin studying and planning for the Centre immediately.

6.48 The Committee believes that education policy in Australia has not kept pace with the increased Asian share of Australian trade, tourism, cultural exchanges and security preoccupations. In this respect, the Committee endorses the recommendations of the Ingleson Report for an expansion of Asia related content in general curriculum design for humanities subjects at all levels of education.
Response

The Asian Studies Council, an advisory body to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, has commissioned the production of a national strategy document for the study of India. A draft structure was provided to assist in addressing areas of particular concern to the Council, including consideration of the recommendations of this Report. The completed document will be available early in the coming year. It is possible that such a centre could operate as a ``think tank'' for organisations which either do not have the specialist resources or the time to devote to issues relating to the area. It could also provide useful services to relevant departments currently dealing with a range of issues where conditions or activities in South Asia are relevant, eg, trade, nuclear disarmament, chemical weapons, strategic planning, zones of peace, narcotics, environments, on a fee for service basis.

The Asian Studies Postgraduate Scheme and National Asian Languages Scholarship Scheme aim to increase Australian expertise on Asia. Under the former scheme, three awards were made for study in India in 1990 and six for study in 1991; under the latter two awards were made for study in 1991.

Australian understanding of the strategic context in which India operates will be enhanced by the establishment of the Indian Ocean Peace Studies Centre, jointly managed by the University of Western Australia and Curtin University of Technology. The Centre was set up by a grant under the National Priority Reserve Fund in 1990. A conference to be held by the Centre in early 1991 on ``Prospects for Peace in the Indian Ocean'' will be addressed by speakers from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and the United States and will be attended by officials from a number of Government Departments and agencies.

The Targeted Institutional Links programme, aimed at broadening Australia's educational interaction with Asia beyond traditional aid objectives to activities more rigorously assessed for mutual benefit, enables Australian higher education institutions to apply for funding to strengthen ties with their counterparts in the Asian region in priority areas for Australia. Murdoch and Curtin Universities have received the grants listed below under the current round of funding to strengthen their links with Indian institutions.
The Government anticipates that arrangements such as these will have positive and long term consequences for Australia's relationship with India.

* Murdoch University received contributions towards links with the University of Jadavpur, Calcutta, the Central Electrochemical Research Institute, Madras, and the Indian Institute of Technology, Madras in the fields of energy technology and data processing.

* Curtin University of Technology received support for a research exchange programme with Delhi University's Delhi School of Economics and Institute of Economic Growth and for postdoctoral research fellowships in petroleum geochemistry with the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India.
* India was one of the first five countries (with Pakistan, Korea, Taiwan and Thailand) eligible for linkages under the Targeted Institutional Links Programme.

* The Government notes that the West Australian Geoscience and Technology Institute has established an impressive range of links in India and has offered to share its experiences with other Australian firms interested in developing the Indian market.
Recommendations 6.43, 6.45, 6.46

6.43 The Committee is aware of the interest in the academic community and government in a broader South Asian perspective for a new Centre, so that it would include study of Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, rather than focus exclusively on India. However, resource priorities would appear to exclude development of such a broad focus for a new centre. Existing discipline-based studies (such as political science or development economics) could be expected to provide some coverage. Foreign academic resources can also be relied upon.

6.45 No time should be lost in establishing the new Centre if it is to begin operating as a driving force in the development of Australian expertise on India, particularly in commercially related aspects. For this reason, the Committee does not regard it as premature for interested parties to begin studying and planning for the Centre immediately.

6.46 Apart from the creation of a new Indian Studies centre, there are a number of avenues in the educating of Australians about India that the Committee believes should be pursued more vigorously. These include teacher and student exchanges, industry training in Australia of Indian nationals from Indian state corporations, conferences and symposia, trade union exchanges, and trade fairs.
Response

The Government accepts the Committee's findings. As noted in my Response, the Committee's recommendation for the establishment of an Indian Studies Centre is being presently considered. The Government takes note of the points regarding its ambit, and would comment that although the priority of any such centre would naturally be India, any study of India would, of necessity, include study of its regional context.
Recommendation 6.47

The advancement of Indian studies in Australia could usefully be accompanied by increased support for Australian studies in India. Australian public bodies have some role to play here and, while needing to consider the prerogatives of the Indian Government, are free to undertake a range of initiatives.
Response

Jawaharlal Nehru University has expressed interest in providing a base for an Australian Studies Resource Centre and the Cultural Relations Branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is examining this possibility as well as the feasibility of establishing an Australian Studies Centre in India.

Additional investigation of means of increasing support for Australian Studies in India could be carried by the Australia Abroad Council, on which the Department of Employment, Education and Training is represented.
Recommendation 6.49

One of the biggest obstacles to the fostering of advanced Studies of Indian affairs, and Asian studies in general in Australia, is the lack of professional rewards available to people with advanced qualifications in the field. For example, people with Master's degrees or Doctorates in Asian studies can receive almost no recognition, compensation or employment in government or industry significantly different from that received by people without such specialist qualifications. Some Asian studies specialists are able to obtain employment in their subject areas for several years but are, for the sake of promotion, eventually forced to work in areas not specifically related to their field of expertise. At the same time, government and industry regularly observe a deficiency in Asian expertise within the country. The Committee therefore urges employers across the country to review their recruitment and incentive policies for people with specialist skills in Asian studies.
Response

The Government appreciates the point made by the Committee. However, in recruitment, the Government is obliged to strike a balance between its needs for specialists and generalists. Recruitment in relevant Departments does follow foreign and trade policy trends, but as a small country, we do not have the kind of structures available to allow specialists to make careers exclusively on the basis of a particular skill. Inevitably, and in the interests of an efficient and effective Government service, specialist officers will require broader management and policy skills to advance beyond a certain level.
AUSTRALIA-INDIA COUNCIL
Recommendations 6.52, 6.53, 6.55

6.52 The Committee recommends therefore the immediate establishment by the Australian Government of an Australia-India Council. The aims of the Council would be to raise Australian expertise on India; to raise awareness of India in Australia and of Australia in India; to identify gaps in the relationship and focus attention on these through appropriate initiatives and to organise support for and otherwise encourage a broad range of contacts between state and private organisations, governments, and people in the two countries.

6.53 The Council should initially comprise leading members of Australian business, academic and governmental organisations who have strong expertise in Indian affairs. The Council should be established by an Order-in-Council, with members to be appointed by the Governor-General, on the recommendation of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

6.55 The Council would be responsible for providing some financial assistance to support innovative projects aimed at promoting longer term Australian goals with respect to India. In order not to dilute its resources or its goals, the Council should in the Committee's view support projects which are likely to have a ``strategic'' impact on relations between the two countries or on Australian expertise on India. The Council could build on areas where cultural exchange already has a prominent profile as is the case with cricket. An eminent practitioner of the sport could be considered for a position on the Council.
Response
The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade supports the establishment of an Australia-India Council, and will seek funds for the Council in the 1991-92 budget.

The Government accepts that Councils such as that suggested by the Committee can have an excellent effect on bilateral relations. Our relationship with India is at a point where its development would be accelerated by the establishment of a Council. The Government also understands that its support for a Council will be welcomed by the Indian Government.
INFORMATION POLICY
Recommendations 6.58, 6.59

6.58 The Committee recommends that Departments and authorities review their basic intelligence capability in respect of India. The Committee believes that the sort of information and analyses that government Departments provided in submissions should already have been available in internal documents before the event and not been the object of a major research and writing task once the Committee called for submissions.

6.59 The Committee recommends that Australian Government departments regularly place in the public domain major assessments and information reports of a topical nature on the key countries of Asia. This already occurs to some extent through a variety of mechanisms, such as ministerial statements, answers to parliamentary questions, departmental information bulletins, and submissions to parliamentary inquiries. The interest shown by the general public through inquiries to this Committee's Secretariat for copies of departmental submissions is some evidence that public demand for certain types of assessments is not being met by other mechanisms. Assessments by the Department of Defence are in particular demand. Regular release of intelligence assessments of the security policies of our neighbours should make a worthwhile contribution to public attitudes and public debate on defence and security issues.
Response

The Government can report that it keeps its intelligence base under review at all times, and finds it satisfactory. We are highly conscious of the importance of promoting an informed public debate on defence and security issues in Australia. The Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities (1986), The Defence of Australia 1987 Policy Information Paper, and my 1989 statement on Australia's Regional Security have made major contributions to this. In addition, frequent Ministerial statements and addresses outline the Government's views on specific issues. While India is undoubtedly a major strategic player in the Indian Ocean region, its capabilities and intentions do not affect Australia's area of direct military interest. Our primary concern is to avoid misunderstandings in our region about India's strategic objectives and the substantial expansion of its maritime capabilities. The Government believes that for Australia to speculate on this issue in the way suggested would be counterproductive, not least to maintaining positive bilateral relations. There is benefit however, in encouraging the Indian Government to be as open as possible in explaining the rationale behind its defence and foreign policies.
Recommendations 6.60, 6.61, 6.62

6.60 The Committee recommends that government departments review the degree to which their existing analysis of Indian politics, economics and defence policy provides an adequate basis for assessment of long term trends across the range of policy issues. In respect of trade, the Government's data base and analysis should be more responsive to the demands of business. In particular, the Committee recommends that government agencies, universities and businesses review their information holdings on legal aspects of doing business in India.

6.61 AUSTRADE has made considerable advances in provision of market intelligence to Australian exporters in the last year through the establishment of a subscriber service computer data base, called TOP-Trade Opportunities, which incorporates not only information collected by AUSTRADE but also major international commercial data-bases. The Committee applauds such initiatives.

6.62 At the same time, the processed intelligence-the hard assessment of particular commercial issues-is something that cannot be provided by a fact based data system. Human resources and constant reassessment are central to good commercial intelligence. The Committee recommends that the government agencies assess the quality of their commercial intelligence services from that perspective.
Response

As is noted in the preceding response to the Committee's Report, resources devoted to India within Government departments have significantly increased. This includes the strengthening of Austrade and our Trade Policy function in Delhi. An additional Trade Commissioner (Engineering) has been added to the staff, charged with the assessment of opportunities for Australian businesses which could flow from Indian encouragement of the private sector and its manufacturing industry. These factors have made a considerable difference to our data base on India, which is growing steadily and under continual assessment to assure its relevance and quality. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is well aware of the need to meet the demands of business and its links with the private sector are solid. To that end the Government is pleased to acknowledge the roles that the Industry based bodies of AUSTENERGY, AUSTMINE and AGRITEC have played in developing a strategic approach toward India and improving market knowledge. My Department works closely with each of these bodies and will continue to do so.
Recommendation 6.64

Given the relatively undeveloped state of expertise on India in the relevant areas of government departments, the Committee recommends that departments institute a system whereby major assessment or policy papers would be subject to critical appraisal by at least one external expert. The establishment of a working relationship between government departments and experts-who could be given appropriate security clearances-is a normal practice in the United States and the United Kingdom.
Response

Most officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade with substantive duties relating to India have considerable experience of working with that country, and several of them have served either in New Delhi or elsewhere in the sub-continent. During the past two years, an officer at Deputy Secretary level has spent much of his time on the development of our commercial relationship with India, and staffing at the High Commission in New Delhi has been increased. As well, the Department has an extensive range of contacts with the private sector, academic institutions and other government departments, and is thus the beneficiary of a wide range of views on India. Its dealings with these bodies, it is constantly engaged in testing its views against those of other interested parties.
We would not wish to see this inhibited by formalising the arrangement.
Recommendation 6.66

The Committee also regards as unacceptable the practice whereby one government department seeks to publish a major document on a subject as important as foreign trade or foreign relations without first incorporating the information or assessments that all other key departments, or the relevant diplomatic missions overseas, might have to offer. The decision by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to publish its ``Trade and Commercial Development Program for Australia in India'' independently from and ahead of AUSTRADE's proposed ``Market Development Plan'' strikes the Committee as undesirable. The lack of regular access of AUSTRADE officials to briefing papers prepared in government departments is also a matter of concern to the Committee.
Response

The two reports referred to in the recommendation covered different areas of reference and had different objectives. Further, the report prepared by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was cleared with AUSTRADE.

It is the emphatic policy of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to employ the most comprehensive research possible in the production of major documents, in full consultation with all relevant agencies. It is quite open with other agencies in its approach both generally and specifically. With regard to India, the Officials' Working Group provides an easy route to wide consultation. The Government is not aware that AUSTRADE has difficulty in gaining access to briefing material. If that had been the case, it is our expectation that this would have been raised either at the Officials' Working Group on India or taken up more formally. The Government expects a free exchange of relevant documents between all Government Departments and agencies. Indeed consultation between AUSTRADE officers and officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on India is active, and frequent.
Recommendation 6.69

The Committee notes the statement in the ``Trade and Commercial Development Program for Australia in India'' that an appropriate Australian Overseas Information Service (AOIS) program will be developed as an integral part of Australia's overall strategy'. The Committee recommends that the relevant departments participate jointly in development of any AOIS plan for promotion of Australia in India. The Committee further recommends that AOIS activities in India be developed with the long term purpose of Supporting Australian exports and not be devoted to support of broader goals of propagandising to Indians the quality and unique features of the Australian way of life. The Committee does not believe that Australia can afford to devote its information resources in India to the imitation of the cultural export policies of more wealthy countries, such as the United States, France or Canada.
Response

The Australia Abroad Council, a body of 30 prominent Australians representing all relevant government agencies and the private sector, chaired by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, has recently been established. The Council will operate as an instrument of public diplomacy. Its role will be to advise the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade on ways of projecting our interests overseas, with particular focus on the Asia-Pacific region. This will naturally include India. The Council has discretionary funds of $A1 million and a particular interest in education, science and technology and sport. The Council will coordinate, focus and further develop the international activities of those government and nongovernment agencies which help shape the projection of Australia overseas.
GOVERNMENT SUPPORT FOR TRADE
Recommendations 6.70, 6.71

The Committee is strongly of the view that the main responsibility for development of export markets rests with the private sector. This view is based on the facts that the market-place decides and that business people are in the best position to respond to the market-place for their particular product. However, in the case of countries such as India, with a large public sector, the Australian Government has an important role as a facilitator.

6.71 Therefore, the Committee does see merit in the development by government agencies of marketing strategies built around the promotion of a wide range of particular sectors in India. At the same time, the Committee recommends that relevant departments, and AUSTRADE itself, could give more weight to sector specific strategies responsible to the global market-place in the development of country oriented strategies. The continued implementation over several years of a country specific plan in countries like India may not prove worthwhile in the longer term if the commercial prospects in the particular country for industries targeted in the country plan do not improve or even worsen. AUSTRADE has already made some progress in developing its sector export strategies, according to its 1988-89 Annual Report.
Response
The Government also believes that the main responsibility for the development of export markets lies with the private sector.

AUSTRADE operational plans for individual markets have developed from the collective assessment of specific industry strategies based on market research by AUSTRADE overseas posts. These strategies are kept under constant review. The scope of these strategies has been considerably expanded since AUSTRADE appeared before the Committee.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade also makes an important contribution through its high level contact with Indian officials and others directed to establishing and maintaining a sound knowledge of the Indian economic system.
It also assesses the prospects for further liberalisation of the Indian market and the opportunities this may present for Australian business.
Recommendation 6.73

The Committee believes that the government function in support of trade must be based on maximum flexibility to respond to the specific demands of business as they arise in four specific areas especially: provision of commercial intelligence; liaison or dealing with state ministries or corporations in the host country on behalf of Australian commercial enterprises; export promotional activities; and provision of administrative support for Australian business people not yet acquainted with or established in the country concerned. The question of the long term desirability of government financial support for Australian exports through various rebate, loan or soft credit schemes is one which the Committee believes is worthy of thorough review.
Response
AUSTRADE routinely provides business support to Australian commercial enterprises. Where resources permit, administrative support can be made available on a user pays basis.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade also makes available information on relevant aspects of Indian economic policy through business and academic services and contact with exporters with an interest in India.
Recommendation 6.75

One important function for AUSTRADE, and perhaps the ANZ Banking Group, in support of Australian exports to India may be active involvement in consortium development, especially in bringing together Indian investors, either state sector or private, and Australian businesses. AUSTRADE may well be the only Australian organisation, apart from the ANZ Banking Group, with sufficient exposure in India to set up long-term collaborations between Australian and Indian partners.
Response

Following a successful collaboration with Grindlays in Africa, AUSTRADE is looking toward further collaborations and is interested in the proposal contained in the recommendation in relation to India.
DIPLOMACY
Recommendations 6.76, 6.77

6.76 Australia must recognise its own limitations in regard to its influence as a medium level power. Simply put, Australia must decide the relative priority it is to give to the fostering of Australian exports in comparison with the priority given to attempts to influence Indian thinking on its own security affairs. No other country will look to Australia's export performance in India but a number of far more influential countries, such as the United States and Great Britain, are already actively seeking to influence Indian economic and security politics in much the same directions as Australia. Australia must recognise the potential reactions it could generate by taking the moral high ground in relation to countries like India.

6.77 The Committee recommends that a large part of Australia's diplomatic effort in India be directed at encouraging the Indian Government to make faster progress towards relaxing trade and investment controls detrimental to Australian business. However, fundamentally important issues like Antarctica, chemical weapons, and nuclear proliferation should-in the Committee's view-still remain important in Australia's diplomatic priorities in India.
Response

The Government is interested in the Committee's comments but surprised at the separation of the two elements. It does not view them as divorced, and would instead argue that an enhanced trade and commercial profile tends to provide greater access in areas of political significance to Australia, such as regional security, Antarctica, and chemical weapons. Similarly, improved dialogue and understanding on the political side of the relationship helps to enhance the prospects for obtaining improved trade and commercial links. Our attempts to work towards a secure and stable region are likely to be assisted by the development and maintenance of as broad a range of positive links as possible. Further, it is the view of the Government that this recommendation does not sit comfortably with the thrust of the report which makes the point that, to enhance and develop the relationship, contacts must be made across a wide range of issues and mutual interests.
Recommendations 6.78, 6.79

6.78 The Committee recommends that in respect of countries such as India, which are not in Australia's area of primary strategic importance, the Australian Government should only develop a diplomatic position on their external policy or defence policy where there is a direct threat to our interests, such as that presented by nuclear proliferation, or a breach of international law. This would appear to be the practical implication of the comments of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, in a speech on priorities in Australian foreign policy when he said:

Priority in our foreign policy should be given to that which is not only important but achievable; . . . for a country of Australia's size and weight in world affairs . . . .it is not wise to have exaggerated ideas of influence beyond our station . . . .

6.79 The submission to the Committee by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was suitably modest in this respect. Nevertheless, at times the desire to lecture India on its economic and military policies appears to creep into Australian thinking. A tendency to blame the Indians for most problems in the relationship-in the absence of any real self-criticism of Australia's performance-is some indication of a disturbing sense of superiority adopted by some officials and other commentators who appeared before the Committee.
Response

The Government appreciates the recent historical factors that have helped to fashion India's perception of its strategic environment. Since Independence, India has fought a number of wars. It still has disputed borders and faces serious separatist and insurgency problems. We recognise that India must be able to protect its long coastline, its scattered island territories and its off-shore interests. India's strategic circumstances mean that it needs to maintain a certain level of military capability.

India is the major power in South Asia, and, although not of primary strategic importance to Australia, we share a common desire for peace and stability in the region. We readily acknowledge that while India's military build-up has enhanced its power projection capability in the South Asian region, this does not constitute a threat to the security of Australia or South East Asia. We would, however, emphasise the need for openness and dialogue to allay any regional concerns that may arise from time to time. The Government would encourage India in the efforts it has been making to ensure that regional countries have a full understanding of its reasons for increases or changes of pattern in its level of defence spending.
Recommendation 6.80
