QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE: RESIGNATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It was reported in yesterday's newspapers that the recently appointed Secretary to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Dr Malcolm McIntosh, has resigned after less than six months in the job and is reported to be leaving within the week. This resignation follows last week's announcement of the resignation of the Managing Director of the Australian Trade Commission, Mr Lindsay MacAlister, as well as the departures of Deputy Secretary Alan Godfrey and First Assistant Secretary Rob Palfreyman. Can the Minister inform the Senate who is actually left in his Department and, given the low-key appointment of Mr Neville Stevens yesterday as Secretary, when the two Deputy Secretary positions will be filled? Finally, will the Minister tell us whether there are any other senior resignations from his portfolio in the pipeline, including his own?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Bishop has one capacity, it is to string together a whole lot of irrelevant circumstances and turn them into a conspiracy.
—Are all your officers irrelevant?

—Irrelevant circumstances, I said. If Senator Bishop concentrated better on the meaning of the English language we would get better questions at Question Time. Senator Bishop, as I said, has this capacity to string together a whole lot of irrelevancies and turn them into a conspiracy. It is true that Dr McIntosh, the Secretary to my Department, resigned. He did so to take up a position which I think is best described as chief procurement officer for the British Department of Defence. It was known publicly and certainly to me a few weeks ago that there was speculation about that position. Dr McIntosh had discussed it with me at the time he became Secretary, but at that stage it was not considered that there would be any firm offer from the British.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom telephoned our Prime Minister about this matter earlier in the week and it was then confirmed that Dr McIntosh would be taking that job. I do not know what follows from that. I congratulate Dr McIntosh on his appointment. I think it is a very great tribute to him that he was offered such a senior position. The offer was so significant that it resulted in an exchange of telephone calls between the respective Prime Ministers.
I regret the fact that Dr McIntosh is leaving for a position in Britain and I wish him every success in his new career. With regard to the position of Mr MacAlister--

TALK.START.PARA: —And also Mr Godfrey.

—Just be a little patient. I cannot even answer this question without interruption. People are concerned about these sorts of interruptions. Yesterday, I received a letter from somebody who watches this show on television.
—More hate mail.
—If Senator Vanstone thinks it is hate mail I will read it to her. The letter states:

ANSWER.PARA: I enjoy the television coverage of Senate Question Time but there is one thing that raises my hackles-it is the constant interruptions and stupid points of order raised by Senators Bishop, Newman and Walters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—It continues:

ANSWER.PARA: Can . . . you give them a blast?
I must pay tribute to the writer because I could not have done better myself. In fairness, I ought to finish reading the letter:
Perhaps you could, at the right moment, say that the constant interruption of the opposition reminds you of a story about Bobbie Burns who, when asked for an epitaph, wrote-
Here lies the bones of Jimmy Jones and this is my opinion, the Lord never took such a blathering bitch into his dark dominion.

It goes on to say that blathering is a Gaelic word. This letter was sent to me from a country town in Queensland. I just mention it because it refers to interruptions and Senator Bishop has interjected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We are getting a bit far away from the question.

—The second person on Senator Bishop's list was Mr MacAlister of Austrade, who has indicated his intention of resigning as of 31 December, which he is quite entitled to do. I do not know what conclusions can be drawn from that.
—Just that they are baling out.

—That is a possible conclusion, but the circumstances do not support that allegation. Thirdly, Senator Bishop mentioned Mr Godfrey, a former Deputy Secretary of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce who has worked in this Department in its various guises since 1963. He went on to a new position. As I said to Mr Godfrey at the time, `There are new challenges out there which you probably might like to take', and he has taken them. He is working elsewhere in another position.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Palfreyman is being moved to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs on secondment, due to changes in positions in corporate management in various departments. It is a great tribute to Mr Palfreyman that he has been asked to move to that Department. To string all these things together and make a conspiracy out of them is an incredible exercise. I say to Senator Bishop that if she wants to ask me another question on this hit list of hers next year there will probably be a few more names.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question: I did ask the Minister when he would be filling the two Deputy Secretary positions-Mr Godfrey having gone in September and the low-key appointment of Mr Stevens to the position of Secretary having been made yesterday. I might add that the Minister said that Mr Palfreyman had gone to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs which, of course, no longer exists.

—The last point is one of pedantry at its highest. The point, in so far as it relates to my Department, is noted with a degree of indifference. The positions of Deputy Secretary will be filled as soon as possible.
—I ask whether the Minister will table the letter from the country town in Queensland from which he quoted.
—That is a matter for the Minister.
—I am quite happy to make it available to the Leader of the Opposition. I would not want any constituent who watches this show to be persecuted.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's reaction to the devastating news of the resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Shevardnadze's resignation last night at the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies was disconcerting, perhaps even devastating news, as Senator McKiernan said, both for governments around the world and apparently no less for Mr Shevardnadze's colleagues in the Soviet leadership. May I say at the outset that I feel a keen sense of personal disappointment at the news of Mr Shevardnadze's departure. I had occasion to have a number of quite substantial meetings with him over the last two years, both in the context of the United Nations and the Cambodia peace process. I, like everybody else who came to know him, found him making an extraordinary impression as an outstandingly intelligent open-minded statesman and, at the same time, someone with an enormously engaging personal charm.

ANSWER.PARA: Should Mr Shevardnadze's decision prove final, and there does appear to be only a very slim chance that it will not be, it will mean the loss from the Soviet leadership of a man who has made a very decisive contribution to forging the new cooperative East-West relationship and, indeed, a whole new global climate. In particular, he played a key role in Soviet policies which have seen the ending of Cold War confrontation in Europe, the conclusion of major arms control agreements, the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan and, most recently, the Soviet Union's support for the international condemnation of and opposition to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.

We should also recall in bilateral terms that Mr Shevardnadze was in 1987 the first Soviet Foreign Minister to visit Australia; a visit that did give great momentum to developing a more constructive and fruitful bilateral relationship with us. It should also be acknowledged what a huge contribution Mr Shevardnadze has made domestically as a key supporter of the implementation of perestroika and democratisation, and in giving very strong personal and political support to President Gorbachev.

What are the implications of his resignation? So far as foreign policy is concerned, the early indications appear to be that Mr Shevardnadze's resignation does not signal any significant departure from the foreign policy line that President Gorbachev and he have pursued in recent years. President Gorbachev has given some very explicit assurances that this will be the case and there is no reason to doubt his sincerity in that respect.

The question does, however, arise about President Gorbachev's capacity to continue to impose his will in the domestic political situation that is now unfolding. It is in respect of the domestic implications of the Shevardnadze resignation that there is, I think, occasion for some more immediate worry. Mr Shevardnadze described his resignation as a protest against the advance of dictatorship in the Soviet Union; a reference to the resurgence in recent weeks of conservative or, as Mr Shevardnadze described them, reactionary forces which are calling for decisive measures to restore order and to rein in the Soviet nationalities pushing for greater autonomy.

It is simply too early to make firm judgments about what precise impact domestically Mr Shevardnadze's resignation will have. The optimistic view is that it could act as a warning shot to galvanise the reformers. There does seem to have been at least partly an attempt by Mr Shevardnadze to do just that, by the style, forcefulness and the nature of his resignation speech. More pessimistically it could, on the other hand, signal the loss of a key reformer reflecting in this respect that conservative groups, which were seeking to pull back some of the hard won reforms of perestroika, may be gaining the ascendancy. We will just have to wait and see how this works out.

May I say, finally, that the Australian Government has welcomed the direction, obviously, of the political and economic reforms initiated under President Gorbachev which have been intimately bound up with the forging of a new cooperative relationship with the West. We hope that the strengthening of democratic processes in the Soviet Union, taking into account the legitimate aspirations of the various people inhabiting the Soviet Union, will continue. The Soviet leadership is facing enormous economic and political difficulties. While we understand the desire to ensure stability and order, we fervently hope that that will not be pursued at the expense of the progress that has been achieved in recent years, in creating a more open society with a much greater respect for human rights.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HMAS BRISBANE: DELAYS IN MAIL DELIVERIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence-it seems to me to be an appropriate question to ask on the day when the Minister and Senator Durack have been joining in the welcome of the Navy frigates HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Darwin in Sydney. Is the Minister aware of reports that sailors on the ship, HMAS Brisbane, which is currently serving in the Gulf, have not received any mail since they left Australia in early November? Can the Minister inform the Senate what action will be taken to ensure that those sailors will be able to receive some news from home before Christmas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I apologise for not being here at the immediate start of Question Time. I am aware of some concern about delays in the mail being received by sailors in the Gulf. I understand that Senator BjelkePetersen has received constituent inquiries about this. However, that part of the honourable senator's question which suggests that no mail has been received by Brisbane is not correct. After some initial problems some months ago concerning, amongst other things, Customs examination of mail in transit through other nations, a generally smooth flow of mail both ways has now been established.

ANSWER.PARA: As of yesterday, this was the situation: of 615 mail dispatches to the ships Success, Sydney and Brisbane and to the task group's medical and logistic elements, 550 dispatches have been received. Sixty-five dispatches are still in transit. Of some 85 mail dispatches from the task group back to Australia, 79 have already arrived. However, Senator Bjelke- Petersen is quite right to identify concerns about mail to HMAS Brisbane. It did suffer some bad luck. Some five bags of mail dispatched to catch the ship at Diego Garcia unfortunately arrived after that ship's departure. But at the same time I should emphasise that three-quarters of all dispatches to the Brisbane have been successfully received. Together with more recent mail sent to the Middle East, I am advised that the backlog will be cleared before Christmas-if it has not already been cleared.

The Navy places great importance on getting mail to sailors quickly and regularly. Mail from Australia is obviously important for morale; likewise, mail from the ships is naturally important to family and friends back here. The transmission of mail is a very public test of efficient organisation by the Navy and it does take the task very seriously.

I appreciate the honourable senator's interest and I can assure her that the Government shares her concern that our military personnel serving Australia far away from home should receive the highest priority for their Christmas mail from their families and friends. I would also like to thank OTC Ltd which has made available for every sailor in the Gulf a phone call home for Christmas. I should acknowledge the role of OTC in that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his very comprehensive reply to my question. I wonder, as the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, will be visiting ships in the Gulf on Sunday and Monday, could he assist the Government and deliver some of the mail that is still waiting to be delivered?

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to get Mr Charles Blunt's assistance on this. I think that would be too difficult to organise, but I do know that Mr Fischer will be taking newspapers to the sailors. One of the things that they really like to get is up-to-date newspapers and magazines as there is always a couple of weeks delay there. I know that Mr Fischer is taking that, amongst other things. I take this opportunity to wish him an enjoyable Christmas in the Gulf region and a safe journey.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Has the Minister seen the article entitled `Fair Go Sport' in the Queensland Sun which states that women's sport still suffers from not being taken seriously by the community and the media? Does the Minister agree that women's sport is trivialised by the media? Can the Minister inform honourable senators what the Government is doing to address the discrimination against women's sport in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley makes a very clear and substantiated point that women's sport has been seriously discriminated against by the Australian media. By way of evidence, if one were to--
—And by the Government. Why is not netball an elite sport?
—Does the honourable senator take anything seriously in this place, apart from himself? For example, today the Telegraph Mirror--
—Yes, I do. Why don't you take netball seriously? It is Australia's major female sport and it is not an elite sport. It is a disgrace.
—Order! There are too many interjections. I ask Senator Bolkus to ignore them and address the Chair.

— The point I was making was that Senator Crowley does make a substantiated point. I agree that women's sport has been seriously discriminated against by the Australian media. As I was about to say, for example, in today's press the Telegraph Mirror has only one article out of a total of 48 concerning women's participation in sport. The Age excels that-it has no articles out of a total of 14.
—There may have been no sport played yesterday.

—That of course may be seen to be unrepresentative in terms of no sport having been played yesterday, as Senator Tate has just said. But if one was to look at Monday's press, after a full weekend of sport there is very little difference in terms of the statistics. The Herald Sun had three articles out of 41. In fact, a major achievement was attained by Australian women in sport on the weekend but even that was ignored by most of the press. Only one of the articles I could find reported that Australian sporting achievement-that world-rated weight- lifter, Debbie Smith, had set five new Australian records on one night, despite an injury. The article was notable, on the one hand, because it was accompanied by a photograph but, on the other hand, it was buried deep in the sports pages.

ANSWER.PARA: To compare this with the coverage of male sport, all one has to do is look at the fact that Merv Hughes gets full back page coverage on all sporting pages across the nation by having his hair cut. So I think it is a fair point to make that it is time for sporting bodies and the media to stop and take a look at the way they are covering women's sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Government, too.

—As Senator Baume said, the Government as well. The second part of Senator Crowley's question does in fact go to the Government's position on this matter. As Senator Crowley would note from her involvement and interest in this area, the Government is concerned about such discrimination. We have, amongst other things, a number of measures in place to counteract this sort of discrimination. As honourable senators would know, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has received many detailed submissions concerning the disparity of funding and prize money for women's sport compared with men's sport. As part of its inquiry it will be conducting a seminar in association with the Australian Sports Commission on 27 and 28 February 1991 to look at the whole issue in detail. Quentin Bryce, the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Commissioner, has been invited to advise the Committee on the potential which exists under the Sex Discrimination Act or other legislation to remove barriers to equal opportunity in sport.

ANSWER.PARA: I must also mention the Government's national agenda for women, and that also includes an objective to promote equity in sport. Initiatives also range from educational campaigns to encourage girls to participate in sport and, of course, to discourage the high drop-out rate, to a coaching apprenticeship scheme aimed at encouraging more women to undertake coaching roles.
I know there has been some cynicism on the other side. Honourable senators opposite who think this is a lightweight or trivial issue probably do not know-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is now debating the point and I ask you to request him to bring his answer to an end.
—It is becoming a very long answer, Senator Bolkus.

— My President, it is a serious issue. In fact, once again, the time taken by Senator Kemp in raising a point of order is the time I would have taken to complete the answer. The basic point is that Australia--
—Oh, come on. Conclude your answer.
—Order!

— Can honourable senators opposite name the Sportswoman of the Year for this year-for this month in fact? In conclusion, I just want to make a point about something that Senator Crowley asserts in her question: we do call ourselves a sporting nation, but I think it is unfortunate that the only sport we see and read about is men's sport. We do have a wealth of female sporting talent and it is time that the Australian media took as much interest in women's sport as they take in Merv Hughes's mohawk.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, resume your seat.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Noting the absence of any provision for equity of access to training under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act and the lack of provision for prosecutions under the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act, I ask the Minister: firstly, is it a fact that equity measures were rejected because of the perceived negative attitude of employers towards affirmative action? If this was not the case, why were such measures rejected? Secondly, how does the Minister intend to ensure equity in training programs for all employees-including low-skilled workers, women and disadvantaged groups? Thirdly, given that women comprise 42 per cent of the work force, only 12 per cent of senior managers and yet are the fastest growing section of our work force, how does the Minister intend to ensure that male-dominated companies will offer women courses or skills designed to advance their career paths? Finally, is it a fact that the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) does not include any gender breakdown in monitoring the application of training in its surveys on employer training expenditure?
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. In view of the fact that the Minister clearly has a prepared answer, I ask that it be incorporated.
—Order! There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Powell for her question. I do have some notes in respect of the issues raised by Senator Powell. The Minister advises me that it was not considered appropriate, at the commencement of the training guarantee, to add to the legislative requirements already being placed on employers by including references to equity of access to training for women or any other group. In Mr Dawkins's second reading speech on the Training Guarantee Act, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is also concerned that low-skilled workers, women and disadvantaged labour market groups have access to training. While it has decided not to include specific training targets for such groups, it will be monitoring industry training behaviour.

It is the Government's intention to ensure that the provision of all training by employers, not just training offered under the training guarantee, is monitored to determine whether women are receiving an equitable share. We have already undertaken to review the training guarantee within four years. If it appears that women are not receiving appropriate access to training, the Minister assures me that he will take action.

Senator Powell also referred to the Australian Bureau of Statistics 1990 survey of employer training expenditure and the fact that that did not include a gender breakdown. I am informed that this was done to minimise the burden on employers, who generally do not keep records of training by gender. However, I am also informed that the ABS has conducted another very detailed survey on training received by women and other groups in the work force. The results of this survey entitled `How workers get their training' became available in July this year.

In conclusion-analysis of this survey has not shown cause for major concern about the provision of training for women but more detailed breakdowns are currently being studied and any issues which emerge will be seriously followed up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I inform the Opposition that I, and a good many women around this country, are very interested in these answers. The Minister has mentioned monitoring and further studies. Could he obtain an answer for me as to why the feasibility study-I am not sure whether that is the one that the Minister referred to-undertaken this year by the ABS examined training hours by gender but did not examine training expenditure by gender? If that is the detailed report to which the Minister referred, I ask that the Minister responsible look at that discrepancy as we need to get to that question of expenditure.
—I undertake to get a full answer to that supplementary question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's response to recent developments in South Africa, including the recent African National Congress (ANC) and public statements by the South African State President, Mr de Klerk? As a result, will there be any changes to the Government's sanctions policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that we continue to acknowledge that much has been done already and even more has been promised by the South African Government since President de Klerk made his path-breaking statement last February about a new era opening up in South Africa. We have seen, particularly over the last year, the unbanning of the ANC and other political movements, the release of key political prisoners, the return of a number of exiles, the repeal of the Separate Amenities Act and the commencement of talks.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time, in the context of examining the questions about the maintenance of sanctions pressure, it has to be appreciated just how much more remains to be done, quite apart from changing the Constitution itself, before one can really say that the process of change is genuinely irreversible. All but a handful of political prisoners still remain in gaol. The return of exiles has really only just begun. Violence in the townships, as we all unhappily know, continues unabated, while the evidence of security force complicity in that violence tends to mount. The promised review of security legislation has yet to bear fruit and the right of peaceful protest remains severely restricted. It is also the case that the most significant elements of apartheid legislation-the Lands Acts, the Group Areas Act, the Population Registration Act, not to mention again the Constitution itself-do remain on the books, although President de Klerk has undertaken to seek the repeal of the Lands Acts and the Group Areas Act when the Parliament resumes in February.

Significant further movement by the South African Government on these key issues-removing the remaining so-called obstacles to negotiations and making some further major progress on legislative change-will be very important in determining the question as to whether actual change, as distinct from intentions, has become irreversible.

So far as Australian policy is concerned, as the Prime Minister and I have constantly said, Australia is not looking to sustain our sanctions any longer than is necessary. It is important to maintain sanctions pressure as long as it is productive to do so. But as the reform momentum accelerates, we will be prepared to consider their phased relaxation. In this respect it is certainly possible to contemplate early movement on the question of academic and cultural boycotts. It is also possible to contemplate in this context movement on the sports boycott, at least in those sports which have achieved unified non-racial structures.

In assessing our position on sanctions we will continue to take into account both developments on the ground in South Africa and the views of others with whom we have been consulting closely. So far as developments on the ground are concerned we note with some interest that Dr Hewson, in his widely publicised call in the press this morning for lifting sporting sanctions, links this quite specifically to the repeal of the particular apartheid legislation that I mentioned. We also note in this respect that while the European Community has of course now lifted its voluntary ban on new investment in South Africa, it is also waiting for legislative action before implementing any further change in sanctions policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has undertaken to do so.

—Yes, I have acknowledged that, but we need to wait and see whether that undertaking is capable of realisation when the Parliament meets in February next year, and that is an important date. So far as the views of others are concerned we will continue to give great weight to the views of the Commonwealth countries with whom we have been working in the Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa, which is scheduled to meet again early next year, and we will continue to give great weight to the view of black South Africans, especially as expressed through the most representative black organisation, the ANC.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of the editorial in the Australian the other day and some other comment I have seen, to say that we will give great, or even enormous, weight to such views does not mean that Australia's views will be dictated or determined by others. As always, we make our own foreign policy decisions on the basis of balanced assessment of our own national interests.

The final point of substance is this: it is also important, as well as closely monitoring the situation in this way, that we continue to step up our political as well as diplomatic contact with both sides of the South African political equation. Nelson Mandela's visit earlier this year was significant in this regard. I am hoping to make some further substantial contact with the ANC while I am overseas in January to get a full evaluation of its present position in the light of the events of the recent national congress. The Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, Senator Schacht, who asked me this question this morning, will be in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. In recent days you have made it clear that there is at least an informal time limit on answers. I presume that has been communicated to the front bench on the other side. In a number of instances Ministers have complied with it. But today we have seen two flagrant breaches of that informal arrangement. I ask you to take some action to ensure that it is properly enforced.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Evans had not reached the unofficial limit, but it is becoming a very long answer.

—I acknowledge that, Mr President. I had thought that it was a matter of some interest to both sides of the chamber. I have very little more to say. I am about to conclude. I wanted to make the point that it is important, I believe, to gradually develop political contact with both sides of the equation. In that respect, as I was saying, Senator Schacht will be in South Africa in the next couple of months, at a time of great importance, as the South African Parliament resumes in February. He will be meeting a broad cross-section of political opinion and he will be doing so with the blessing of the Government. Depending on progress, even higher level visits may follow.

ANSWER.PARA: Just finally, may I say that Australia, along with the rest of the international community, will be keenly following events in South Africa in the next few months, especially after the reconvening of the South African Parliament. It is my sincere hope that during that session of parliament we will witness reforms that will allow us to say finally that apartheid is dead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will the Government be removing the luxury car sales tax, as speculated upon in this morning's press?

—The answer to that question is no. There is no consideration of removing the luxury sales tax. In the light of that speculative piece in the Australian this morning, I have put out a press release to that effect this morning.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WAR CRIMES (CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY) AMENDMENT BILL

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave under standing order 72 to ask Senator Peter Baume a question relating to his private member's Bill listed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the honourable senator tell the Senate what he hopes to achieve by proposing the War Crimes (Crimes Against Humanity) Amendment Bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The general obligations of Australians not to commit war crimes is covered by the Geneva Conventions Act 1957, specifically by the provisions of the fourth convention of that Act. That was assented to by this Parliament some time ago. But it seems appropriate that any one living in this country who may have committed a war crime-against whom an allegation exists-should be capable of being subject to the law of Australia. The Geneva Conventions Act is not sufficient on its own to pick up all of the people who might be so accused.

ANSWER.PARA: The War Crimes Amendment Act 1988, which was passed by this Parliament, was very limited in its scope, applying only to particular war crimes in a particular theatre between particular years. I can see no reason in logic or propriety why there should be any limitation on our search for war criminals or in our pursuit of those alleged to have committed war crimes. This amendment Bill proposes that any person, anywhere, at any time who has committed any war crime should be subject to the provisions of the War Crimes Amendment Act.

I might just add that the War Crimes Act is, at the present time, subject to challenge in the High Court of Australia as to its constitutionality. It would obviously be inappropriate to proceed to amend that Act until the High Court has come down with a judgment. The High Court will probably not bring down its judgment until the end of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not then.
—The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs might assist me.
—Not until next year.

—When that judgment comes down, we will know whether the War Crimes Act is constitutionally sound. If it is constitutionally sound, it would be my hope that someone in this place might look again at this amending Bill which I have proposed. If there is agreement with me that there should be no limitation on the pursuit of war criminals, someone may wish to reactivate that Bill.

—My question is to the Minister for Defence. I refer to this morning's report that senior organisational and parliamentary members of the left wing faction of the Australian Labor Party, including Senator Bruce Childs, Mrs Jeanette McHugh, Mr Stewart West, Mr Frank Walker and Mr Colin Hollis, have placed an advertisement to appear in tomorrow's Sydney Morning Herald effectively rejecting the United Nations resolution on the 15 January deadline and advocating that Australia does not send troops into a Gulf conflict. Does this further demonstration of disunity within the Government Party in Australia again undermine the unity that Australia should be presenting to Iraq and to the international community? What further steps will the Minister take to address this campaign by his colleagues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I would love to be able to read tomorrow's Sydney Morning Herald. I would probably read today's race results first before I went on to read the rest of the paper. There are all sorts of hopeless assumptions in Senator Hill's question. First, he asked me to postulate on something that I have not seen and that he alleges will appear tomorrow. Secondly, what does he mean by the word `troops'? If by `troops' Senator Hill means sending in the Australian Army to that region, I am fully in accord with my colleagues.

ANSWER.PARA: In the statement by the Prime Minister, which was backed up by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and myself, we said that we regard our current commitment to the Gulf as commensurate with our world role. It should be no higher and, in our judgment, it should be no less than that. Some of my colleagues are saying-and I reflect their views-that they do not want a conflict in the Gulf.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you sign the letter then?

—Sign a letter I have not seen yet which will be in tomorrow's paper? I thank Senator Alston! His breadth of vision is so staggering that he can see into the future by a day. Is that not absolutely terrific!
—It is reported today. It is in today's press.

—Something is reported in today's paper. Good gracious me! I am supposed to take that as absolute fact. Which of the articles in today's papers am I supposed to say is true or false? I would much prefer, having read tomorrow's paper, to make the appropriate comment. One of the factors in formulating this Government's views, and one which has always been in the Australian Labor Party-we are in our ninety-ninth year-is that we do not have zombie-like uniform views as do those opposite. One thing that we do agree on-Opposition senators can go right down this bench and right around the rest-is that in the end we make collective decisions. In the end we stick by them. All my colleagues have a right to input into that decision making process. There is no absolute wisdom sitting here or sitting there or anywhere else.

—Senator Evans can dissent on that all he likes but that is the fact. As a political party, we draw our advice, our views and our policies from a far wider region than do those opposite. The basic modus operandi of the Liberal Party of Australia is to elect a leader every couple of years and to give that leader a form of papal infallibility. The rest of the Opposition members toady and grovel to that leader so that they can get their shadow Cabinet positions, or not. The successful applicants are sitting on the front bench; the unsuccessful ones are sitting behind them. Arthur Calwell once said that the only two places where people do not have arguments or disagreements in this world-and this is no longer true-are in the cemetery and in the Liberal Party. But the Liberal Party arguments are always on personality and power, never on policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the wage-tax trade-off agreed by the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions provides for tax cuts which, with the tax cuts proposed in the 1990-91 Budget, come into effect on 1 January? Can the Minister advise the Senate what the wage equivalent increase will be from 1 January to persons on average weekly earnings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, in 10 days' time the Australian Government will cut taxes for all income earners in Australia. They will benefit by receiving that tax cut. It means that their household disposable income will increase or-to put it another way-pay packets will get fatter without imposing any costs on employers. It will be of benefit on both sides of the fence.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two elements to the tax cuts. The first is that a substantial tax cut was announced in the Budget this year. Then, of course, about four weeks ago we announced a wage-tax trade-off which added to the amount of tax cut that is being provided.

I am asked in the question to provide some illustration of the advantages the tax cuts will offer at average weekly earnings. A person on average weekly earnings would be on an annual income of $24,756. That person will receive a tax cut of $9.80. The wage equivalent of that-the wage that an employer would have had to pay had he paid a wage to that real purchasing power value-would have been $18.40. It amounts to a 3.5 per cent increase. A person on a full adult average weekly earnings with two children-according to annual income figures-would be on $30,012. The value of that person's tax cut is $12.20. The wage equivalent of that would have been $20.10. That is, again, equal to a 3.5 per cent increase in wages. As we can see, the tax cuts are of substantial benefit to people on ordinary incomes.

Because of the wage-tax trade-off, there is effectively for central wage fixing in Australia a 12-months wages pause. It means as well that aggregate wage outcomes for the year are down from 7 per cent to 6.25 per cent; that we are likely to undershoot our inflation target of 6 per cent; that we have in place an inflation circuit-breaker; and that living standards are being maintained while purchasing power is being increased.

This stands in stark contrast to the stated policy of the Opposition to introduce a consumption tax. According to the figures I have, a consumption tax of 15 per cent would impose an extra $12.2 billion tax surcharge on ordinary Australians without any indication of what compensatory mechanisms there might be.

We are, in fact, lowering the tax take. The Opposition, by contrast, has a policy which is very cloudy but the effect of which is to fuel inflation, push inflation rates right up and impose a higher tax on ordinary Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the Burkegate cover-up. Will the Minister examine the following documents which show prima facie evidence of improper conduct of the Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, during and after his term as Premier of Western Australia, to determine whether he should be recalled and his appointment suspended during the royal commission into WA Inc., which is due to commence early next year? The documents I would like him to look are: the Hansard of the Legislative Assembly of the Western Australian Parliament dated 18 November 1987; an extract from the minutes of the State Government Insurance Commission board meeting in November 1987; the McCusker report of the inquiry into Rothwells Ltd; statements by the former Rothwells director, Mr David Hurley, tabled in the Western Australian Parliament; the blue `Govt' file; a detailed article on the blue file in the Sunday Times of 2 December; transcripts of evidence to the McCusker inquiry by David Hurley; the letter of 16 December 1987 from the National Companies and Securities Commission formalising the suspension of the Rothwells investigation; and, finally, the report of Estimates Committee E, April 1989, containing advice from the Attorney-General's Department in relation to Burke's involvement in the suspension of the NCSC investigation into Rothwells.
—No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. On Monday, in answer to a question from Senator Beahan, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia has some particular strengths in liquid waste treatment, membrane technology, bioremediation and sensing equipment.
He went on to praise the support his Department has given to this technology, of which he said:
. . . one of the priority fields being considered in the multifunction polis feasibility study.

What tangible support has the Minister's Department given to these Australian developed waste management technologies? If Australia has already shown itself capable of developing innovative and globally needed technology in this important area, is a foreign dominated multifunction polis (MFP) really necessary to further these sorts of developments? Is it not very likely that the imposition of an MFP will see these and other technologies taken offshore by foreign, rather than Australian, companies? Finally, would it not be wiser to spend the $2.6 billion marked for Government spending on MFP infrastructure on properly and more comprehensively supporting the proven cleverness of indigenous Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another question out of the shed at the bottom of the garden. It is not a fairy at the bottom of the garden, but a shed. There are a number of parts to this question. I do not have any answer because of the notice which Senator Coulter did not give me.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to part one of the question, we have established a generic technology committee through the Grants Committee of the Industry Research and Development Board and declared waste management a generic technology. We have conducted a number of seminars with various companies and researchers in relation to these issues. It is, of course, an embryonic industry in Australia but there are some very good companies involved.

It is important, in dealing with the second part of the question, to make the point that this whole industry is a growing one around the world. The multifunction polis is not necessary in order to develop these industries, but it could be a very useful vehicle as environmental management issues have been seen as a key feature of the MFP and have been discussed with other governments as a potential area of Australian strength.

Is it likely that these technologies will be taken offshore? I hope so-but in the hands of Australian companies. Certainly, I think it would be sensible if they were taken offshore by Australian companies in collaboration with overseas companies, because that is the best way to do business in the international marketplace. With regard to the reference to $2.6 billion marked for government spending on MFP infrastructure, there is no such sum marked for government expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Do I understand the Minister to be saying that the MFP is not necessary for the development of these technologies, which he has identified as very important ones? Secondly, in light of his own Department's economic analysis of the MFP, I repeat: would it not be wiser to spend this $2.6 billion which has been earmarked for MFP infrastructure on supporting those Australian industries which have, in his own words, proven to be world class and capable of being taken offshore to the benefit of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter is making a bit of a farce of Question Time, if he does not mind my saying so. He has just asked me a question. I said that there was no $2.6 billion earmarked for spending on infrastructure, then he repeats the allegation. If he came in here at Question Time to seriously ask questions, rather than stunting as he does-he is just a stunt merchant-he would listen to the answer. But he does not seem to be capable of listening to the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the first part of the question is concerned, yes, I said that the MFP is not necessary for the development of these technologies. I said, however, that it would be desirable because scientific research on topics of this kind is best carried out on an internationally collaborative basis. That is the view of the Government. If Senator Coulter has some spooky theories to the contrary, I have no doubt he will articulate them in some forum of his own.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and concerns Cambodia. I refer to reports published this week, based on confidential documents from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, including documents from the British and the Americans, which assess the Khmer Rouge as growing in strength, not only militarily but also politically, and give a pessimistic assessment for the peace process in Cambodia. I also refer to three recent statements by the Minister himself which are entirely contrary. According to Hansard on 6 December, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is no prospect of an early military takeover by the Khmer Rouge.
On the World Today program on 1 November, he said:
The Khmer Rouge can't be more than a marginal player-a marginal nuisance.
According to Hansard on 13 October, with reference to Cambodia, he said:
. . . the international community . . . not place too much emphasis on transient alarums and diversions,
If the Minister's own Department has assessed the Khmer Rouge as growing in strength, is he not misleading Parliament by insisting that the Khmer Rouge does not pose a serious threat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague was nice to me just before Question Time about India so I will forbear from giving him the monstrous serve that I am being invited to give him by my colleagues. I will just say, with as much patience as I can muster, that Senator Teague once again seems to have misunderstood both the situation in Cambodia and the way in which we have been responding to it. The essence of the situation is simply this: the Khmer Rouge, presently supplied as they are by China, are a significant influence on the ground in Cambodia--
—It is not a marginal player.
— I will come to that. Senator Alston is a source of difficulty to us all.
—It was better than your last effort.

— It was; it is Christmas. The situation is that they are capable of causing considerable difficulty, militarily and politically, in the environment as it presently exists in Cambodia. Although they have not hitherto been able to sustain more than hit and run guerilla attacks and have not had the capacity to seize and hold large tracts of territory or particular provincial towns; nonetheless, there is cause for concern in the longer run about an increase in Khmer influence-perhaps even ultimately a Khmer Rouge takeover of the country-particularly if there were to be an accompanying collapse of morale, discipline or order of administration, in Phnom Penh. Those two factors have to happen together and in a number of statements that I have made, I have indicated the complex balancing between those considerations.

ANSWER.PARA: What I have said about the marginal influence of the Khmer Rouge is simply this: if China can be persuaded-as seems certain in the context of a comprehensive settlement being reached but which is not at all clear and, in fact, is extremely unlikely if a comprehensive settlement strategy cannot be reached-to withdraw its support from the Khmer Rouge and withdraw from the situation on the ground then there is every prospect, and I say this with complete confidence, that the Khmer Rouge will be reduced to the status of a marginal isolated player. This will not happen immediately because they have got access to significant arms caches which will probably keep them going and making a considerable nuisance of themselves, as I have said, for another two or three years, but, in the longer run, there is a very strong intelligence basis for the assessment that they will be reduced to marginal status if that external arms supply source dries up. It is that combination of factors which explains the various quotes. If they are read in full in context, they are all entirely consistent with each other.

May I make the point just once more that I am perfectly happy to debate the pros and cons, the virtues, the difficulties, of the United Nations (UN) peace plan we have crafted and which is now accepted by the United Nations and, in effect, by all the relevant players. I am perfectly prepared to consider viable alternatives to that if there is any other way of achieving peace-an end to the civil war and the removal of the awful spectre of a resumption of Khmer Rouge authority. But I have to say that, for whatever reason, the Opposition has not, nor has anyone else, produced a credible alternative plan which will have the result, in particular, of taking all the external players, and in particular China, out of the situation. The substance of my very carefully expressed statement in this place on 6 December was just that.

We fear very much that any solution other than the UN comprehensive plan approach will be a recipe for civil war and endless ongoing disaster in Cambodia. That is why we believe that instead of being distracted by will-o'-the-wisps and bits and pieces of other ideas that the Opposition might have from time to time, it should focus its attention and support behind that comprehensive plan and help us achieve it and put it in place internationally-the state of affairs in Cambodia at this time is very delicately poised-instead of going on in the way it continues to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Given the Minister's answer that repudiates the severest interpretation of his earlier statements, does he acknowledge now that there is a danger that the Australian Government sponsored peace plan may in fact have the danger of locking in a balance of power which will result in a triumph for the Khmer Rouge?
—I do not, for all the reasons I have very carefully, and at great length, spelt out in the statement on 6 December and on innumerable other occasions over the course of the last 12 months.

—I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Will the Minister tell the Senate what the Government will be doing in response to the report of the National Committee on Violence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that the Committee on Violence was set up by the Prime Minister and Premiers as a result of the Hoddle and Queen Street massacres to try to find what were the cultural reasons underlying the prevalence of violence in Australian society. As a result that distinguished committee made several recommendations, most of which have certainly been accepted very readily by the Commonwealth Government. As to the immediate cause of the inquiry-those terrible massacres in Hoddle and Queen Streets-the question of gun control was looked at.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the recommendations of the Committee was that semi-automatic quasi-military style weapons ought to be banned-ought not be allowed to be imported to Australia-and regulations to give effect to that particular recommendation were brought into effect yesterday. But, as to the more fundamental underlying causes of violence in our society, the most horrifying statistic in that particular report was that when one looked at the age groups most vulnerable to homicide in Australia, it was not the young thugs and hoons between 18 and 22 who might be involved in some sort of criminal violence or brawls or whatever; it was not the fragile elderly who might be hit over the head by an intruder; far and away, the age group most vulnerable to homicide in Australia are those between zero and one year of age-by far.

It is quite clear that the household-the home that ought to be the haven and refuge from violence in our society-is for many Australians the place where they experience and learn about violence and, therefore, the Federal Government's major response to this report has instituted parent skills training centres. Four pilot schemes were established yesterday around Australia. I believe that we should try to get to those vulnerable families and help them with their parenting skills, particularly where an abused child becomes a parent and, therefore, is in danger of abusing his or her children, as it is shown that this violence goes on generation after generation. Where people do not have a particular role model that they can draw on we believe that this scheme of helping in these parenting skills projects will be a helpful contribution to changing the culture of violence in our society.

There are many other recommendations of the Committee which commend themselves to the Federal Government. I believe they also commend themselves to State and other organisations, including community and voluntary organisations. There is a chance now that over the next decade or so we can change the culture of our society to make it less prone to violence-less tolerant to violence-and a better place for our fellow Australians to grow up.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the Minister's response to a question from Senator Childs yesterday concerning Mr Uren's refutation of the Minister's charge that he, Mr Uren, regularly briefed former Prime Minister Fraser on the internal divisions within the Labor Party. Given that the Minister's charge was made in this chamber on 12 December and that Mr Uren has now had his refuting statement incorporated in Hansard, does the Minister believe that it is proper for this most serious matter and these charges and counter charges to remain unaddressed by the Minister until next February, as he indicated yesterday?
—Leave him swinging.

—Of course, there are a number of other charges left swinging that Mr Uren has in effect made against the Prime Minister, Senator Evans and me-that is, that we are guilty of undemocratic practices, that we are warmongers, et cetera. In answer to Senator Childs's question yesterday I said that the most appropriate time for me to deal with it in the chamber would be at the first available opportunity when the Privileges Committee report comes up. It appears, from looking at the Privileges report and what Mr Uren has to say there, that only one word of what I said is in question and I will give that due consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 December, Senator Watson asked me a question, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, regarding company tax. I have now received a response from the Treasurer. It is quite a long response and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: 1. As previously announced, any company which is not able to pay on time should contact the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) so that the Office can determine whether to extend the time for payment or to allow the company to pay by instalments.

A company approaching the ATO for an extension will have to satisfy the Commissioner that it is appropriate for him to exercise his discretion under Section 206 of the Act to grant such extension of time ``as he considers the circumstances warrant''.
The Act also provides a discretion to the Commissioner to remit the penalty imposed by the Act for late payment.
The Commissioner has set out guidelines for the exercise of those discretions in Income Tax Rulings IT 2569 and 2570.
Those rulings make it clear that the guidelines are provided to assist the exercise of the discretion, and are not taken as in any way restricting the exercise of the discretion.
Discretions, by their very nature, must be exercised according to the facts of each case and the judgements of the person exercising the discretion.

Nevertheless, the rulings provide guidelines which assist taxpayers in understanding how discretions will, in general, be exercised. It is clearly inappropriate for extensions to be given lightly, as the ATO should not be capable of being used as a lending institution.

The Commissioner's rulings indicate that, generally, a taxpayer does have to satisfy the Commissioner that insufficient funds are available to fully discharge the debt, or that payment would cause financial hardship, and that all avenues for obtaining the necessary funds have been exhausted.

However, the rulings also indicate that short term extensions, which might be required at short notice, or for only a very short time, may be provided where the Commissioner is satisfied that reasonable grounds are furnished, with closer examination being required where longer extensions are sought.

Where business operations are involved, the guidelines indicate that additional factors to consider include, but are not limited to, whether the difficulties which caused the inability to pay the debt are not permanent, and whether the business has good prospects of successfully trading out of its difficulties.

Different companies may face different financial problems and the Taxation Office will need to consider each application on a case by case basis and on its merits in order to determine the term of the extension and the amount of late payment penalty to apply, if any.
Notwithstanding an inability to pay, companies are still required to lodge returns.

2. Generally, any arrangement that extends the due date will incur a penalty of 20 per cent per annum until full payment is made. However, the Commissioner of Taxation has limited discretion under section 207 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to remit all or part of the late payment penalties imposed. The guidelines for remission of late payment penalty are outlined in Income Tax Ruling IT 2570.

In that ruling it is a requirement for the taxpayer to demonstrate that the delay in payment was caused by specific factors which affected the cash flow and the taxpayer has taken reasonable steps to mitigate those circumstances to minimise the delay in payment. Factors beyond the control of the taxpayer may include strikes, unforeseen collapse of a major debtor or sudden ill-health of key personnel in a small business.

Mitigating steps may include a budget reorganisation to counteract the reduction in cash flow, attempts to raise additional funds from financial institutions and action by the taxpayer to protect the financial position where money is owed to the taxpayer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Herron asked me a question concerning minimum pricing policy in relation to Amoxil. I seek leave to incorporate an answer provided to me. I will check on one other aspect of the answer which Senator Herron has notified to me.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday Senator Herron asked me a question about the alleged unavailability of some brands of the antibiotic Amoxycillin.
Firstly, let me stress that the Government introduced a minimum pricing policy not a generic prescribing policy.

This policy is intended primarily to increase price competition amongst manufacturers with the objective of making substantial and ongoing savings to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) through increased incentives for manufacturers to offer lower prices:
thus addressing the concerns raised by manufacturers about the lack of price competition.
In relation to Amoxycillin, only the Amoxil brand of syrups have a premium. The tablets are not affected.
For the Amoxycillin range, Amoxil brand is the only brand which attracts a premium and prescribers have the choice of three alternative brands at the benchmark price.
One of these alternatives is Moxacin and the prescribing of this or any other brand is a matter for the medical practitioner.
Pensioners if prescribed Amoxil have to pay an additional 88 cents not the $27.00 referred to by Senator Herron.
The alternative brands are available at the base price and in the case of pensioners this will be $2.50.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few days ago Senator Parer asked me a question raising unsubstantiated allegations and innuendo about the Transport and Storage Group. I have an answer for him now and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Furniture removals are arranged on a national basis by the Transport and Storage Group of the Department of Administrative Services through a contract and business arrangement involving an approved panel of removalists.

Entry to the panel is obtained by meeting specific criteria and providing evidence of being able to meet particular standards stipulated by the Department. Currently there are some 100 approved contractors who undertake removals on an Australia-wide basis.

For each removal in a particular state quotes are invited from all eligible panellists and a contract is awarded with the lowest price being the common determinant. The exception to this might be, for example, where there are some reservations, at a particular time, about a removalist's ability to conduct a removal in accordance with the Department's requirements.

Consistent with the Department's conditions of contract and business arrangements the quoting process provides for all approved panellists to compete for work in a particular state each time a removal is required. The allocation of work flows from this process after quotes have been considered by contracts staff in the Transport &Storage Group on a lowest price basis. The Department monitors prices on a continual basis and is able to readily obtain state by state comparisons.

Where there are indications of excessive prices being quoted or noticeable price increases it is taken up with the removals industry and the National Furniture Removers' Association (NFRA) which forms part of the Australian Road Transport Federation.

The NFRA is a representative industry body which the Department co-operates with at the national level in its removals business dealings. Recently, there has been cause to register concerns with the NFRA about price increases, although at this time of the year the normal trend has been for prices to increase.

With regard to the probability of a cartel operating in Brisbane and south-east Queensland the Department has no evidence to support such an allegation. If any information became available the NFRA would be informed and an explanation sought. The consequences would be severe if contractors were involved in such a process.

MINISTER REPRESENTING THE MINISTER FOR ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 18 December 1990, Senator the Hon. Peter Walsh asked a question without notice relating to the funding by the Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia of legal actions by both Mr Robert Bropho and Mr Corrie Bodney. I undertook to obtain additional information from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and to provide this to Senator Walsh.

ANSWER.PARA: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has now provided me with information in response to the Senator's question. I am advised that the former Department of Aboriginal Affairs provided a special grant of $50,000 to the Aboriginal Legal Service in 1989/90 to enable an appeal to be taken to the High Court of Australia concerning the future of the old Swan Brewery in Perth. The Commission has not been able to determine, in the time available, the exact amount expended in representing particular litigants in this legal action. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will, however, write to Senator Walsh providing these details.

The Commission was able to determine, however, that Messrs Bropho and Bodney were represented in the legal action as a result of funding provided through the Aboriginal Legal Service, although they were not opposing litigants but joint plaintiffs. Separate representation was considered appropriate as each party had a legitimate interest in the legal action and there was conflict between Mr Bropho and Mr Bodney. Both Mr Bropho and Mr Bodney were represented in court for one day.

The Aboriginal Legal Service is an independent body and is able to commence or defend actions which it considers to be in the interests of its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander clients. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission provides funding to the Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia and these funds must only be expended within guidelines. The Commission does not believe that the funding guidelines were, in any way, breached as a consequence of providing legal representation for either Mr Bropho or Mr Bodney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the implications for Australia of reform in the Soviet Union together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The inquiry into the effect on Australia of the political and economic reform in the Soviet Union has taken place at a time of extraordinary change and turbulence in the Soviet Union and in its constituent republics. Without question, these and the equally dramatic changes in eastern Europe over the past year mark a turning point in twentieth century history. In my forward to the report I refer to the volatile situation in the Soviet Union and the possibility of new unexpected events occurring there. Of course, we had the unexpected event yesterday of the resignation from office of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Mr Shevardnadze.

The changes in the Soviet Union will have major implications for the rest of the world, including Australia. The Senate Committee believed it was important for the Australian Government to reassess its position in relation to the changes; hence, the inquiry was initiated by the Senate Standing Committee.

The report is based on 45 submissions from government departments, business people, academics and other interested members of the public. Among the witnesses were the then Soviet Ambassador to Australia, Dr Samoteikin, Dr Abel Agenbegyan, a senior adviser to President Gorbachev on economic matters, and Mr Gennadi Gerasimov, a USSR Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman.

The Committee decided to divide its recommendations into two groups-namely, security and economics. The Committee concluded that Australia should make the most of the opening up of the Soviet economy and seek to develop closer economic ties with that country.

In the Committee's view the Soviet Union has enormous economic potential. Just how quickly that potential is realised will have important implications for Australia. The Committee believes that Australia has much to offer the Soviet Union in terms of providing agricultural, mining and management expertise. Further trade opportunities could be developed through credit arrangements in addition to those which exist for wool and meat.

The report also recommends improved communication between Australian government departments and the Australian business community so that local businesses can be kept informed of possible trade and development opportunities as they occur in the Soviet Union.

In immediate terms, the report recommends that the Australian Government provide food to the Soviet Union to help overcome its crippling food shortages. The Committee believes that the assistance should not be a handout but a transaction in the form of favourable terms of credit. The arrangement should, however, be made on the proviso that the Soviet Government not use force or economic blockades to deal with republics that want greater autonomy.

In respect of security issues, the Committee has recommended that Australia review its security position to go beyond the Defence White Paper of 1987 and the December 1989 statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on regional security. This recommendation reflects the Committee's conclusion that the world has entered a post-Cold War environment with ramifications that go well beyond the European theatre.

The Committee believes that Australia should be working with the Soviet Union to improve the security of the Asia-Pacific region. Specifically, the Committee believes that the Australian Government should continue to press for multilateral dialogue on security issues for the whole region and that such talks should include the Soviet Union. Also the Committee recommends that the overall level of armaments in the Asia-Pacific region should be discussed as a regional issue.

Finally, we suggest that Australia could act as a regional negotiator to reduce the risk of nuclear proliferation in the Asia-Pacific region by bringing together the three nuclear powers with interests in this region. We will watch with great interest the historic endeavour of the people of the Soviet Union to create a new social, economic and political structure. We urge our Government to seriously consider the report's recommendations which the Committee believes will help Australia meet the challenges of these new times.
I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The main recommendations of the report are:
SECURITY ISSUES

1. A Cabinet review of Australia's strategic environment to supplement, and go beyond the Defence White Paper of 1987 and the Foreign Minister's December 1989 statement on regional security. This recommendation reflects the Committee's conclusion that the world has now entered a post-cold war environment with ramifications that go well beyond the European theatre.

2. That the Australian Government should also continue to press for regular processes of multi-lateral dialogue on security issues for the whole Asia-Pacific region. The USSR should be a part of this regional process-it has legitimate interests in the region and legitimate aspirations to be part of this region's efforts to promote its economy.
3. That the overall level of armaments in the Asia-Pacific region should be the subject of regional discussions.

4. Regarding possible nuclear proliferation, Australia as consistently supported initiatives to achieve a global nuclear non-proliferation regime. In line with this approach, the Committee recommends the review should thoroughly explore what measures Australia might take to reduce the risk of nuclear proliferation in the region, particularly on the Korean peninsula and by Taiwan. More specifically the review should examine what scope there might be for Australia to act as a facilitator in bringing the three nuclear powers with a direct interest in the issue in the region, namely the United States, the Soviet Union and China together to address the issue.
TRADE ISSUES

5. That more effective channels of communication and a greater flow of information be established between government assessment agencies and departments, and the Australian business community. The objective should be to establish an active program for the regular dissemination of assessments on the USSR to important user groups within the community.

6. That the Australian Government, in collaboration with private business, seek to establish a high-level joint working group, comprising both Australian and Soviet Government representatives, business people and academics. Such a committee should analyse the evolving economic situation and identify potential trade and investment projects. Representatives of USSR Republics should also be included in the joint process as necessary to deal with specific issues of direct interest to Australian business in individual republics.

7. That credit arrangements (in addition to those already negotiated for wool and wheat) be considered for potentially significant Australian exports to the Soviet Union for the immediate future. These arrangements should not be confined to the Central Soviet authorities but should also be extended to individual republics.

8. There is scope for considerable expansion in Australian exports of technology and scientific expertise to the Soviet Union, particularly in the agricultural and mining sectors. In pursuing these opportunities the Committee recommends that particular attention be given to joint venture possibilities including third parties such as Korean companies.

9. With regard to the high levels of controls still applied under COMCOM, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government work actively to ease the restrictions further in order to open up new trade opportunities for Australian exporters of high technology goods and services to the Soviet Union. An important opportunity to do so will be at the forthcoming meeting of COMCOM in early 1991.

10. That the decline in Australian university resources devoted to Russian studies be halted, and preferably reversed. One avenue would be for the representatives on the joint working groups proposed above, to explore ways of developing, along with private business, a long-term program for a steady increase in Russian studies in Australia. In addition, a student or senior scholar exchange with specific institutions in the Soviet Union, preferably both in Moscow and in the Soviet far east, should be established.

11. That members of ethnic communities in Australia with origins in the Soviet Union be encouraged to use their natural advantages, such as knowledge of language, to establish business contact with the Soviet Union and with its constituent republics. In particular, efforts should be made to remove obstacles, including any limiting regulations, and to facilitate such contacts.

12. The Soviet Union is desperately short of expertise to manage the transition to a market economy. The Committee recommends that the Australian Government draw the attention of Australian business to the possible benefits to be gained from offering management training to senior executives of their potential or existing business partners in the Soviet Union.

13. That Australia's aviation authorities and Qantas should consider the potential trade and tourism benefits that would flow from further expanding agreements allowing Aeroflot to operate charter flights and to establish regular services, together with reciprocal opportunities for Qantas in the Soviet Union.

14. The report notes the range of bilateral agreements signed by Australia and the Soviet Union at the time of Prime Minister Ryhzkov's visit in early 1990. The Committee recommends that there should be a sustained effort to implement those agreements and not allow them to gather dust. In particular, scientific exchanges in the area of monitoring major environmental changes such as ozone depletion and the greenhouse effect should be encouraged.

15. That the Australian Government look at a possible mechanism for involving the USSR in the Asia Pacific economic cooperation (APEC) process. At a minimum, it should ensure that the USSR is kept informed on the APEC progress. Consideration might, in the first instance, be given to some form of observer or other partial membership status for the USSR.

16. The Committee recommends that particular attention be given to devising effective means for Australia to contribute to international efforts to provide food to the USSR during the coming critical months. In line with the approach being considered by the countries of the European Community and Canada, such assistance should not be a hand-out but a commercial transaction in the form of favourable terms of credit. At the same time it should be made clear to the Soviet Government that the use of force, including imposing economic blockades, in dealing with the wish of some of the republics for greater autonomy, is unacceptable.
