The document read as follows-
Mr President
The two reports I have tabled today are a report on Finance Minutes of the Public Accounts Committee and a report of the Committee's activities for the year 1989-90.
Finance Minutes

The Committee's Report 306 on Finance Minutes contains the formal responses to reports of the Committee which were received by the Committee during 1990. The responses deal with a variety of issues including the Management of the Antarctic Division, Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports, the Engagement of External Consultants by Commonwealth Departments, Safety Principles for Explosives and the Commonwealth's Offsets Program.

The presentation of this report is a means of making available to the Parliament and to other interested persons the responses to recommendations made by the Committee in its reports. The fact that the Committee has presented these responses in this report does not mean that the Committee will not examine them in greater detail in the future and it certainly does not indicate any reduction in the importance with which the Committee views its formal response process which is known as the Finance Minute process.

The Committee believes that the overall process of accountability is aided by the prompt tabling of Finance Minutes. This gives parliamentarians and the public an opportunity to comment on the adequacy or otherwise of the responses by Departments to particular concerns and recommendations of the Committee.
Report of Activities 1989-90

The second report I have tabled, Report 307, is a report of the activities of the Committee for the year 1989-90. The primary purpose of this report is to inform the Parliament of the Committee's activities.

The report deals with the work of the Sixteenth Committee of the Public Accounts, which was chaired by the Honourable Member for Hughes, The Hon R E Tickner, MP, and also with the work of the current Committee.

Of great interest to the Committee during the year were the presentation to the Parliament of responses by both the Government and the Auditor-General to the Committee's Report 296, The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and the Parliament, Reform of the Australian Audit Office.

I am heartened by the number of recommendations in Report 296 that have received a favourable response from both the Government and the Auditor-General. I note that both the Audit Office and the Department of Finance have begun working on drafting instructions for new legislation recommended by the Committee to replace the existing Audit Act.

As the reports tabled by the Committee in 1989 covered a wide range of subjects, so too do the Committee's current inquiries. They include the Business Migration Program, annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities, Defence's supply computer systems, research and development in the public and private sectors, an account set up in relation to the Parliamentary Information Systems Office and the social responsibilities of Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises. With each of these inquiries there is a focus on issues of accountability and value for money.

On behalf of the Committee I would like to acknowledge, with great appreciation, the contribution made to its work by the members of the Committee Secretariat and the Committee's advisers. Additionally, we thank all those who gave assistance during the year, particularly officers from the Department of Finance and the Australian National Audit Office.
In conclusion, I would like to say that I enjoy the work of the Public Accounts Committee but it is a hard working Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend these reports to the Senate. I suspect that many people outside the Joint Committee of Public Accounts do not really appreciate the significant amount of time devoted to the Public Accounts Committee work. The dedication of contribution made by members of the Committee over so many years has greatly enhanced the public accountability of the Commonwealth activities. I commend these reports to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) tabled a statement in the Senate headed `Annual Statement on the Aid Program 1990'. This is a new initiative. It is a response by the Government to a report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommending such a course of action. As I was then a member of the Committee and part of that recommendation, I obviously welcome the statement as an addition to the public debate on the aid program.

SPEECH.PARA: As the statement has only just been made available, my comments today will be brief, but I hope that in the next year there will be opportunities to debate in more depth the Australian aid program. It is, of course, a significant part of the Budget-$1.3 billion. It is the subject of continuing debate in the community both as to the quantum and quality and as to the direction of the aid program. It is interesting to note that many Australians, apart from contributing to this through their taxes, also individually make donations to non-government aid organisations. I think it was suggested that over one million Australians make such donations and, therefore, it is a matter of interest and concern to the community.

I will be brief and make only a couple of points on this occasion. The first is in relation to the Minister's statement concerning policy dialogue. This statement gives some prominence to policy dialogue, suggesting that it will be given an increased emphasis. Papua New Guinea (PNG) is cited as the first major priority for increased attention to policy dialogue. The view of the Opposition is that this is appropriate, and we believe in the importance of PNG to Australia. The fact that PNG has long been the biggest recipient of Australian aid funds indicates the importance of looking at PNG in this upgraded attitude of policy dialogue.

I am a little surprised, I have to concede, because I asked the Minister in an Estimates committee hearing only a couple of months ago about the part of policy dialogue, that is, trying to influence policy outcomes at the recipient end. I asked him what the position of the Government was, and the reply came back:

There is a certain ritual quality that ought to be noted about a number of these incandatory paragraphs that appear from year to year and stay on the word processor from year to year. I think it is ever thus with annual reports of this kind.

Nevertheless, in the meantime the Minister seems to have had a new vision and upgraded the importance of policy dialogue. I am pleased to note that. I think that the statement, however, does gloss over continuing serious shortcomings in this area. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, of some that were referred to in the audit of the aid program of PNG. Mention is made later in the statement to the auditor of that aid program, but only briefly and only in relation to the major question of the lack of success in achieving economic growth in PNG.

The question of the failure of the Australian Government to persuade the PNG Government to contribute funds in support of the major project to improve PNG constabulary is one issue that should be further addressed because, without allocation of funds apart from the Budget support from Australia, the project will not be able to achieve its objectives which, of course, is important for the improvement of the law and order situation in Papua New Guinea.

The audit report also raises another important issue in relation to law and order: the effect of the centralised wage fixing system in PNG which, of course, has been borrowed from Australia, and the effect that this is having in leading to urban wages that are unrealistically high. I will quote from this report-this will, no doubt, be of interest to Senator Cook:

The gap between rural and urban wages doubled in the 1970s and has maintained since through the indexation system. This has encouraged rural urban drift, increased the reserve price of rural wages and contributed to urban unemployment and widespread law and order problems.

This is clearly an area in which the Government should be engaging in some serious policy dialogue. The Government, I suggest, should be urging the adoption of an appropriate wage system. Bearing in mind that 75 per cent of the population in rural areas in PNG live below the absolute poverty line, the interests of the comparatively well off minority in formal employment in towns should not be allowed to override the interests of the rural poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —That should be put to the Commissioner in PNG.

—Well, it adopted our system, we guided them and I am suggesting seriously to the Minister that it might lead to an outcome which I do not think he intended. This might be a good subject for serious debate at some future time, because this is an important issue. Some of PNG's problems have been inherited from us as well as benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Improved law and order is essential for the maintenance of Australian investment in PNG, which is in the long term interests of both countries. In that light I would remind the Senate that a most uncomfortable matter so far as I am concerned was the recent report of an intention to build what is called `secure' housing in Port Moresby for Australian High Commission staff. It seems to me that the construction of a `complex' sounds like a bunker, which is an admission of a pessimistic outlook by the Australian Government for the law and order situation in PNG. Perhaps some more frank acknowledgment from the Australian Government of its real assessment in this area would be helpful. Thus, I suggest that policy dialogue is important on a whole range of issues, but it is disappointing that there is no indication that the Government will carry out that policy dialogue to the extent that I have indicated.

I wish also to mention briefly the fact that an insufficient proportion of the $1.3 billion that Australia spends on aid program is actually spent on bilateral programs. This was a debate we recently had in the Senate on the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill and I do not want to revisit that debate in any detail today. But, if we are to look at the aid program, in the Opposition's opinion the balance between multilateral assistance and bilateral assistance deserves further consideration. The bilateral share of the overall aid program has dropped from 68 per cent of the program to 58 per cent over the past five years. If the Government is doing this as a result of policy, it should indicate that to the Parliament. We do not know. We do not know whether it is simply as a result of having been locked into the multilateral program and that, with constraints on the total ceiling, it has had an unintended effect. If it is having an unintended effect, what are the consequences of it?

The question of the development import finance facility (DIFF) is mentioned, but only in passing. The Opposition's opinion is that the DIFF program requires greater community and parliamentary debate. In particular, has the program worked, bearing in mind those who argue that it is not good aid? Has it achieved its commercial objectives? There seems to be a hint of an assessment in the Minister's paper that the program is not achieving those objectives. I suggest that that is another issue that should be debated.

With those few comments, I conclude where I started. I suggest that issues concerning Australia's foreign aid, the best quality aid, whether it should be more regionalised, as the Opposition has been suggesting, and whether it should take account of factors such as the extent to which a recipient State spends on its own military needs rather than on the ultimate cause to which the aid is intended, again deserve further attention. I hope that there will be more opportunity to debate these matters in the course of the next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on one of the issues which should be debated in future and which is of some concern to people in this chamber and to the wider community. I refer to the very substantial aid funds which have been granted to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) since this Government came to office. The figures which have been supplied by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) show that, since 1983, $9m of taxpayers' funds will have been supplied to the ACTU for foreign aid purposes. The money which the ACTU receives goes to a range of bodies. One which seems to have done particularly well is a body called APHEDA, which stands for the Australian People For Health Education and Development Abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two brief matters I wish to raise, one of principle and one of policy. The principle is whether foreign aid moneys in very substantial quantities should be given to an organisation such as the ACTU, a wealthy organisation, the members of which have greatly improved their own benefits in the sense of power and privilege under this Government. There is an issue as to whether it is appropriate for taxpayers' funds to be used in this manner. If the ACTU wants to carry out foreign aid that is fine, and I have no argument with it, but my point is that the money with which the Council carries out this foreign aid should come from its own membership, its own unions, and not from taxpayers in general.

The other issue concerns a matter of policy. Since I raised this matter in this place previously, the point has been made to me by members of the public and others as to whether we are seeing in some of these grants an attempt by the Government to run a two-track foreign aid program. There has been very great concern about some of the grants which have been made by APHEDA to various groups. In South Africa the African National Council has been given a grant and there are other grants to which I have already drawn attention. I would urge the Government to think very carefully about the way in which taxpayers' money is being used. I think that it is bad in principle for an organisation with a stated membership, an organisation which is large and which has plenty of its own resources, to use taxpayers' money for foreign aid purposes. The other matter is one of policy as to whether it is appropriate for some of the grants to be made to various bodies which are being funnelled through APHEDA. I am pleased to see that Senator Gareth Evans has said that in the coming months the development education program of APHEDA will be carefully reviewed, and we in the Opposition wait with interest to see the results of that review. In terms of the matters of principle and of policy, I believe that all honourable senators would be well advised to look closely at the amount of money which is being funnelled through the ACTU and how that money is being spent.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —As is customary at the conclusion of the Senate sitting year, I would like to reflect briefly upon the year past and pay tribute to all of those who have made the smooth running of this chamber possible. The year 1990 has been an eventful one in many respects. Of note was, of course, the March election and the departure of some good friends from all sides of the political spectrum. Then we had the arrival of no fewer than 14 new senators who have all made their own particular mark upon the day-to-day life of the Senate. To all of those new senators, I hope that we have made you welcome and that you now feel at home in these often difficult surroundings. Of course, given that you have spent the best part of three months here, day and night, I am sure that you now feel that this is home.

INTERJECT.PARA: However, we are saying yet another farewell today. Senator Peter Baume will not be returning to the Senate next year. Over the past 16 years, Senator Baume has been a tireless and dedicated worker not only for his Party but also for the Senate. I realise only too well that had the result of the March election been different, Senator Baume may well have been in my place today. I also realise that had he been, he would have done the Senate proud. His input into the work of the Presiding Officers' information technology advisory group has been absolutely invaluable to the Speaker and me. Indeed, Senator Baume has, on many occasions, shared with me his thoughts on the administration of the Parliament.

One notable example of this was at a football game just before my re-election as President. At that time I said that I hoped he would run for Deputy President so that we could work together in a bipartisan way on the administrative problems of the Parliament. I was sorry that he did not run, but now I know why he made that decision. Peter, I wish you all the very best for your future career.

In September, I and a number of my parliamentary colleagues travelled to Zimbabwe for the annual Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference, the results of which I have mixed feelings. Whereas I suffered a personal disappointment, Australia's long held wish that we be a separate region from the South Pacific and New Zealand was finally achieved, giving this branch permanent representation on the executive committee. The work done by our colleagues at this important meeting was faultless. I would like to give a particular personal vote of thanks to Senator Bjelke-Petersen for her solid support during that conference.

The year 1990 has been another busy but productive one for the parliamentary departments as they adapt to the new Parliament House. We can really no longer call our building new, but nevertheless we constantly face settling in problems that continue to occupy much of the Speaker's and my time. We have been able to focus on streamlining the various administrations with some degree of success.

Following two reports from the Auditor-General late last year on Hansard and the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO), we have been able to effect substantial change within the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff (DPRS). The Hansard division has undergone major restructuring and reorganisation with the introduction of word processing, computer assisted transcription and electronic transfer of text to the Government Printer. As well, significant changes to the pay conditions and work practices of reporters were negotiated under the structural efficiency principle and industrial negotiations are continuing to bring about similar changes in other areas of Hansard. Both the amount and pace of that change has been very great. None of this would have been possible without the enthusiastic support, cooperation and commitment of all staff in the Hansard division. I would like to thank them all for the very positive manner in which they have responded to the changes which have taken place.

The Sound and Vision Office (SAVO) has not only continued to improve its services to senators but also, in cooperation with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, has taken Senate Question Time live to the people of Australia. This involves significant additional work and resources for SAVO. The result has been most worthwhile.

This year has been a testing and challenging period for the Department of the Parliamentary Library, with major program restructuring. The transfer of PISO to the DPRS in February was a major undertaking with widespread ramifications, particularly in the corporate services area. We are again grateful to the Auditor-General, John Taylor, who has agreed to his officers assisting us in further streamlining operations in the Library so that senators and members can receive an even better service from this valuable resource. I am grateful for the assistance and cooperation I continue to receive from all Library officers in helping us achieve these worthwhile goals.

The Joint House Department, with its many faceted roles, has consolidated during the year as it comes to grips with managing the building. The Speaker and I have been looking closely at the Parliamentary Catering Service to ensure that efficient, cost-effective service is provided to all. Honourable senators will be aware of the changes made to date and we will be giving them a further opportunity to express their views in a survey which is to be conducted in February next year.

With regard to the running of this chamber, I am very much aware of the current scrutiny of the conduct of Question Time. I take this opportunity to point out to honourable senators that the decline in the number of questions began in 1982-the first full year in which the then government did not have control of the Senate. However, I would also like to point out that this year has been the best since 1984 and is very close to being the best since 1982.

As we come to the close of what has been a long Budget session, I must pay tribute to the efforts of all the officers of the Department of the Senate who have so ably assisted in the functioning of the chamber. I am personally grateful for the guidance and assistance I have received from the Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk Assistant. A most sincere vote of thanks must also go to the Deputy President, Senator Colston, who since his election has fulfilled the role of Deputy with distinction and dedication.

It only remains for me now to express my appreciation and best wishes to all of the staff of Parliament House who have played their part, both big and small, in making this a successful year. I greatly appreciate all of the support and assistance that I have received and I look forward to seeing all honourable senators back here in February 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to join you in the remarks that you have made. This has been a long session of the Parliament and a number of changes have taken place during this period. You said, for example, that television was now taking the Senate live to the people of Australia. A lot of people would regard that as an exaggeration.
—I have also received quite a few letters, Senator Button.

— The Senate is usually described in the terms which I think Jeremy Thorpe once used about the House of Lords-that it is proof of the existence of life after death. That joke was stolen by Fred Daly and applied to the Senate. It is nice to see that we are being taken live, as you put it, to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to join in thanking all of the Clerks, officers and attendants of the Department of the Senate whom you have mentioned and who have, again, been very diligent and helpful to senators. I thank the Committee staff, the Hansard staff, the Department of the Parliamentary Library staff and the Joint House Department staff. Of course, I thank you, Mr President, for presiding over this chamber with fairness and expedition. Similarly, I thank the Deputy President, the Temporary Chairmen of Committees and the Whips on both sides who have facilitated the workings of the chamber.

I would particularly like to mention Senator Jim McKiernan who has acted as the Government Whip during the Budget sittings. That seems to have exhausted him totally as I understand he is retiring from the position of Deputy Whip. I think Senator Reid would agree that he has discharged his duties very well and has been a help to all of us.

Mr President, in your remarks you mentioned both old and new senators. The new senators constitute quite a large group and I suppose, for them, it has been an interesting period. It is very nice to see that Senator Austin Lewis is back from his travels. I have to tell you, Senator, that while you have been away the Opposition was flagging a bit. It is like bringing a new player off the interchange bench in the last quarter to see you come back and reinvigorate the side. We welcome that because I can tell you that while you were away, the old lags have behaved as badly as ever and the new ones have not learnt any good habits from them. Now that you are back, I hope that that will improve.
The main purpose of my remarks today is to refer to our colleague Senator Michael Baume.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That was wishful thinking.

— Precisely. Talking of Michael Baume, a few things might be said. Clearly, Senator Michael Baume gives me many nightmares and concerns at various times. For that reason, I inadvertently mentioned him. But Michael Baume will keep. I look forward to making a speech about him at some stage, whether he is retiring or not.

SPEECH.PARA: This chamber arouses many strange passions-anger, humour, sadness, boredom. Peter Baume entered the Senate at the same time as I did. In all that time, the only passionate disagreement we have had has been about poetry. I think on two or three occasions, we have had passionate disagreements about poetry, and on nothing else. I have much more reason to respect Senator Peter Baume than he has to respect me. But I think that there is some mutual respect between us; I do not want to dole out the proportions. I have always had a great deal of respect for him. We worked together on many committees. If one reads about any of us in the Parliamentary Handbook we sound pretty one-dimensional. If one reads all the committees that Peter Baume has sat on and the functions and work that he has performed as a senator and as a member of the Liberal Party of Australia one sees a very long list indeed. All that represents is hard work.

But, of course, he has been far more to the Senate than that. I think it is true to say that he has been a friend to us all. Occasionally he has been a provider of pills to people like me when I have had a toothache. I think that everybody in the Senate has respected him. That is largely because Peter Baume has always been an issues man. Even today when he answered his last question, which took me back to his days as a Minister, he answered the question about an issue which has been of deep concern to him over many years, about which he has felt very strongly and on which he has been totally consistent. There have been other issues of a similar kind. Not many of us in this chamber-some of you will say in my case, regretfully-have ever resigned from a shadow Cabinet or a Cabinet or who have crossed the floor on questions of principle and Peter Baume is one of those.

Today I looked back at his maiden speech in this place. In those days he was a much more political man. Those opposite were all fussed up in the heat of 1974 with the sins of the Whitlam Government. He was swept away in that mood at the time in his maiden speech. But since then he has always addressed himself to issues and has been a rational, informed, intelligent debater of issues without base passion in terms in which he has dealt with problems.

Peter, I will miss you as a colleague and a friend. I am sure that I speak for most other senators-certainly all Government senators-when I say that. On behalf of the Government, I wish you every success in your new career, although in some ways it is a return to a lifelong interest which you have had. I am sure you will have a very fruitful life in that new career, which will prove to us all that there is life after politics and that people, after they leave the Senate, can make a very great contribution. Thank you for your friendship and contribution, and good wishes for the future.
Honourable senators-Hear, Hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Opposition senators, I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in thanking all of those people who have made our life a little easier in this place and who have provided services for us. I mention specifically you, Mr President. Thank you for your impartiality. In some ways it seems that your job is becoming more difficult as the Government seems to be under greater strain and Ministers are showing signs of being tired and emotional. In these stressful times, you are handling a difficult job with dignity that could be treated as a precedent by some on the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank also the Deputy President, who in some ways came into the job in difficult circumstance. Particularly in the Estimates Committee, he showed a tolerance which has helped build goodwill. The Deputy President deserves a particular mention for that, as well as the temporary Chairmen of Committees, who have made our task easier.
I thank all of those who provide services-the Clerks, Hansard staff, others within the Department of the Senate, committee staff, the Library, Comcar drivers-everyone, in fact.

I make particular mention of the role and function of the Clerks. I do that because of the rather unfortunate and sour note that was introduced into the Senate this morning in a notice of motion. The Clerks have a difficult job. They of course advise both sides. I guess any of us who have been to a football match always think that the umpire is on the other side. But generally speaking, he is not. If honourable senators feel that the Clerks are fulfilling their task by advising the other side, then they should recognise that that is part of their job.

I can remember in the very recent past Senator Button being presented with a problem. He had a statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for which leave was not granted to be incorporated. I saw the Clerk lean over and give him a tip on how to get out of the problem, that is, by tabling the statement. My immediate reaction was, `Why should someone with Senator Button's experience need help in this way?'. But of course it is part of the job. From my observation and impression, in the nearly 10 years I have been here, the Clerks have been non-partisan, do an excellent job in difficult circumstances and help us all out when we ask for that help.
Honourable senators-Hear, Hear!

TALK.START.PARA: — I mention the management of government business. Each year, at about this time, we are told that it will be improved in the following year. We have been told it again. I hope that this time it is true. Really the pressures of the last few weeks have resulted from a shambles in relation to government business this session. The Government has set aside more sitting days in the first half of next year to try to work through some of the backlog. I simply say that with better planning there is no reason to get into the situation that we have had this year, which has the unfortunate effect of resulting in work of not the quality that we desire.

SPEECH.PARA: In that vein of looking at the Senate working better as a Senate, I commend the new system that we have adopted of referring Bills more often to the legislative general purpose standing committees for what are being referred to as `mini-inquiries'. There is no doubt, this being the first parliamentary session in which this system has operated, that there have been teething problems. But I can point to many successes already on the board out of that new system not only in producing better quality work, which should be a key objective of all of us but also giving those who have particular interest within the community in a piece of legislation the opportunity to contribute. I have noted that that is already being appreciated by the various interest groups and professional groups-as I said, those who have particular interest in a particular topic. I think that it will be a very major reform of this Senate. When we get through the teething problems and the system is working smoothly, as I am sure that it will, we will look back upon this as a time of worthwhile reform.

Senator Button mentioned Question Time. There is no doubt that Question Time is becoming more stressful. As honourable senators are aware, there is concern on this side of the chamber that there are not the opportunities to ask what we regard as a sufficient number of questions. Today was a bad example of what some of us feel is becoming a practice of insufficient questions, answers being unduly lengthy, statements being put down under the guise of questions without notice, which was never the intention of this parliamentary mechanism. It was designed to give an element of accountability of government Ministers to elected members of parliament. I hope that we can work through this difficulty of Question Time during the next session and the result can be more questions being asked and answered.

Television was mentioned. This is another reform which I know is regarded by some as a bit of a joke. This is another opportunity for the parliamentary process to be better taken to the community in an accepted medium. I have noted, as have many of my colleagues, the interest that it now seems to have engendered. Mr President, you mentioned that you are getting letters. We are all getting letters and other responses. That will ultimately have the effect that we want it to have: that the community will understand the processes of parliament and this democracy better and, hopefully, will therefore be more supportive of it.

We are, as the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) said, standing here today particularly to mark the pending retirement of one of our colleagues. I also wish to join with the Leader of the Government to say a few words regarding the career of my friend and colleague Peter Baume. He is one of the lucky people in our society who will have three careers, it seems. His first, as a consulting physician, was one that I understand was outstanding. He then came to us and he can have the comfort of retiring from his parliamentary career knowing that he distinguished this institution.

Perhaps a touch of the motivation of Peter Baume was seen in interviews that he accepted at the time of announcing his pending retirement from here to go to his third career, that of a professor of community medicine at the University of New South Wales. In one interview he said:

It will allow me to continue and to develop further my interests in a range of health-related issues, including evaluation theory and practice, drug policy, health services planning, social inequalities in health, HIV and AIDS and other issues.

Some of us know of the work that Peter Baume has been doing in these areas. Drug policy has always been a field of great personal commitment to him. In recent years he has been involved with the issues relating to the scourge of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) in a sensitive attempt to help those who are suffering from that disease and to prevent its spread. This attitude and atmosphere of community service has been very much at the heart of Peter Baume's contribution to public life.

Today I shall just briefly put on the record some of his contributions within the parliamentary process as a Cabinet Minister and as a parliamentarian. The various portfolios he held in the Fraser Government included Aboriginal Affairs-for which his work is well known in the community-the health portfolio for a brief period, and the education portfolio. I remind honourable senators that Peter Baume served with distinction in the Whips field, both as a Deputy Whip and as a Whip. My colleagues who remember those days speak of him as a strict but fair disciplinarian. I think in many ways he is still very proud of his contribution as Whip and holds the position of Whip as one of vital importance to the smooth running of this institution.

His shadow ministerial responsibilities have included education and youth affairs, the status of women and community services. He has given outstanding service on committees, including four years as the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, participation on the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, and involvement with the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance in 1989.

He was a capable technician, and honourable senators on this side of the chamber will remember his handling of the very difficult Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation not very long ago, involving over 40 hours of complex and detailed debate, which he led from our side. As Senator Button mentioned, he has served as an Acting Deputy President and as such was an acknowledged master of the Standing Orders.

Apart from that record, I want also to put down a few personal thoughts on Peter Baume the man, my friend and my colleague. There is no doubt about Peter Baume's intellect. It has been of great benefit to our side of the Parliament and to the Parliament as a whole. There is no doubt about his passion and determination and there is no doubt about his courage, as Senator Button mentioned, in relation to one or two difficult issues. Peter Baume has come to us as a committed and dedicated Liberal. By that, I acknowledge his belief in the supreme dignity of individuals-each and every individual having the entitlement to be treated with respect and equally. As I have said, his record has been as a fighter for the underprivileged, for anyone who has been discriminated against. We can look at Peter Baume's work in relation to Aboriginals and in relation to AIDS as a couple of examples.

Philosophically, he has made clear to us-all of those he has sought to educate in various ways-the value of an interventionist role of government when it is necessary, particularly to help those who need support of government. Peter Baume has not hesitated to say that the Government should accept and meet that responsibility. I particularly acknowledge the work that he has undertaken in this place in the promotion of the interests of women and the equal opportunity legislation debate, on which he resigned the shadow portfolio. That was of great difficulty for Peter Baume, but it demonstrated the courage of his convictions. He may not be known by all as a great supporter of the family, but he is. He has been very lucky to have Jenny as both a friend and supporter as well as a wife. He has been a great supporter of democratic institutions and particularly of this Senate. That is why I say that he will be remembered as a distinguished senator.

Lastly, I acknowledge his support for young people. His curriculum vitae shows that he was a patron of the Young Liberal Movement and other youth organisations, always wanting to help and advance the interests of young people. It has been a very fine contribution to public life, through the Senate and through the opportunity of government. I congratulate Peter Baume. I wish him well for the future. He has been a good friend to me and a good counsel.
Honourable senators-Hear, Hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, on behalf of my Party, to contribute to the final debate in this Budget Session. Initially, I thank those who make this place work, albeit with enormous difficulty from time to time, and not necessarily with the full cooperation of all of us in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank you, Mr President, for your firm hand which has so often been needed-particularly during the last rather fraught weeks; and your Deputy who has shown, through this first session in his position, a similar firm hand tempered, I think, by a great sense of humanity and even a little dry wit from time to time. I look forward to the rest of his term of office.

I would also like to mention the Democrats' great appreciation of the work and guidance of the Clerks. In our position in this place, holding the balance of power, nothing could be more crucial for us than that advice and guidance which is, of course, as Senator Hill has said, given to us all to do with as we will. We are the receivers of advice; whether we take it or not is entirely in our hands. We appreciate the advice that we get from the Clerks and the very hard work that they, along with many other people around this place, do.

I have often wondered, particularly in these last few weeks, how any of us physically cope with the sort of regime to which we subject ourselves. Most particularly, I think about it in the context of those-the Clerks, whom I have mentioned; the committee staff; the Hansard staff; the Library staff; the drivers and everyone else-who seem to have to revolve around our activities and the hours that we set ourselves. When we are making decisions about how we are going to operate within this chamber, we should think more often about what it is we do to those people and, of course, to their families and their lives.

Therefore, I commend to all honourable senators my own new year's resolution, that is, to do everything I can to ensure that this place does not sit in the last week before Christmas next year. The Government is responsible for the management of this place, as Senator Hill has said. Nevertheless, we all have a role. The Government has a swag of Bills ready for us when we come back nice and early next year. I think that with the planning which Senator Hill asked for from the Government, and with cooperation, we could make that new year's resolution come true.

It is for the sake of the Clerks and everybody else who works in this place-and I am conscious of the long hours that you, Mr President, and the Deputy President have spent in the chair these last few nights-that I speak about that goal which we should all have. I do not think legislation by exhaustion is really what this country deserves from this chamber.

I have served my first session as Leader of my Party. It has been a session of new elements for the Senate. There has been a new committee system. We are on record as saying we have done everything we can to see whether or not it will work. That is something we will all have to look at in the coming year. The pressure and stresses, particularly as those committees have met in these last few weeks, have been heavy burdens on my colleagues with their heavy portfolio loads. I think we should acknowledge the work that they have done.

This session there has been the televising of Question Time and my own new leadership, of which I have been particularly conscious, and also the relatively new leadership-having had four weeks to be run in, so to speak-of Senator Hill and Senator Boswell. Senator Button has been sitting there, not so new, on the other side.

I would particularly like to acknowledge the new team which I have led. Five of my senators have been new, with Senator Lees and Senator Bell having had four weeks in May to add to their experience before they came for the Budget session. I congratulate my colleagues. It is very difficult to sit in balance of power, particularly in these last few weeks with the rush of legislation. I thank my colleagues, in particular my Deputy Leader, Senator Coulter, for their cooperation, stamina and fortitude in those circumstances.

I think the Senate can be proud of the work that it does. If one looks at the Order of Business, one sees a long list of amended Bills that have come back to us from the House of Representatives. I would like to say something about this process. We hear a lot about deals in this place and I think we ought to see what that really means. It means that we have a chamber where the voice of the people can be heard and can have an effect. Those amendments are Government-Opposition amendments, sometimes.
Senator Macdonald interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell Senator Macdonald that they are sometimes Opposition-Democrat amendments-quite often, in fact. They might be Government-Democrat amendments. Nevertheless, they are the work of this chamber. As I say, it is work which is done perhaps not in the most organised way. It is important for us to acknowledge the process that goes on here.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one has had more experience of that than Senator Peter Baume to whom I want to say a very fond farewell. I had the pleasure of being a neighbour of Senator Baume's when we moved into this House. I saw quite a bit of him in the corridors in those years before coming downstairs this session myself. He has always been a cheerful person around the place. Sometimes, particularly towards the end of a year like this, that in itself can be enough to endear a person to any other person around the place. Someone who can manage a cheerful demeanour and a kind word is certainly popular for that reason alone. I think Senator Baume bears the title `the Hon.', which he has earned and which has been bestowed on him through his political work, perhaps more rightfully than anyone I can think of. He is an honourable politician who has been guided by those principles of liberalism which he has so often expounded very clearly in this place.

When I spoke to the 100 outstanding year 11 students at the Queen Elizabeth II Silver Jubilee seminar they were at pains to tell me how much they had been impressed by Senator Peter Baume who had spoken to them the day before. They drew the contrast between the impact Senator Baume had on them and what they thought politicians were actually like. I know that Senator Peter Baume has spoken to many other groups of young people. I think we are all indebted to a politician who can actually raise young people's opinions of politicians in this country to a higher level. He has done us all a service.

I add to what Senator Hill said about the groups of people in the community who have been championed by Senator Peter Baume as a Minister, in Opposition, and on the back bench of his own Party-Aboriginal people, the disabled, young people and, in particular, women. He is a politician who has lived, worked and voted by his principles-something which is quite unusual. Even though he does not tell these young people that that is what he has done, that is what they can see and appreciate.

I personally wish to acknowledge the support of Senator Baume for those measures over the years which Democrats before me, and currently, have taken towards reducing the incidence of tobacco use in our community; his support for my private member's Bill whose provisions come into effect in a few days time; and his work within his own Party and the community on this issue.

His contributions in this place have always been intelligent and compassionate. He is a politician of courage. He is a politician who is extremely loyal to his Party-from my point of view, unbelievably loyal. His loyalty must be acknowledged, and I think it is, by his own Party.

I wish him well in his, as Senator Hill has said, third career. He will be a magnificent professor of community medicine. No-one could be better suited to such a position, for he is a politician who has never been out of touch with the community. I believe he will bring great distinction to the University of New South Wales as he already has to politics and his profession. He will be missed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join in the contributions that the other party leaders have made. This is the day that we have all been waiting for over the last four or five weeks. We are hoping today that we can join our families and children at Christmas.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I would like to thank you on behalf of my colleagues for the fairness and firmness in the way you have handled the Senate. Our thanks go to your Deputy President also. I would like to thank the transport people who get us here, keep us here and help us to get away. I would like to thank the attendants who bring the mail in and are always supporting us. I would like to thank the Whips and their Clerks. I would like to thank the Hansard staff who always seem to make my speeches sound a lot better when people read them than when I give them. I would like to thank the Library staff and the excellent service that they provide to all of us in giving us rural information and current media transcripts. It is a very good service. Mr President, you could almost say that if the inmates behaved in the way that the officers do, and carried out their duties with the same efficiency, we would have been out of here two weeks ago.

I thank Senator Bjelke-Petersen for taking the job on as our Whip when Senator Brownhill was overseas. We wish Senator Bjelke-Petersen all the best for Christmas in her very hard times. I thank my colleagues in the National Party. We are only a small number but we are a happy team.

TALK.START.PARA: —And getting smaller by the day.

—We have been down before but we have always been able to come back. I would like to say a special word about the Clerks. I believe Harry Evans will be one of the great Clerks in the history of the Senate. His article on the new procedures relating to the referral of Bills to committees was a very important and a very timely one. The article by Peter O'Keeffe, the Clerk Assistant, on how a private member is able to get a private member's Bill through was, I have to acknowledge, one worth writing. I acknowledge the tribute that he paid to my former colleague in this place, Senator McGauran, who will be back after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember the debate on the War Crimes Bill when we joined as one to pass it because everyone in the Senate, including Senator Collins, could see the merits of the arguments. It was approached in a bipartisan way. I hope that Senator Collins will use his considerable influence in getting the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) to accept that Bill when it is debated in the lower House.

I thank the Clerk and deputy Clerks for their work in the chamber and the service that they provide us. I know that as Leader of the National Party I have had to seek their advice on a number of occasions. I thank my staff also. They have been very helpful to me over the last seven or eight months for which I have been Leader.

Mr President, we now come to a sad part of the procedure today in farewelling our colleague, Senator Peter Baume. I suppose there are not too many more unlikely combinations in the Senate than Senator Peter Baume, a liberal, and a person like myself, a merchant and a conservative. But we formed a great partnership and a great respect for each other-at least I certainly respect Senator Peter Baume and I hope he respects me.

We have been on a number of committees together. I will always remember an incident that occurred on the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs when we were travelling in one of those Hawker Siddeley planes-the ones that defy gravity by hanging in the air at a minimum speed. It was an interesting debate because Senator Devlin, Senator McMullan, Senator Peter Baume and I were there-an interesting combination of a waterside worker, an economist, a doctor and a merchant. The discussion moved into deep intellectual philosophy. Senator McMullan and Senator Peter Baume were trying to prove by some equation that the earth was round. This developed into such an intellectual discussion that one had to have at least five degrees to enter into the debate. Either Senator Devlin or I said, `Listen, the way you find out that the earth is round is you start from one point and you keep going and when you come back to the same point you know the earth is round'.

I give that little example of what actually happened when four people from diverse backgrounds came together. Senator Peter Baume could cover the whole spectrum. He could talk to me, to the intellectuals, to the waterside workers and the workers and he could give them all the same confidence. That is one of the greatest attributes that I believe he brings into the Senate. He could cover the whole spectrum of human relations. For that I admire you Peter; I will miss you. I stood by Peter in one of the most trying speeches I had to make here. I do not want to mention the name of the debate and bring it up again because it did the job it was intended to do. Peter Baume stood alongside me and I thank him for that.

Peter, today you leave the Senate to start your third career. To you, to your wife in the gallery, to Sarah and your son-to your family-I wish you all the best. I say to you, Peter, that I am sure that you will make the same success of your third career as you have of your first and second careers. In conclusion, I wish everyone here a happy, safe and a holy Christmas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Other speakers in this debate have spoken of the work done by parliamentary staff and the thanks we all owe them for that. I know that a number of people want to speak in this debate so I will not go over that ground.
—Thank the Whips.

— Yes, all of those people, and the staff-best wishes to them all. I want to confine my remarks this afternoon to the departure of Senator Peter Baume. I must say that I feel very sorry for Senator Peter Baume. I think we should have made some arrangement for him to go off and sit in a soundproof room somewhere outside the chamber. It must be trying actually to sit here and listen to all this stuff. Might I say, and there are a few in this chamber who can testify to it, that we all find at times that valedictories-and I remember the last one in here with Senator Button-are a bit trying at times in that some of it is gush, and let us admit it, and some of it is not quite as sincere as it might be, but that will not apply to anything said in this debate by either side this afternoon and we all know that.

SPEECH.PARA: My personal association with Senator Peter Baume goes back a number of years and predates my arriving in the Senate. But I have not forgotten it. It was in the early 1980s and he was the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I was a young and much smaller Northern Territory politician-and in every sense. Peter Baume came to the Northern Territory-this was a decade ago-at a time when conditions for Aboriginal people were considerably worse than they are now. They were appalling in some circumstances. I am known for my tolerance and even temper but I was not displaying those qualities in those days. I had a virulent dislike of conservative politicians in respect of the issue of Aboriginal affairs because Aboriginal people had lived under a very long period of neglect and I held conservative politicians to blame for a lot of that. The only reason that I mention that is to put this incident in context.

We had a serious problem in the Northern Territory, which is not relevant to this debate, so I will not go into it. To my astonishment I was approached by the conservative Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who had had it suggested to him that he come to see me about this particular problem. That was at a point in my political career where I could barely manage to say, `G'day' to a conservative Federal politician. First, I was astonished that a conservative Federal Minister would come anywhere near me to ask for advice and, secondly, I decided very early in the conversation that I would have to revise my views about conservative politicians in terms of making generalisations about them and that this was a bloke who was fair dinkum. I gave him some advice; the issue was resolved and there it was.

The reason I mention this is that some years later when I came to the Senate I was approached by Peter Baume during the first one or two days I was here. He said, `Hello, you probably have forgotten that some years ago when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs', et cetera. I want to tell Peter Baume now that I had not forgotten it, and still have not forgotten it. He thanked me for the advice I gave, took it and the issue was resolved. My regard for Peter Baume started from that point in time. It has been a privilege and a pleasure to work with him-and Ron Boswell has mentioned the same committee -not just in this chamber but also on the committees of this Parliament, and my regard for him has increased and deepened over the years.

Peter Baume, as well as being an able and diligent politician and one of the really good people in Parliament, has made a real contribution. He has many personal attributes which not only do I not share but will never possess. I know that this will be hurtful to Senator Michael Baume, the other half of the Baume family here, but I might say that one of the differences between Michael and his cousin, Peter Baume, is that, while Michael is a very able and diligent senator, he is often nasty and at times horrible. I mention that because-being a bit honest-I must admit that, while over the years I have admired Peter Baume, I have always tended to identify with Michael Baume. I do not possess and never will -I guess it is a deficiency in my make-up-some of those qualities I admire which Peter Baume has brought to this Parliament and to public life, along with the abilities of which we are all very well aware.

I woke this morning to the dulcet tones of Mr Bruce Webster on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on my clock radio. He was giving his report to the ABC on today's proceedings in the Senate. Bruce Webster, as most of us know-although some of us here may not-has the job of professionally watching and listening to everything we say in this chamber. He has been doing it for a decade. No doubt, as a result-and I am sure that it will inevitably come to pass-a small green van will pull up at the gates of Parliament House and men in white coats will carry him away a gibbering wreck. Of a number of people in this Parliament Bruce is in a better position than most-along with the staff who are constrained in appearing on ABC radio, although Bruce has a bit more flexibility in that regard-to pass comments on members of this Parliament. He said this morning:

Today the spotlight is on the human face of Parliament. On the motion of Senator Bourne a NSW Democrat it is Professor Senator Doctor Peter Baume Day . . . and following a move by the President Kerry Sibraa, Senator Peter Baume will be Honorary President this morning.

Parliament is a microcosm of our society . . . the members and senators reflect our strengths and weaknesses. They come and go, often unnoticed by the community at large. However every so often someone special comes along. Peter Baume is such a person. He is admired and respected by the whole Parliament . . . in fact, dare I say it-
this is a bit gushy-
. . . he is much loved. He goes on to become Professor of Community medicine at the University of NSW.

I quoted that because I have been in parliament now for 14 years and over that time I have come across a small number of politicians whom I have detested. That detestation for some people-no doubt equally shared-has never been because of their political views. It has been because-and it is a very small number of politicians indeed who fit into this category; I stress that I am talking about both sides of the House-they are politicians who put in the minimum and take out the maximum. Peter Baume certainly is not in that category. Over the years I have also met a number of politicians whom I have liked very much but respected very little or not at all. I have also met politicians on both sides of the House for whom I have enormous respect but do not like very much at all. I have to say-and I think I speak for a lot of people on all sides of this chamber-that I do not think I have met anyone in 14 years in Parliament whom I have both liked and respected as much as Peter Baume. Sad as Peter Baume feels-and I know he does-about leaving this Parliament, he at least leaves it with the comfort that he has the respect, regard and good wishes of everyone in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that this comment at the end of the year should first start as a personal explanation in response to Senator Collins. However, I will get the usual good wishes out of the way, not because I want to downgrade them but because I want to talk about my cousin. Mr President, I wish you, the Clerks and everyone here all the best for Christmas and the New Year.

SPEECH.PARA: I have known Senator Peter Baume for more than 50 years, which I think probably just exceeds the time that most members of the Senate have known him. When I first met him he was a very skinny little kid. He was one of the few people in the world I towered over-for a short period of time. His family home at Collaroy was almost a home away from home for me. Under the benevolent dictatorship of his father, we had a great, funny, very exciting and interesting youth. Of course we always had holidays in the country together, where my mother was able to demonstrate-I think at a height of less than five feet-that she could tower over everybody.

The determination and bravery of Senator Peter Baume can probably be best summed up by observing that, despite having inherited the family nose, he still played hooker for the university rugby second grade side. That bravery also took him into, as I recall, the Ku-ring-gai Municipal Library, where he obviously found more than books in the stacks. While I could do no better than a very hard cover that was on temporary loan, he managed to find a very loyal and supportive wife there.

When he joined Parliament 16 years ago he had achieved great status as a consulting physician and many people asked, `Why are you doing this? You are a loss to medicine; it is an incredible waste of enormous talent'. His response then was that he had become a doctor because he was concerned about people and he was becoming a politician because he was concerned about people. It seems to me that he is now becoming Professor of Community Medicine because that concern about people is still driving Peter Baume. If one asks what drives Peter Baume, it is that evident concern; and he has been fortunate enough to have the ability and opportunity to be able to put into effect ways in which he can practically and usefully express that concern. Just as he was a great loss to medicine when he came into politics, so he will be a great loss to politics as he goes back into community medicine.

While today is obviously a very important day to Senator Peter Baume, it is also a very important day for me, because today is the day that in effect Peter Baume ceases to be Senator Peter Baume and I cease to be Senator Michael Baume; from today I simply become Senator Baume. I have one objective which remains, however, and that is to note that Senator Peter Baume, when he ceases being Senator Peter Baume, will still be the Honourable Peter Baume in all its aspects. If I have one objective in this place, I suppose it is to gain the word `honourable' both in capital letters, as Peter has done, and in lower case, as Peter has done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I echo the words that have been espoused by speakers from all sides of the chamber in regard to Senator Peter Baume on his pending retirement from this place. I do not want to spend a long time repeating those words because many others have served a lot longer in this place than I have and have worked with Peter over a wide range of issues. I have worked with Peter in this place for the benefit of Australians, and I consider that to be a privilege to me.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to thank the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) who made some kind remarks about me and the role that I have been fulfilling in the past few months. It seems like a few years, but I am assured it has been only a few months. I am pleased that in this period because of the actions of the Government in the Senate the country has not come to a standstill. We have completed the program on time with the help of one particular motion that was carried in this place earlier in the week.

The work would not have been completed-and my work would not have been done in the way it was-without the enormous assistance that has been given to me by my two deputies, Senator Foreman and Senator Faulkner. I thank them for their assistance. It also would not have been done without the able assistance of the Opposition Whips-Senator Reid, Senator Knowles and Senator McLean-and many others who combine together to make this place work. I include in that the Clerks and the staff in the Table Office out in the corridor. Special mention must be made of Joan Harvey, the Whips Clerk, who is here from well before the bells ring in the morning until they ring very late at night. Joan has had many accolades given to her in this place at this time of the year for the work that she continues to do on behalf of the Parliament, and I am pleased that I have the pleasure on this occasion of registering the thanks of the Senate for the work that she does. I think that we ought to include in those remarks the people on the other side of the corridor from the Opposition Whip's office who play an enormous role in keeping this place moving.

I add into that my own staff member Marianna Serghi who has worked together with Joan to assist in keeping this place going. I am aware that there is a very distinct smell in the air. I detect avgas. With that in mind, I conclude my remarks by wishing everybody the compliments of the season, and let us hope for a very peaceful new year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish a very happy Christmas to everyone in the Senate and all those who serve the Senate. I thank all those who have contributed to this session. More particularly, I rise to wish every success to my dear, good friend Senator Peter Baume. We will miss you, Peter. With his wife, Jenny, who is in the gallery, and all his family, we are confident that he will have a very happy continuing contribution to make, in his career, to all Australians. We hope to see him often.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to recall one particular month in the history of our Parliament. May 1987, three and a half years ago, was a very sad and difficult month. It was at a time when the Opposition was not in the strongest of fortunes. It was a time when, despite the principles that my Party stand for, a very controversial issue had come before us: the question of equal employment opportunity, especially for women, disabled people and newly arrived Australians. We had already seen in the Parliament one item of legislation go through with the support of both sides of the Parliament. This was the first equal opportunity legislation. At the time, our spokesman on the status of women-and with a very careful concern for this issue and for reform in our country-was in fact Senator Peter Baume. As a senior member of the shadow Cabinet he had the carriage of this area and had called in the first debate for a similar Bill to relate to the area that in fact this second Bill in May 1987 addressed. As I say, we were in a difficult time, and I do not wish to reflect upon the political judgment of others, as there was a variety of judgments, but I wish to highlight the carefulness, the conscientiousness and the courage that Peter Baume showed in that month. It showed him to be a person who cared for the people of Australia and who cared most courageously for the principle of equality.

It led to a number of us disagreeing with our Party. I for one, quite independently, determined that it was the first time that I would cross the floor and vote against my colleagues. There were seven of us in the Senate who said that we will stand for the principles that our Party has foundered upon and we will stand for equality. This was our personal judgment, and we believed this to be the issue in the matter that was before us. But the burden on Peter was much greater and, whilst there were some conversations with us, there was no conspiracy, no discussion, nothing other than his personal political attitudes which were being tested. He independently resigned from the shadow Cabinet and he was not a member in the three and a half years thereafter. It was an enormous price that he paid personally for a principle that I think we should remember him for.

I believe that it was an enormous price for my Party and, in retrospect, I regard us as sitting on this side of the chamber not least because of decisions like the one made in 1987. This led to greater disunity at that time because of the way in which that was not resolved. It was an enormous price that we were not, on our side of the Parliament, able to reconcile and to recognise the principles that Peter and a number of us so conscientiously espoused then, and we espouse them now without one small apology. I hope that we can remember that Senator Peter Baume exercised human compassion and the principles of liberty and equality in all that he brought to this chamber and to our Party. He leaves us now with enormous admiration on our part. We know that he was here to serve the people, and we wish him and Jenny every success in the years ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to do two things: to add my thanks to the staff of the Parliament, and also to pass a few remarks about Senator Peter Baume. All of us who come into this place will have remembered those first few days when one realises the vast difference which separates the workings of Parliament from what goes on outside. Particularly new senators, on those first few days when the Parliament sits way into the evening, find that all of the staff are still working, the lights are on and one has a sense that Parliament is like a great ship at sea-and several other people have remarked on this also. It is totally self-contained. It operates with incredible facility, precision, cheerfulness and independently, to some extent, of what is going on in the community outside.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot mention all the staff because, as everyone knows, there are many thousands who work in this place. I recall on about the third or fourth day in this place when I asked the library for a particular reference and it came to about 7.30 at night and I thought that the library staff would have gone home. I did not think of ringing them up again. The librarian rang up and said, `Do you still want that reference?'. I said, `Oh, are you still working?'. He said `Oh, yes, we are still working as long as you are here.' I went down to the library-as it was in the old place-and was helped at great length.

That is characteristic of the way in which the staff work, and I see Cleaver Elliott sitting over there. All of us who have been through these last four weeks will know that we have been down to him early in the morning, in the middle of the day, late at night, saying, `Can you draft up this amendment?'. We have been met with confidence, competence and a great deal of humour, even though he has been worked very hard indeed. Before him I recall in that role Peter O'Keefe and John Vander Wyk. They served with exactly the same good humour and competence. I mention those people simply as examples because around the Parliament those are the characteristics one finds among all the staff.

I turn to Senator Peter Baume. I note, as have others, that he is leaving Parliament to go back into an academic career. I have come the other way: I have come from an academic career into Parliament. I know very well that I could not go back into an academic career because I do not have the ability while I am in this place to carry on at the level required, with the sorts of understanding and work that are required. The first characteristic that one notices about Peter is that he has been able to keep up with his own speciality, which indicates an incredible intelligence and ability not only to keep up with what is happening but to remain at the forefront. One does not become appointed to a professorial position unless one is of more than just average competence and average knowledge.

Some senators will have noted that, on the last occasion on which there were valedictory speeches, I did not come into the chamber. I was in my office watching proceedings on the monitor, and I was rather concerned that I may have come into this chamber and heard things being said that were not being said with full sincerity. I have come in here today knowing that everything that is said of Senator Peter Baume will be said with complete sincerity.

My experience of Peter is that he has shown not only the incredible intelligence that I have mentioned, but also an enormous degree of fairness and great forthrightness in very difficult situations. I have served on several committees with Peter, and I remember one occasion not many months ago when we had before us a number of government officers. Without any messing around after these government officers had given evidence, Peter simply said, `Will you give me an answer to this question and outline the answer yes or no?'. He kept after those officers, and when he was quite unable to elicit an appropriate answer, at the end of their evidence he said straight across the table to them, `That is the worst submission I have ever heard in this place'. I do not have the courage to say that, Peter, but that was absolutely right. I have found you to be not only an intelligent and courageous person, but also an extremely fair person of supreme integrity. That is a very important quality in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join colleagues in speaking on the occasion of the departure of Senator Peter Baume from this place. Unlike some senators here, I come to praise Caesar, not to bury him. I have had the pleasure of hearing Peter Baume in this place in any number of speeches, and certainly in Estimates, where I suppose the best way to describe his contribution is, `Always the rapier, never the broadsword'. Over the last year on the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, I have been particularly appreciative of and grateful for his contribution to what I think will turn out to be a useful contribution to the ongoing debate on health care.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Baume is a man of undoubted talent, commitment and compassion. That has been said by many, and I confirm that of my own knowledge. People can be assured that, if they ever take the time to dial up the parliamentary Hansard and select the name of Senator Peter Baume, they will have a very good read. I suppose that on any number of occasions one can say, `That was a good speech' or `That was a singular contribution', but I would urge people who wish to read Senator Peter Baume's contributions particularly to check out his speeches on the war crimes legislation. However, I hate to suggest that they stop there.

Given the praise for this man that I have heard in this place today, I can only wonder at the Opposition, which is clearly somewhat profligate with talent. Peter Baume has taken a stand on principle and it has cost him dear. In particular, with others, as was mentioned by Senator Teague, he crossed the floor on the equal opportunity legislation. As a result of that action, I fell to thinking, by way of this valedictory, with whom I might compare this man. Senator Peter Baume is something of a philosopher. Perhaps then he is a Thomas Aquinas. Do not fear, Senator Baume, Thomas Aquinas might be right on philosophy, but he was awful on women. Thomas Aquinas reckoned that they are a `deformed species of the human race, only conceived when the wind blows from the north'. That would not do as an analogy at all.

Then perhaps I could consider Senator Peter Baume as a gentleman and scholar. Perhaps I could see whether Samuel Johnson was a model. What I found in the Library assisted me in this because Samuel Johnson said:
I am very fond of the company of ladies. I like their beauty, I like their delicacy, I like their vivacity, and I like their silence.

That will not do either. No, he cannot be a gentleman and a scholar of the Samuel Johnson sort. As Senator Peter Baume is a person concerned with due process and good order, committed to using the law for change, I thought that maybe Jeremy Bentham would do. We know that Jeremy Bentham's contribution was that the dominant group in society that has the power can determine the good. Bentham thought that superior power was its own moral justification. Thus, he taught that the superior legal rights of men were justified because they had physical power and because women were `delicate, inferior in strength and hardiness of body, in point of knowledge, intellectual powers and firmness of mind'. That will not do either, Senator Baume. None of those captured your contribution or what you have given us to understand is your view and the sort of person you are.

I concluded from my little search that, Senator Baume, you are your own man, and that is probably one of the greatest ways in which you have contributed to this place. I wish you well in your new career in medicine. Parliament's loss is medicine's gain. I trust that Senator Herron and I will be able to continue your practice in this place. I look forward to your contribution in community health, and when and if you ever have to come before the Estimates committees, I hope that I am present. My best wishes to you, to Jenny and the family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to express my best wishes to colleagues and staff alike. I wish briefly to say a few words about my good friend and colleague Senator Peter Baume. To say farewell to Senator Peter Baume is a sad day for many of us. However, one always has to be mindful that, when a person is moving on to do something of his choice, we should and do wish him well in his future endeavours. I wish to place on record my personal thanks to Senator Baume for being a great friend and a wonderful colleague.

SPEECH.PARA: When former Senator Lajovic made his last speech to the Senate, I had been here for only a few months, but he said one thing that struck a real chord in me:

I thank all my friends and supporters in the Liberal Party. It is impossible to name all of them, but there is one person I have to name, Senator Peter Baume. He guided me in my first days here and was constantly at my side, always willing to help.
As a new girl at the time sitting beside him, I could well and truly empathise with his sentiments at that time.

Peter has always been ready, willing and able and never too busy to share his vast experience with new and old colleagues alike. Many people in my own very conservative State of Western Australia found it puzzling, to say the least, to believe or understand, for that matter, how I could consider Senator Baume, coming from a much more damp State, a friend. But Parliament is no different from any other aspect of life, and a prerequisite of friends should not be having to agree with them on everything-thank heavens.

Peter's experience and wisdom is something that, I believe, will be missed by this Parliament generally and by the Senate in particular. His medical skills will also be missed by many. While Peter never professed-pardon the pun-to have the answers for every illness, the fact remains that he did. One of my staff, Jeremy Buxton, said the other day that even though he had never been to Peter for a consultation, he recognised him as one of the most supremely caring and decent people that he had encountered in 21 years of political involvement.
