He also said-in a bit of a heavy note, I suppose-if he were ever to receive bad news from a doctor, Peter Baume is exactly the sort of man from whom he would want to learn that news because of his compassion. We can all relate to a lot of that because, Peter, we do recognise you as a very caring and decent gentleman.

Peter's wife, Jenny, who is sitting up there today also deserves recognition for her fine contribution over Peter's 17 years in the Senate and the Parliament, and for helping his contribution to the Liberal Party. It has always been a pleasure to see you, Jenny. I hope we will see a lot more of you in the future and keep up that smile.

Peter, thank you for what you have done for the Liberal Party. Thank you for what you have done for the Parliament, and thank you for your advice and friendship. I wish you well in your new role as the honourable professor. I wish you, Jenny, and your family all the best in your new phase of life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, many honourable senators have been kind enough to come into the chamber for this small occasion and to all of those senators, thanks. Some senators have been kind enough to speak, and I apologise to those who would still like to speak but I am conscious of the time and of the nearness of 3.45 p.m. To you, Mr President, to the Clerks, to the Hansard staff, to the librarians, to the drivers, to the committee secretaries, to the Senate officers, the attendants and the waitresses-thank you not just for what you have done this year, but for what you have done over the long period since 1974 for me personally. You have all been very kind.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to thank my colleagues too for their friendship, for their tolerance, for their collegiality and for their kindness. I want to thank you, Mr President, and the Senate for the great honour you did me this morning and say how much it was appreciated. I would like to thank the attendants in this place for an event earlier this week where they made a presentation to me which moved me very much.

Valedictories, while the person is alive, have something of an anticipatory quality. It is the kind of occasion where only the good is remembered, where people's attributes are magnified and where faults are conveniently forgotten. It is an important occasion for the individual; one that should occur once only and in my case, Senator Teague, it will be once only. I will probably take the advice of some of my colleagues and not return.

However, it is an opportunity for a look back and a retrospective view of one's parliamentary career and what one has done. On that score let others judge. I do not care to do so. I just mention that when I was a Whip and we brought down the guillotine, we did not just bring down a guillotine, we brought down a guillotine with a gag attached. But in any event, Mr President, I did come here with less understanding than I have now. I have taken part in some great events; some of them quite painful to those dear to me; and some have been mentioned today. The thing about it is that one grows in the process of moving through those events, whether it is 1975, 1987 or whatever. I have grown in terms of passion and in terms of clarity of view. I have grown because of the crises and I would not have avoided them.

This question of growth and understanding-perhaps it is the same with all honourable senators. Honourable senators should leave this place with no apologies and they should remember that senators are a better quality than people outside generally acknowledge, even if they are not always of the quality they give themselves. But senators, if I may say so, do lack a sense of history. There is a story about General Douglas MacArthur, to whom an apology was made by a newspaper, I think in San Francisco, in which it said that it had made the great error of undervaluing him simply because he overvalued himself. That is a good story.

Perhaps honourable senators might consider that we sometimes lack a sense of historical perspective. We sometimes ignore the lessons of those who built up the Senate over 90 years since Federation. If we do forget those lessons, Mr President, we know that we are doomed to relearn them the painful way.

Retirement from the Parliament is one such matter. There are people who have been here previously who have given some very good advice about retirement. I think the only privy councillor we have had in recent years, Senator the Rt Hon. Reg Withers, advised me not once but three times, and twice in writing, to get out. He made the point that those who left voluntarily do so with much less bitterness than those whose retirement is forced upon them. Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has probably told Senator Kemp the same thing. She told me that she has not missed the place once since she left. Sir Robert Cotton made a complete break when he left, after a very distinguished career here. And of course, Senator Powell, your predecessor, Senator Michael Macklin, having made his own decision, spent the next three months urging me to follow him-which I am now doing.

Honourable senators sometimes think that the Senate began when they arrived and that it will end when they leave; that its only existence is for that brief period when honourable senators are here. Because I am leaving today, I do not have that view. Honourable senators sometimes think that they are immortal and invincible. They know in an intellectual sense that they will go some time, but that is something to be put off. The Senate only exists because they are here.

Well, in medicine we sometimes talk about the process that we call denial. It is quite useful sometimes, but it can be difficult if it is taken too far. `Golden lads and girls' who read Cymbeline might care to remember their inevitable association with chimney sweepers. It is the institution, Mr President, that is continuous. It is the Senate that continues; not the senators. The Senate outlasts Presidents, Clerks, officers and senators.

Since I arrived here, I have seen some absolutely amazing characters leave this place. Senator Justin O'Byrne was a senator for 33 years. We have only had the Senate existing since 1901, for 90 years. He served a large part of that time. Then there was Senator Sir Reginald Wright, and also Senator Ian Wood, who served 27 years. Senator Douglas McClelland and Senator Peter Rae served 20 years each. Yet, when each of them left, they were forgotten one day later; it was as if they had never been here. That is as it should be. The view of the Senate is resolutely towards the future. There is little time for any regrets or any farewells, and almost no time for a backward glance.

Senator Button, Senator Walsh and I came into the Senate at the same time-I think only Senator Durack, the father of the Senate, has been here longer. In the Parliament which I entered I had as Party colleagues John Gorton, Don Chipp, Bill Snedden, Ian Macphee and Alan Missen-all of whom just happened to be good liberals and all of whom are now gone. They were forgotten one day after they left.

It does not matter how long honourable senators serve; their role is in helping the institution. It does not matter, Mr Clerk, how long you are here; you are but the present Clerk in a line that stretches from the past and will carry on into the future. It does not matter, Black Rod, how long you are here; you are the link between the Black Rods past and present. It is the same for all honourable senators. So I look forward, with some pleasure, to knowing who it is that my division will eventually choose to replace me and who will come here next year in my place.

I mentioned the General of the United Army, Douglas MacArthur. As an old man he returned to the United States Military Academy at West Point, of which he had been Commandant, to receive the highest honour that the Academy could confer. And he made an amazing speech-he used no notes at the age of 82. In the peroration of that speech he mentioned that wherever he was his mind would come back always to, `The corps, and the corps, and the corps . . . '. The best testament to the service of any individual senator in this place will be not what rank he or she achieved-whether that senator was a Minister, whether that senator got into Cabinet, whether that senator did this or that. The best testament will be through his or her part in sustaining and developing the Senate itself; in contributing to the vigour of the Senate, in contributing to its procedures, to its capacities and to its role and to determining whether the senators have contributed towards the strength of the Parliament.

I remind honourable senators that a former senator, Fred Chaney, was once asked whether the parliament lacked power. Chaney's answer was that the parliament lacks no power, what it lacks is parliamentarians to use the power it has. Each of us have a duty to think about our contribution and our role in the parliament. I say to officers: I have set these things out so you can know what my objectives are and if you wish to question me later we can go into performance indicators and performance standards. When Arthur William Edgar O'Shaughnessy wrote a very famous poem, he ended it with the lines:
For each age is a dream that is dying; or one that is coming to birth.

He could have been talking about the Senate and its progress, movement and change. I leave now in line with the advice of Reg Withers, at a time of my own choosing, to go to a career of my own choosing-to a third career; to a position of value and worth to teach medical students in a fine department in a great university. Of course, there is sadness and loss, particularly with regard to the friendships and the company of significant people. But I go to do more work to contribute to the education of young doctors. So, Mr President, I will not be here when you return in February, but always there will remain in my mind the Senate, and the Senate, and the Senate. I wish you all well and I wish you good fortune for your remaining time here and for the work you undertake on behalf of this institution and this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time is short and I shall be brief but sincere. For 14 years Peter Baume has been my friend, my companion and, on many occasions, my adviser. I shall miss him. My wife will miss him. And we shall miss Jenny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that Peter did not think he was now closing the debate because there are still a few of us who would like to say just a few things about him. I have worked with Peter in roughly the same area of interest for the past 15 years, but particularly in my first three or four years in this place when Peter and I served on the same committees. Peter and I have disagreed on many issues. It started with the first report we put out together. Peter was the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare which released a report entitled Drug Problems in Australia-an Intoxicated Society? Senator Peter Baume, Senator Grimes and I were members of that particular Committee, along with others who have now left the Senate. As honourable senators would be aware, Senator Grimes has also left the Senate. But I mention his name because he also contributed to the next report we compiled, which was entitled Through a Glass Darkly. Senator Baume was also Chairman of that Committee, and it was one that I found fascinating as a fairly new senator because I can tell my colleagues who are unaware that this is really what started the real evaluation process that has gone on ever since. We called that report Through a Glass Darkly because there was no evaluation, not only within the Government, of any of the programs that the Government put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember Senator Peter Baume asking the senior departmental officer of the Department of Health, `What is the purpose of hospitals?'. The officer said, `Would you mind repeating your question?', and Senator Baume said, `It is a very simple question. What is the purpose of your hospitals?'. The officer said, `I am sorry, Senator, I just don't understand your question'. That was the first indication to me of just how far we were going.

I remember very well Senator Baume asking the head departmental officer of the Department of Social Security, `How do you assess that your policies are really reaching the people that they are meant to reach?'. The officer replied, `From the correspondence we get in'. Senator Baume said, `Would you like to rephrase that?', and the departmental officer said, `No, I would not like to rephrase that. It is exactly how the Department works'. That, of course, caused quite a discussion along the lines of what happens to all of those people who would never think, or be capable, of writing a letter to the Department to say, `You are not reaching me'.

I intend to keep my remarks very short because I have just had the nod from so many of my colleagues who want to join me in speaking for just a few minutes. But I think that I have priority because I have been here for a lot longer and I have worked with Senator Baume in so many areas. As I have said, even though we disagreed about many things right from the first report-although I would say that there were only about three areas upon which we have disagreed, Peter-we have agreed on by far the majority of occasions. Senator Baume, I certainly wish you everything you could possibly wish yourself in your next career.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Reid. I am being placed in an impossible position because I have not called on anybody from the Government side for some time. So I ask honourable senators to make their remarks brief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always happy to wait until near the end on such occasions as there are only two of us here who do not have far to travel to get home. I want to say to Senator McKiernan, Senator Foreman and Senator Faulkner, `Happy Christmas, and thank you for the working arrangement that we have had'. I most certainly include Senator McLean in that. We have had a busy session due to the introduction of the Selection of Bills Committee operations and also, to an extent, perhaps due to the televising of Parliament, but I think the Whips' office jointly has worked extremely well.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Bjelke-Petersen for her contribution and the help she has given Sue Knowles and me during this session while Senator Brownhill has been on the United Nations trip.

In particular, I place on record my thanks-and I think that of all Opposition senators-to Kathy Cornford for the way she runs the Whip's office and for her enormous contribution to the smooth running of the Opposition in the Parliament. I also thank Michele Cornwell and Rob Jones. They have had to learn the new procedures, just as we have.

I will briefly speak about Peter Baume. He is a former Whip and he has set a high standard for Whips. He has always been extremely helpful to me since I became Deputy Whip. He has a subtle way of letting you know what should be done in a way that you always accept as meaningful and of value. I have known him since shortly after he came into the Parliament, as I was active in the Party organisation at that time. I most certainly have valued his and Jenny's friendship, which we will make sure that we retain.

The highlight of Tom's and my involvement with Jenny and Peter Baume was touring Israel in a group with them. It is neither the time nor the place to go into what is one of the outstanding 10-day periods of our lives, greatly contributed to, Peter, by your knowledge, empathy and care of the place and what you were able to convey to all of us who were with you at that time. It is certainly something I shall always remember. Best wishes, Jenny and Peter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the time I will be very brief. My remarks are directed to Senator Peter Baume. I agree with all the remarks that have been made about Senator Peter Baume and I think they can be summed up in the following way: you are an outstanding parliamentarian. I know that I will never match your qualities as a parliamentarian. You are a brilliant Liberal-in the true meaning of the word Liberal. You have been a brilliant Liberal in the long tradition of the last 200 years of Liberal philosophy. Your speeches on the War Crimes Bill and in the immigration debate in the last session are still the two best speeches I have heard in the Parliament in my short time here.

SPEECH.PARA: You are a good Australian because of your concern for the wider community and your interest in a wide range of issues. I, as a person who does not follow any organised or orthodox religion, have a humanitarian bent. The only description I can give you from a humanist point of view is how I hope some people will describe me one day-you are a great human being.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to the honourable Senator, Doctor, Professor Peter Baume. In so doing, I say briefly that as a new chum on the block, Peter Baume has challenged me intellectually on a number of issues when he sometimes thought that I could have seen another view. He has coached me in procedure and, in particular, in performance on Estimates. I think that his wisest counsel there has been to say, `If you don't know the answer, don't ask the question'. He has also been a counsellor to whom I have turned a couple of times in personal need. As a challenger, as a coach and a counsellor he has been a great colleague. As Antony said, and I am sorry it is in the past tense:

SPEECH.PARA: His life was gentle and the elements
So mixed in him that nature might stand up
And say to all the world `This was a man'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an even newer chum, I was moved by Senator Peter Baume's speech. He left me, as a new boy, with three messages. The first is his great love of this chamber and the huge potential that this chamber has. The second is the fact that we are but a link in a long chain. The third is that how strong that link is and how effective we are, how effective this chamber will be. I thank you Senator for those thoughts. They are most valuable.

SPEECH.PARA: As a new chum I briefly mention the enormous amount of help that I-and I am sure my colleagues-have received in my induction to this chamber. I particularly thank you, Mr President. The training course that you presided over in the early days was most helpful. I thank you for that. I might say-in some encouragement-no matter how bad people think this chamber is, I spent some time as a staff member in the other place, and we are still miles ahead. But we still have a long way to go.

I particularly thank the Clerks for their help and guidance and for the courses that they gave perhaps to try to encourage us to not adopt the bad habits of the chamber but to adopt the appropriate procedures and appropriate performance. To you, Mr Clerk, Harry Evans, Anne Lynch, Peter O'Keeffe, Cleaver Elliott, John Vander Wyk and Michele Cornwell-and I hope I have not missed others-thank you for all your help in those early days.
In conclusion-and I am sorry to have to say this-I personally deplore the comments by Senator Coates this morning in his most unfortunate and cowardly attack on the Clerk.

Finally-I leave honourable senators with the thought that Senator Peter Baume expressed-we should sustain, develop and improve the role of the Senate. That is quite right. I hope that I and my new colleagues will prove worthy of you. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise as one of the new chums. I wish to add my appreciation for the work that this chamber, you, Mr President, the Deputy President and the Clerks are doing. I also wish to distance myself from the motion moved today. When I came into this chamber I was somewhat surprised not only by the support, the efficiency and the cheerfulness with which all help was offered but also by a certain quality of deference. In fact, I was occasionally embarrassed by it. I hope that we do not take this too far-that we do not take it to the point where we deny people who work very hard in this chamber and who believe, as we do, in the ideals of what we are doing and the right to express an opinion. I know that that kind of humility would cause some of my friends to look at me with some degree of surprise but I can assure honourable senators that on this occasion it is genuine.

SPEECH.PARA: Peter Baume and I go back a long time. I first met him in the mid-1970s when he, although in the Opposition party, supported the Australian assistance program, which I was intimately connected with. I appreciated his position then. To this day he has continued this tradition of independence and commitment to issues. I have some personal appreciation of the private member's Bill that he brought forward two days ago. Seeing that I, as a child, witnessed war crimes at first hand committed by people of many nations, and provided there is agreement from other honourable senators, I would be honoured indeed were I able to continue the work on that Bill. Senator Baume, we shall all miss you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I held back because I wanted to make sure that Opposition senators had the opportunity of paying tribute to Peter. I will be very brief. My life has been intertwined with his from the time he was a medical student and I was an apprentice. I have watched his career go through those phases: he became a doctor, a specialist and then a Minister. Of course, I have had the experience of working with him in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Most things have been said, but on behalf of the Committee that I chair, I say that I think that we all appreciate-particularly those of us who did not go to university-the training he has given us. He has made sure that we say what we mean and are sharp in the way that we express things. I have certainly learned, and I know that my colleagues appreciate it. It is good for him to go back to the university with the experience of having trained us and worked with the raw material-us. I would like to be associated with all the things that have been said. But I know that others want to speak and that is why I have been very brief.

TALK.START.PARA: —I promise to be brief and will be brief. I too want to pay tribute to Peter Baume. I think he is a very genuine, principled man. I think he is a very fine Australian. I have served only a short time in this chamber with him but I have valued our friendship over the years. I say to Peter Baume: honourable senators more erudite than I might say that you are a rose among thorns as far as your role in the Opposition is concerned. I thought that I would conclude my remarks by using some very old Australian slang to reflect my attitude to Peter: you are indeed a lily on a dustbin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I waited, because it will be evident from what I say, that I hoped to be the last speaker. Mr President, first of all I want to thank you and Harry Evans and his department for the orientation course given to the new senators. Speaking as the newest of the new, as you will appreciate, it was a culture shock to be in this body of people having come from the real world to this different world.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to dispute something that Peter Baume said, and I speak as one of his colleagues. Perhaps he will not be here physically but he will be in spirit. He has already written to me about some matter that he wishes to carry on in the future. I hope that I can carry on some of the matters in this Senate which Peter wishes to see continued. I am sure that we have not heard the last of him, even though he has said that today.

Finally, as a new boy, I want to assure the people of Australia that they see here the theatre in the round as the various actors perform. Behind the scenes I have been enormously impressed with the committee work that occurs, the genuine camaraderie that exists on both sides of the chamber and, as Peter mentioned earlier, the collegiality of my own Party. I wish to thank all the people who have made all the new senators so welcome to this Parliament. I am sure that we all look forward to serving with our fellow senators, all the clerks and the attendants in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall just add my words to the many great tributes that have been paid to Senator Peter Baume. The remarkable thing is that none has been hyperbole, even though the tributes have been great and penetrating analyses of a man, which would normally result in hyperbole. Peter Baume has always struck me as a great spiritual figure in this chamber. It goes to show the worth of a spiritual man. It shows that, through great spiritual qualities, great good can come to very many people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes the greatest tribute a person can pay to a colleague is to adopt silence. To you, Peter Baume, we nod our heads.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 10 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's department or any agency for which the Minister is responsible entered into any contracts with Gary Morgan's company, Roy Morgan Research Centre, since 1975; if so, for each contract since 1975;
(a) was there a specific contract; if so, what were the specifications of the contract and was it altered after it was entered into; if not, why not;
(b) what was the fee;
(c) was the contract put out to tender; if so, why was Roy Morgan Research Centre chosen; if not, why not, and why was the Centre chosen;
(d) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to supply a copy of the questionnaire;
(e) did the Centre supply a copy of the full questionnaire used to conduct the survey; if so, please provide a copy of the full questionnaire;

(f) if a part only of the questionnaire was supplied, was the Minister's department or agency aware of the exact nature of the full questionnaire; if not, why not, and what safeguards were taken to ensure there was no conflict of interest or subject bias;
(g) were there any questions asked by the Centre which were not included in the report supplied by the Centre; if so, what were they;
(h) please provide a copy of the Centre's report;

(i) if, for whatever reason, the Minister's department or agency will not provide a copy of the report, please provide an outline of its contents and an explanation as to why the Minister's department or agency refuses to provide a copy;

(j) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to provide a computer printout of the survey; if so, did the Centre provide an interpretation of the survey results; if not, what special skills and qualifications does the Minister's department or agency have in the interpretation of attitudinal survey data and please provide an outline of how the survey data was interpreted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Industrial Relations was created on 23 July 1987. Information on all contracts that may have been entered into by the predecessor Departments prior to that date is not readily available. Since July 1987 the department has not entered into contracts with Roy Morgan Research Centre. Available records suggest that no contracts were entered into with Roy Morgan Research Centre for several years prior to 1987.
None of the current agencies within the Industrial Relations portfolio, namely:
National Occupational Health and Safety Commission;
has entered into contracts with the Roy Morgan Research Centre since their creation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 18 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to the recent closure of Deluxe Coachlines, what protection is there for the entitlements of the employees of Deluxe.
(2) What protection is there for Deluxe customers who have purchased pre-paid travel fares.
(3) What assurances have been given to the Australian travelling public that adequate bus services will be maintained, given that Deluxe Coachlines held roughly 45 per cent of the bus travel market.
(4) What ongoing plan is in place for coach building in Australia after the recent flood of over 170 coaches onto the Australian market.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The failure of businesses, for whatever reason, are matters for regret. However I consider that it is not appropriate for government to involve itself in the day to day operations of particular industries or members of those industries except to the extent that matters of safety or other regulation need to be addressed from a federal perspective.
The matters raised by Senator Kernot are not specifically matters for the land transport portfolio and I have consulted with appropriate Ministers in the preparation of this response.
In the light of these comments, the answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

(1) I am advised that there were no special provisions in the awards of the employees of Deluxe Coachlines that would provide any additional benefits in the event of the failure of the organisation. Accordingly, the employees were entitled to one week's wages in lieu of notice in addition to accrued wages, leave and other entitlements.

These entitlements become calls on the company and rank for distribution of the asset disposal proceeds of the company according to the normal rules for such distributions. The distribution in the case of Deluxe is a matter for the Receiver having regard to the status of other creditors.

(2) There are no protections available to the purchasers of prepaid travel fares other than that they may have a claim against the distribution of the proceeds of the disposal of Deluxe's assets. The ranking of these passengers would depend on the status of other creditors.

I understand that other carriers provided assistance to Deluxe passengers in the first week or so after the company ceased to operate where those carriers had spare capacity. This provided relief to a large number of travellers who might otherwise have been stranded and I would like to commend those carriers for providing this assistance.
(3) The bus travel market has been oversupplied for some time. Significant increase in capacity was provided by the industry to meet expected demand for the Bicentennial and Expo.
Industry sources indicate that patronage has declined significantly since then and that the capacity provided by existing operators is adequate to meet existing and anticipated demand.

(4) No special federal government assistance is currently made available to the coach building industry in Australia. The government takes the view that industry is capable of planning for all levels of demand, both high and low. The industry, like any other, operates in a commercial environment and planning decisions are the proper province for industry management.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 12 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government yet made any and what request to State or Territory governments to share capital and recurrent costs for the additional centre-based places in the community and for additional outside school hours child care as promised in the last election campaign and reiterated in the recent budget; if so, what responses if any, have been received to date.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister met with State/Territory Ministers responsible for child care on 10 August 1990 to discuss the Commonwealth's proposal for the expansion of the National Child Care Strategy as announced in the 1990 election context and confirmed in the 1990-91 Budget.

The Minister presented to State Ministers a proposal for the split of new places between States by service type together with Commonwealth estimates of state capital and recurrent contributions under the cost sharing arrangements.

The Minister has since written to State/Territory Ministers to suggest that officers finalise details in bilateral discussions in early 1991. A formal agreement with each State/Territory will follow from these discussions.
As bilateral negotiations have not yet commenced no formal response has been received to date.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 15 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What studies, if any, have been conducted in 1989 and 1990 into the feasibility of converting the Adelaide to Melbourne railway to standard gauge.
(2) What is the latest cost estimate for this possible project.
(3) Does one extra option still involve the standardisation of the railway from Wolseley to Mount Gambier, with a direct connection from Mount Gambier to cities in Victoria.
(4) Is the overall Melbourne-Adelaide project still under review; if not, what is the major obstacle to the project's proceeding.
(5) What is the current position of the State Government of Victoria in respect of the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following a series of benefit/cost studies on Adelaide-Melbourne standardisation undertaken during 1988 by the Australian National Railways Commission (AN) and V/Line, there has been only a limited amount of work undertaken.
Studies undertaken during 1989 and 1990 were preliminary engineering studies of alternative routes to avoid the steep grades, tight curves and restrictive tunnels through the Adelaide Hills.
Major investigative work has been suspended pending developments on the National Freight Initiative.

Following a submission by AN, the Minister for Land Transport recently approved funding from the Australian Centennial Roads Development program of $21.029 million over a three year period to upgrade a 100 km section of the main south line from Coonalpyn to the Victorian border. AN is in the process of letting contracts for this project.
The upgrading will include replacement of poor condition wooden sleepers, with concrete, gauge convertible sleepers.

(2) Cost estimates have been prepared for a number of options. Simple standardisation on the existing corridor has been estimated at $90m but this would not involve any alignment upgrades and would preserve the tight curves and height and speed restrictions through the Adelaide Hills, and alignment problems elsewhere such as near Bacchus Marsh. Standardisation with a new, improved alignment through the Adelaide Hills has been costed at $350m. Standardisation with a new alignment through the Adelaide Hills and a track upgrade elsewhere, including the easing of grades and all tight curves with improved alignment options to enable full double stacking and lifting of speed restrictions, has been estimated to cost $550m. All figures are in June 1989 values.

(3) The matter of the Wolseley to Mount Gambier line has not been considered further since the 1988 studies. The options considered then included the standardisation of the Wolseley to Mount Gambier link and retention of broad gauge (possibly involving mixed gauge) into Victoria.

(4) The National Freight Initiative should provide an opportunity for standardisation of Adelaide-Melbourne to be considered further. A National Network Study, which will include consideration of the Melbourne-Adelaide standard gauge project, has been proposed for funding under the $50 million allocation which the Minister for Land Transport announced would be made available from the Centennial Roads Development program for rail infrastructure upgrading proposals in connection with the National Freight Initiative.
(5) The current position of the State Government of Victoria in respect of the project is not known.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did consultants present a report on commercial vehicles for the defence forces at the end of 1988; if so, what is the name of this report, what did it contain and is it possible to obtain a copy.
(2) Have any of the recommendations of the report been implemented; if so, which ones.

(3) Has there been any resistance to introducing management information systems and commercial vehicle management practices to manage the Services' vehicle fleets; if so, what resistance and from where.
(4) Are the Services aware of the personnel costs involved in operating commercial vehicle fleets, if so, are any reports made to senior management.
(5) Is it correct that the Services do not know what their real operating costs are for fuel, oil, servicing, spare parts, labour, tyres, repairs and accidents.
(6) Has there been an increase in the contracting out of the management of commercial vehicles; if so, what is the current situation in regard to this.
(7) Has the Department of Defence estimated what it might cost to commercialise the Services' vehicle fleets; if so, what are the costs and if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Pak-Poy and Kneebone Pty Ltd with Henderson Consultants reviewed the Defence commercial vehicle fleets in 1988 with assistance from a Defence Review Team and presented the following reports:
Consultancy Study-Army Commercial Vehicle Fleet Phase 1B
Consultancy Study-Review of Defence Commercial Vehicle Fleet Phase 2 (Navy, Air Force, remainder of Defence)
Copies of these reports are available.
(2) The following recommendations agreed by the Services are being implemented:

The Services should maintain the ownership of their CL vehicle fleets but in so doing should adopt new acquisition and disposal criteria which are no less advantageous than those pursued by DAS and commercial operators.

Even though there would be a long term cost advantage from the Department owning its own fleet, at this stage it should continue to hire its CL vehicles from DAS where it does so at present (ownership would require Government approval for an exemption from current rules).

A substantially self-funding arrangement should be adopted in which funds generated from the disposal of Service CL vehicles are preserved and applied directly to the procurement of replacement Service CL vehicles.
In the present sales tax free environment, a basic replacement criteria of 2 years/40000 km should be adopted to maximise the sales tax advantages of self-funding.

An automated fleet management information system (Fleet MIS) should be introduced by each Vehicle Controller within Defence to provide information to allow managers to make timely decisions and to enable their fleets, as a whole, to be operated in a cost-effective manner.
The arrangements and organisational structures for the management of the various fleets should be simplified and the resources devoted to vehicle fleet management should be reduced.
A standardised system of vehicle nomenclature and groupings should be adopted throughout Defence.
VIP and ceremonial Service vehicles should continue to be purchased in Service colours. Other vehicles should be purchased in colours which maximise the returns from sale.
Defence air-conditioning policies should be reviewed.
Vehicles should be purchased with accessories, options and specifications which would optimise returns from sale.
Whole of life costs should be considered during acquisition.
Defence should establish and maintain appropriate channels of communication with DAS and pursue the scope for obtaining discounts in other than just the long haul area.
The scope for increased use of civilian contractors for repair and maintenance should be examined.
A series of initiatives should be taken to develop and introduce disposal arrangements which would optimise returns from the sale of Defence owned vehicles.

(3) In the early stages, some resistance was experienced but, as staff have become better informed and more aware of the benefits of improved fleet management practices, this resistance is no longer evident and indeed has been replaced by support.

(4) The Services are aware, at the macro level, of the personnel costs involved in operating commercial vehicle fleets. There is not the same awareness at the micro levels where the actual vehicles are managed. There are currently no regular reports of these particular personnel costs made to senior management. However the Commercial Vehicle Management Program initiatives now being introduced will improve visibility of these costs at all levels of management.

(5) As with personnel costs, vehicle operating and maintenance costs are available at a macro level. Current management information systems do not readily provide detailed information on operating costs for commercial vehicles. The introduction of a new Fleet Management Information System in early 1991 will provide the means for the Services to capture, analyse and report this information down to the level of individual vehicles if required.
(6) The management of the Services commercial vehicle fleets is not contracted out. The consultants recommended that the management of commercial vehicles remain within Defence.

(7) The estimated cost to bring the Services' commercial vehicle fleets up to an efficient standard was an additional $36m over two years. Substantial savings would then accrue. These funds are not available and a longer term funding option is being undertaken with additional funds being provided to the Services for implementation of the initiatives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 26 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the report of the Review of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation conducted by Mr Charles Perkins and Dr Jeremy Long been concluded?
(2) Has the Aboriginal Arts Unit of the Australia Council made a response to the report or in any way amended the report?

(3) Has the Aboriginal Arts Committee for the Australia Council formulated any proposals for the continued and long-term funding/support for the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation; and if so, are any such proposals consistent with the original recommendations of the report by Mr Perkins and Dr Long?

(4) What consultations have been conducted between the Australia Council, the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation, ATSIC and the Northern Territory Government to guarantee continuing and long term funding/support for traditional-cultural heritage in Northern Australia?
(5) Can copies of the Perkins/Long report and responses and/or alterations of the Aboriginal Arts Unit and Australia Council decisions be tabled in the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism, and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) The Aboriginal Arts Committee considered the draft report at its meeting of 13 and 14 September 1990. Following this meeting the Director of the Aboriginal Arts Unit, which provides administrative support for the Committee, notified the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation (ACF) that funding would cease from 1 January 1992 given that, with the development of new administrative structures for Aboriginal affairs and the increasing demands made on the Committee's funding, the ACF would be more appropriately funded through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). This decision is consistent with recommendations made in the draft report. The draft report has not been amended by the Aboriginal Arts Unit.

(4) The Australia Council has an extensive national program of support for traditional cultural heritage which includes support for festivals and ceremonial activities, dance groups and art centres in Northern Australia. Officers of the Aboriginal Arts Unit have ongoing consultations on this subject with a range of organisations in this field, including those referred to. The Australia Council has previously had discussions with the ACF, ATSIC and the Northern Territory Government about ACF funding. The ACF and ATSIC have been informed of the decision to cease ACF funding, and the reasons for doing so.

(5) It is expected that the final report will be completed by the end of December 1990 for submission to the Aboriginal Arts Committee. A copy of the report, together with any responses of the Aboriginal Arts Unit and Australia Council decisions on the matter, can be made available to the Honourable Senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 28 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funds have been approved for the Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) over the last five years.
(2) What Australian content requirements are applied to exports approved for DIFF assistance.

(3) Were checks carried out on Australian content conditions in relation to all of the above DIFF funds approvals; if not, is there a possibility that Australian funds were used in support of exports of goods and/or services that failed to meet Australian content requirements.
(4) Have checks ever revealed a failure to meet Australian content requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following funds have been approved for the Development Import Finance Facility since the 1985-86 financial year:
These funds are associated with export credits from the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation of the Australian Trade Commission (AUSTRADE-EFIC).

(2) The Australian content requirements applying to exports approved for DIFF assistance are that the equipment or service being exported must be wholly or mainly of Australian origin. The figure generally agreed upon between AIDAB and AUSTRADE-EFIC is at least 75% Australian content.

(3) All the required checks have been, and are being carried out by AUSTRADE-EFIC on the Australian content level of DIFF-supported projects. This is part of established AUSTRADE-EFIC procedures undertaken before the exporter receives payment for goods and services supplied. These procedures include a signed Exporter's Declaration that must accompany all claims for payment. The Declaration requires the exporter to indicate any goods, for which payment is claimed, that are not wholly produced or manufactured in Australia. A similar declaration is required for services.

Following the increase in funds allocated to DIFF, a Project Monitoring Unit was established within AUSTRADE-EFIC in November 1989. The Unit's objectives are to monitor the progress of projects for which loan funds are being drawn, and to establish in greater detail project compliance with various requirements, including Australian content.
(4) The above checks have led to several enquiries to exporters. In all cases the Australian content level was found to be within the required limit.

(2) I am unaware of the development referred to by the honourable senator. I can only suggest that any such developments should be brought to the attention of the College, or other appropriate scientific body.
